ğŸ”¹ 4. Password Credentials Flow (Legacy Approach) ğŸ”¹

Used in **trusted applications** where the client directly collects the user's **username & password**. 


1. The user provides credentials to the app.
2. The app exchanges credentials for an **Access Token**.
3. The token is used to access resources.
ğŸ”¹ 5. Device Authorization Flow (For IoT Devices) ğŸ”¹

Used for **devices without browsers** (e.g., Smart TVs, IoT devices). The user logs in on a different device. 


1. The device requests authorization.
2. The user logs in on another device and enters a code.
3. The server issues an **Access Token**.
4. The device uses the token for API requests.
ğŸ“Œ Example: OAuth 2.0 with Spring Boot

@Configuration
@EnableWebSecurity
public class SecurityConfig {
    @Bean
    public SecurityFilterChain securityFilterChain(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
        http.oauth2Login();
        return http.build();
    }
}
âœ… Summary Table
Flow Use Case Security Level
Authorization Code Web apps, secure login ğŸ”’ High
Implicit SPA (Client-side apps) âš ï¸ Low (Token in URL)
Client Credentials Machine-to-Machine ğŸ”’ High
Password Credentials Trusted legacy apps âš ï¸ Medium (Credentials shared)
Device Authorization IoT devices, TVs ğŸ”’ High
âœ… Key Takeaways
  • OAuth 2.0 enables **secure authorization** without sharing passwords.
  • **Authorization Code Flow** is the most secure and widely used.
  • Use **Client Credentials Flow** for microservices communication.
  • Implicit and Password Grant Types are **not recommended** for new applications.

Unit testing in Spring Boot ensures that individual components (such as services, controllers, and repositories) function correctly in isolation.

ğŸ“Œ Key Components of Unit Testing
  • JUnit 5 (Jupiter) - Testing framework.
  • Mockito - For mocking dependencies.
  • Spring Boot Test - Provides testing utilities.
  • AssertJ/Hamcrest - Assertion libraries for better test readability.
âœ… 1. Setup Dependencies

Add the required dependencies in pom.xml:


<dependencies>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
        <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-test</artifactId>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.mockito</groupId>
        <artifactId>mockito-core</artifactId>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
</dependencies>
âœ… 2. Testing a Service Layer with Mockito

Let's assume we have a simple **UserService** that fetches user data from a repository.


@Service
public class UserService {
    private final UserRepository userRepository;

    public UserService(UserRepository userRepository) {
        this.userRepository = userRepository;
    }

    public User getUserById(Long id) {
        return userRepository.findById(id)
                .orElseThrow(() -> new UserNotFoundException("User not found"));
    }
}

Now, let's write a **unit test** for this service.


@ExtendWith(MockitoExtension.class)
public class UserServiceTest {

    @Mock
    private UserRepository userRepository;

    @InjectMocks
    private UserService userService;

    @Test
    void testGetUserById_Success() {
        User mockUser = new User(1L, "John Doe");
        when(userRepository.findById(1L)).thenReturn(Optional.of(mockUser));

        User user = userService.getUserById(1L);

        assertNotNull(user);
        assertEquals("John Doe", user.getName());
        verify(userRepository, times(1)).findById(1L);
    }

    @Test
    void testGetUserById_NotFound() {
        when(userRepository.findById(2L)).thenReturn(Optional.empty());

        assertThrows(UserNotFoundException.class, () -> userService.getUserById(2L));
    }
}
âœ… 3. Testing a Controller Layer with MockMvc

Let's assume we have a **UserController**.


@RestController
@RequestMapping("/users")
public class UserController {
    private final UserService userService;

    public UserController(UserService userService) {
        this.userService = userService;
    }

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    public ResponseEntity<User> getUserById(@PathVariable Long id) {
        return ResponseEntity.ok(userService.getUserById(id));
    }
}

Now, let's write a unit test using **MockMvc**.


@WebMvcTest(UserController.class)
public class UserControllerTest {

    @Autowired
    private MockMvc mockMvc;

    @MockBean
    private UserService userService;

    @Test
    void testGetUserById_Success() throws Exception {
        User mockUser = new User(1L, "John Doe");
        when(userService.getUserById(1L)).thenReturn(mockUser);

        mockMvc.perform(get("/users/1"))
                .andExpect(status().isOk())
                .andExpect(jsonPath("$.name").value("John Doe"));
    }

    @Test
    void testGetUserById_NotFound() throws Exception {
        when(userService.getUserById(2L)).thenThrow(new UserNotFoundException("User not found"));

        mockMvc.perform(get("/users/2"))
                .andExpect(status().isNotFound());
    }
}
âœ… Summary
  • Use **Mockito** to mock dependencies in service layer tests.
  • Use **MockMvc** to test controllers without starting the full application.
  • **Assertions** ensure expected outputs.
  • Test **exception handling** and edge cases.

Code Coverage is a metric that measures the percentage of your source code executed by your test cases. It helps ensure that critical parts of your application are tested and reduces the risk of undetected bugs.

ğŸ“Œ How Code Coverage Works

During test execution, a code coverage tool tracks which lines, branches, and paths in the source code are executed. The result is then displayed as a report, showing coverage percentages.

âœ… Key Code Coverage Metrics
  • Line Coverage: Percentage of code lines executed by tests.
  • Branch Coverage: Ensures both if and else branches are tested.
  • Method Coverage: Ensures each method is executed at least once.
  • Path Coverage: Ensures all possible execution paths in a method are tested.
âœ… Popular Code Coverage Tools
  • JaCoCo (Java Code Coverage): A widely used tool for Java applications.
  • Cobertura: Another Java coverage tool, but less popular than JaCoCo.
  • SonarQube: Provides advanced analysis, including code quality and coverage.
  • Emma: A lightweight coverage tool for Java.
âœ… 1. Using JaCoCo in Spring Boot

Add the following dependency in pom.xml:


<plugin>
    <groupId>org.jacoco</groupId>
    <artifactId>jacoco-maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>0.8.7</version>
    <executions>
        <execution>
            <goals>
                <goal>prepare-agent</goal>
            </goals>
        </execution>
        <execution>
            <id>report</id>
            <phase>verify</phase>
            <goals>
                <goal>report</goal>
            </goals>
        </execution>
    </executions>
</plugin>
âœ… 2. Running JaCoCo

Execute the following command to generate the coverage report:


mvn clean test
mvn jacoco:report

The HTML report will be generated in target/site/jacoco/index.html.

âœ… 3. Checking Code Coverage in IntelliJ IDEA
  1. Run tests with coverage: Ctrl + Shift + F10 â†’ "Run with Coverage".
  2. View the coverage report in the **Coverage Tool Window**.
âœ… 4. Enforcing Code Coverage in CI/CD

To fail the build if coverage is below a threshold, add this in pom.xml:


<configuration>
    <rules>
        <rule>
            <element>CLASS</element>
            <limits>
                <limit>
                    <counter>LINE</counter>
                    <value>COVEREDRATIO</value>
                    <minimum>0.80</minimum>
                </limit>
            </limits>
        </rule>
    </rules>
</configuration>
âœ… Summary
  • Code coverage helps identify untested parts of the application.
  • JaCoCo is the most popular tool for Java applications.
  • Use coverage reports to improve test quality and prevent regressions.
  • Integrate coverage checks in CI/CD to maintain high test standards.

You can achieve this by using Java 8's Collectors.groupingBy() in combination with Collectors.counting() and Collectors.groupingBy() again.

ğŸ“¦ Employee Model

class Employee {
    private String name;
    private String gender;
    private String department;

    // Constructor, Getters, Setters
    public Employee(String name, String gender, String department) {
        this.name = name;
        this.gender = gender;
        this.department = department;
    }

    public String getGender() { return gender; }
    public String getDepartment() { return department; }
}
ğŸ§  Java 8 Stream Code

List<Employee> employees = Arrays.asList(
    new Employee("John", "Male", "HR"),
    new Employee("Sara", "Female", "HR"),
    new Employee("Mike", "Male", "IT"),
    new Employee("Emma", "Female", "IT"),
    new Employee("Tom", "Male", "Finance")
);

Map<String, Map<String, Long>> genderCountByDept = employees.stream()
    .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(
        Employee::getDepartment,
        Collectors.groupingBy(Employee::getGender, Collectors.counting())
    ));
ğŸ” Output Example

{
  HR={Male=1, Female=1},
  IT={Male=1, Female=1},
  Finance={Male=1}
}
âœ… Explanation
  • groupingBy(Employee::getDepartment) groups by department
  • groupingBy(Employee::getGender) groups by gender inside each department
  • counting() counts the number of occurrences

âœ”ï¸ This approach is clean and efficient for categorizing and counting data in complex nested structures using Streams.

NULL represents the absence of a value in SQL. Special care is needed to handle it correctly in conditions and functions.

ğŸ” 1. Using IS NULL / IS NOT NULL

SELECT * FROM employees
WHERE department IS NULL;

Use IS NULL or IS NOT NULL instead of = NULL (which wonâ€™t work).

ğŸ§ª 2. Using COALESCE()

Returns the first non-null value among arguments.


SELECT name, COALESCE(mobile, 'N/A') AS phone_number
FROM users;
ğŸ“¦ 3. Using NULLIF()

Returns NULL if the two arguments are equal, otherwise returns the first.


SELECT NULLIF(salary, 0) FROM employees;
ğŸ§® 4. Using CASE for Custom Handling

SELECT name,
  CASE
    WHEN bonus IS NULL THEN 'No Bonus'
    ELSE bonus
  END AS bonus_info
FROM employees;
ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips
  • NULL values donâ€™t behave like normal values in comparisons.
  • NULL = NULL is FALSE, but IS NULL works.
  • Use COALESCE or CASE to provide defaults or alternative logic.

âœ… Proper NULL handling ensures reliable query results and prevents logical bugs.

ğŸ”„ A subquery is a query nested inside another SQL query. A join is used to combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column.

ğŸ“ Subquery Example:

Get employees who earn more than the average salary:


SELECT name, salary 
FROM employees 
WHERE salary > (
    SELECT AVG(salary) FROM employees
);
ğŸ”— Join Example:

Get employee names and their department names:


SELECT e.name, d.department_name 
FROM employees e
JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.id;
ğŸ” Key Differences
  • Subqueries return single or multiple values and are often used in WHERE, HAVING, or FROM clauses.
  • Joins combine rows from multiple tables into a single result set.
  • Performance: Joins are generally faster than subqueries as they are optimized by the SQL engine.
  • Readability: Subqueries can make the query more modular or readable when filtering based on derived data.

ğŸ’¡ Use subqueries when you need intermediate calculations or filtering, and joins when combining data from related tables.

Idempotency ensures that processing the same message multiple times results in the same system state â€” avoiding duplicates and inconsistencies.

ğŸ“Œ Common Causes of Duplicate Messages
  • Kafka retries due to consumer failure
  • Network partitioning
  • Manual replay of messages
  • Consumer crash before acknowledging offset
âœ… Idempotency Strategies
1. Use of Unique Message Keys / IDs

Each event/message should carry a unique identifier (e.g., eventId, orderId, etc.) generated by the producer. Consumers can track and ignore already processed events.

2. Idempotency Key Store (Persistence)

Maintain a datastore (Redis, DB, etc.) to track processed message IDs:

  • Check if eventId exists in the store
  • If exists â†’ Skip processing
  • If not â†’ Process and mark it as processed
3. Deduplication in Database

Use database-level constraints like unique indexes to ensure records are not inserted more than once.


CREATE TABLE orders (
  order_id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
  ...
);
4. Transactional Outbox Pattern

Instead of publishing Kafka messages directly, store them in an "outbox" table within the same DB transaction. Use a separate service to poll and publish those events to Kafka. Ensures atomicity.

5. Exactly-Once Semantics (EOS)

Kafka offers **EOS** for producers and Kafka Streams. Configure enable.idempotence=true in producers and use **transactional producers** to ensure message is published and consumed exactly once.

6. Consumer Offset Management

Always commit the offset after the successful processing of the message. This ensures a message is retried only if it wasn't fully processed.

ğŸ” Design Recommendations
  • Design consumer services to be stateless and idempotent
  • Use idempotent service logic (e.g., PUT/UPSERT operations)
  • Use message headers to pass metadata like correlationId
  • Enable retry mechanisms with backoff and dead-letter queues (DLQ)

ğŸ” Conclusion: Idempotency in Kafka is essential for data consistency. Combine Kafka configurations, stateless processing, and durable idempotency tracking mechanisms for robust design.

ğŸ”¹ 1. transient

transient variables are not serialized. When the object is deserialized, they will be initialized to their default values (e.g., null, 0, etc.).

ğŸ”¹ 2. static

static variables belong to the class, not the instance. So, they are not serialized. Their value comes from the current JVM, not from the serialized object.

ğŸ”¹ 3. final

final variables are serialized if they are not transient or static. They behave like normal instance variables.

ğŸ“Œ Example

import java.io.*;

class Person implements Serializable {
    private String name;
    private transient int age; // won't be serialized
    private static String type = "Human"; // not serialized
    private final String gender; // serialized

    public Person(String name, int age, String gender) {
        this.name = name;
        this.age = age;
        this.gender = gender;
    }
}
ğŸ” Summary
  • transient âŒ Not serialized
  • static âŒ Not serialized
  • final âœ… Serialized (unless static/transient)

ğŸ”¸ Enum in JPA/Hibernate

JPA supports mapping enum types as fields in entities using the @Enumerated annotation. This helps Hibernate store the enum value in the database as either a String or an Ordinal (int).

ğŸ’¡ Usage
  • EnumType.STRING: Stores enum name like "ACTIVE"
  • EnumType.ORDINAL: Stores enum ordinal like 0, 1
âœ… Recommended: EnumType.STRING

Using STRING is safer for versioning and readability. Changing the order of enum constants won't affect data.

ğŸ“Œ Example

public enum Status {
    ACTIVE,
    INACTIVE,
    DELETED
}

@Entity
public class User {
    @Id
    private Long id;

    private String name;

    @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING) // or EnumType.ORDINAL
    private Status status;
}
ğŸ“Œ SQL Output with STRING

-- For EnumType.STRING
INSERT INTO user (id, name, status) VALUES (1, 'John', 'ACTIVE');
ğŸ“Œ SQL Output with ORDINAL

-- For EnumType.ORDINAL
-- ACTIVE = 0, INACTIVE = 1, DELETED = 2
INSERT INTO user (id, name, status) VALUES (1, 'John', 0);
âš ï¸ Caution

Avoid EnumType.ORDINAL unless absolutely necessary. Changing enum order can corrupt your data mapping.

ğŸ”¹ DELETE
  • Removes rows one at a time based on a condition (optional).
  • Can be rolled back (transaction-safe).
  • Triggers ON DELETE constraints or triggers if defined.
  • Slower compared to TRUNCATE for large tables.
  • You can use WHERE clause.
DELETE FROM employees WHERE department = 'HR';
ğŸ”¹ TRUNCATE
  • Deletes all rows in a table instantly.
  • Cannot use WHERE clause.
  • Cannot be rolled back in most databases.
  • Does not fire triggers in many DBs.
  • Faster and uses fewer system & transaction log resources.
  • Resets identity (auto increment) in some DBs.
TRUNCATE TABLE employees;
ğŸ“Œ Summary Table
Aspect DELETE TRUNCATE
WHERE Clause Yes No
Rollback Yes No (usually)
Triggers Yes No (usually)
Speed Slower Faster
Reset Auto-Increment No Yes (depends on DB)

ğŸ”¹ What is an Immutable Class?
  • An Immutable Class is a class whose state cannot be changed once it is created.
  • All fields are private and final.
  • No setters; fields are set via constructor only.
  • Any mutable objects must be deep copied during construction and when accessed via getters.
âœ… Benefits of Immutable Classes
  • Thread-safe by default.
  • Safe to use in cache or shared environments.
  • Better for debugging and testing.
ğŸ’¡ Example: Immutable Class with Mutable Field
public final class Employee {

    private final String name;
    private final Date joiningDate;

    public Employee(String name, Date joiningDate) {
        this.name = name;
        // Defensive copy
        this.joiningDate = new Date(joiningDate.getTime());
    }

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }

    public Date getJoiningDate() {
        // Return defensive copy
        return new Date(joiningDate.getTime());
    }
}
âš ï¸ What Happens Without Defensive Copy?
  • If you return the actual Date/List/Map reference, its internal state can be modified from outside.
  • This breaks immutability.
ğŸ’¡ Example with List (Mutable)
public final class Department {

    private final List<String> employees;

    public Department(List<String> employees) {
        // Defensive copy
        this.employees = new ArrayList<>(employees);
    }

    public List<String> getEmployees() {
        // Defensive copy
        return new ArrayList<>(employees);
    }
}
âœ… Good Practices
  • Use Collections.unmodifiableList() if deep copy is not needed.
  • Make class final to prevent inheritance.
  • Return defensive copies of mutable fields in getters.
ğŸ§  Quick Recap
  • Immutable â‰  no mutable fields. It means mutable fields cannot be changed from outside.
  • Use defensive copies in constructor and getter.

ğŸ“Œ SQL Functions
  • Returns a single value (scalar) or a table.
  • Can be used in SELECT statements.
  • Must return a value using RETURN.
  • Cannot modify database state (usually no INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE).
  • Useful for reusable business logic in queries.
Example:
CREATE FUNCTION GetDiscount(@amount DECIMAL)
RETURNS DECIMAL
AS
BEGIN
    RETURN @amount * 0.10;
END;
ğŸ“Œ Stored Procedures
  • Performs one or more operations (including DML).
  • Can have input, output, and return parameters.
  • Used for complex logic with conditions, loops, and transactions.
  • Can be called explicitly using EXEC or CALL.
Example:
CREATE PROCEDURE UpdateSalary
  @empId INT,
  @increment DECIMAL
AS
BEGIN
  UPDATE Employee SET Salary = Salary + @increment WHERE Id = @empId;
END;
ğŸ”„ Key Differences
Feature Function Stored Procedure
Return Type Must return a value May or may not return a value
Usage in Queries Can be used in SELECT Cannot be used in SELECT
DML Operations Usually not allowed Allowed
Error Handling Limited Robust (Try-Catch)
Transactions No Yes
ğŸ§  Conclusion
  • Use Functions for small calculations or logic in queries.
  • Use Stored Procedures for complex business operations and DB manipulations.

ğŸ“Œ String
  • Immutable â€“ any modification creates a new object.
  • Stored in string pool (memory efficient).
  • Thread-safe due to immutability.
  • Slower in repeated modifications due to object creation.
String s1 = "Hello";
String s2 = s1.concat(" World"); // New object created
System.out.println(s2);
Common String methods:
  • length()
  • charAt(int index)
  • substring(int start, int end)
  • equals(Object obj)
  • indexOf(String str)
  • toUpperCase(), toLowerCase()
ğŸ“Œ StringBuilder
  • Mutable â€“ changes apply to the same object.
  • Not synchronized â€“ Not thread-safe.
  • Faster in single-threaded environments.
StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder("Hello");
sb.append(" World");
System.out.println(sb.toString());
Common StringBuilder methods:
  • append(String str)
  • insert(int offset, String str)
  • delete(int start, int end)
  • reverse()
  • replace(int start, int end, String str)
ğŸ“Œ StringBuffer
  • Mutable and Synchronized â€“ thread-safe.
  • Slightly slower than StringBuilder due to synchronization.
  • Useful in multi-threaded scenarios.
StringBuffer sbf = new StringBuffer("Hello");
sbf.append(" World");
System.out.println(sbf);
Common StringBuffer methods:
  • append(String str)
  • insert(int offset, String str)
  • delete(int start, int end)
  • reverse()
  • capacity(), ensureCapacity(int min)
âœ… Conclusion
Feature String StringBuilder StringBuffer
Mutable No Yes Yes
Thread-Safe Yes (due to immutability) No Yes
Performance Slow (many objects) Fast (single-threaded) Slower (due to sync)

ğŸ“Œ What is API Gateway?

API Gateway is a single entry point for all clients. It handles request routing, composition, security, monitoring, and more. In a microservice architecture, it hides service internals from clients.

ğŸ“Œ How does it know where to route?
  • Uses predefined routing configuration.
  • Can use service discovery (e.g., Eureka, Consul).
  • Can use static route mapping (host/path based).
  • Load balancing using Ribbon, Spring Cloud LoadBalancer, etc.
âœ… Example with Spring Cloud Gateway
# application.yml
spring:
  cloud:
    gateway:
      routes:
        - id: user-service
          uri: lb://USER-SERVICE
          predicates:
            - Path=/user/**

        - id: order-service
          uri: lb://ORDER-SERVICE
          predicates:
            - Path=/order/**

ğŸ§  The `lb://` prefix means it will use LoadBalancer to look up the actual service instance from service registry (like Eureka).

ğŸ”— With Service Discovery (Eureka)
// Eureka Client in UserService
@EnableEurekaClient
@SpringBootApplication
public class UserServiceApplication {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(UserServiceApplication.class, args);
    }
}

Now, Spring Cloud Gateway registers itself and looks up services from Eureka registry. Based on route paths, it knows which service to forward the request to.

ğŸ§­ Alternate Routing Strategies
  • Path-based routing: `/api/user/**` â†’ User Service
  • Host-based routing: `user.api.com` â†’ User Service
  • Header-based routing: If header = "X-Env: dev" â†’ Dev service
  • Query param routing: `/search?type=order` â†’ Order service
ğŸ” Other Features of Gateway
  • Authentication & Authorization
  • Rate Limiting
  • Circuit Breaker
  • Logging, Metrics, Monitoring
ğŸ“¦ Supported Gateways
  • Spring Cloud Gateway
  • Netflix Zuul (legacy)
  • NGINX / HAProxy
  • Amazon API Gateway
  • Kong, Apigee, Tyk

Problem: Move all 0s to the front of the array, keeping the relative order of non-zero elements.

Example:

Input:  [1, 0, 2, 0, 3, 4, 0, 5]
Output: [0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Solution:

public static int[] moveZerosToFront(int[] arr) {
    List<Integer> nonZeroList = new ArrayList<>();
    int zeroCount = 0;

    for (int num : arr) {
        if (num == 0) {
            zeroCount++;
        } else {
            nonZeroList.add(num);
        }
    }

    int[] result = new int[arr.length];

    for (int i = 0; i < zeroCount; i++) {
        result[i] = 0;
    }

    for (int i = 0; i < nonZeroList.size(); i++) {
        result[zeroCount + i] = nonZeroList.get(i);
    }

    return result;
}

Explanation:

  • First, count the number of zeros.
  • Collect non-zero values preserving order.
  • Create a new result array.
  • Fill zeros at the beginning, then copy non-zeros.

1. Predicate<T> â€” returns a boolean.

Predicate<String> isLong = str -> str.length() > 5;
System.out.println(isLong.test("Hello")); // false

2. Consumer<T> â€” takes input, returns nothing.

Consumer<String> printer = s -> System.out.println(s);
printer.accept("Hello Consumer");

3. Function<T, R> â€” takes input and returns result.

Function<String, Integer> toLength = s -> s.length();
System.out.println(toLength.apply("Java")); // 4

4. Supplier<T> â€” supplies a result of type T.

Supplier<String> randomUUID = () -> UUID.randomUUID().toString();
System.out.println(randomUUID.get());

5. UnaryOperator<T> â€” special case of Function: input and output types are same.

UnaryOperator<Integer> square = x -> x * x;
System.out.println(square.apply(5)); // 25

6. BinaryOperator<T> â€” takes 2 inputs of same type, returns same type.

BinaryOperator<Integer> add = (a, b) -> a + b;
System.out.println(add.apply(2, 3)); // 5

7. BiFunction<T, U, R> â€” takes two arguments, returns a result.

BiFunction<Integer, Integer, String> sumToStr = (a, b) -> "Sum is " + (a + b);
System.out.println(sumToStr.apply(2, 3));

8. BiPredicate<T, U> â€” takes two inputs, returns boolean.

BiPredicate<String, Integer> checker = (s, len) -> s.length() == len;
System.out.println(checker.test("Hello", 5)); // true

9. BiConsumer<T, U> â€” accepts two arguments and returns nothing.

BiConsumer<String, Integer> printer = (name, age) ->
    System.out.println(name + " is " + age + " years old");
printer.accept("Alice", 30);

10. IntFunction<R>, DoubleFunction<R>, LongFunction<R>

IntFunction<String> toHex = Integer::toHexString;
System.out.println(toHex.apply(255)); // ff

11. IntSupplier, LongSupplier, DoubleSupplier

IntSupplier random = () -> new Random().nextInt(10);
System.out.println(random.getAsInt());

12. IntPredicate, LongPredicate, DoublePredicate

IntPredicate isEven = x -> x % 2 == 0;
System.out.println(isEven.test(4)); // true

13. IntUnaryOperator, LongUnaryOperator, DoubleUnaryOperator

IntUnaryOperator triple = x -> x * 3;
System.out.println(triple.applyAsInt(3)); // 9

14. BooleanSupplier

BooleanSupplier condition = () -> 5 > 3;
System.out.println(condition.getAsBoolean()); // true

Note:

  • All these are part of java.util.function package.
  • They support lambda expressions and method references.
  • You can chain them using andThen(), compose(), etc.

What is String.chars()?

  • It is a method in the String class (Java 8+).
  • Returns an IntStream of Unicode code points.
  • Each int value represents the character at a position in the string.

Signature:

public IntStream chars()

Why not return Stream<Character>?

  • For performance reasons, `chars()` returns IntStream instead of Stream<Character>.
  • You can easily map the int to char using typecasting.

Example:

String input = "Java";
input.chars().forEach(System.out::println);

Output:

74
97
118
97

Convert to Characters:

input.chars()
     .mapToObj(c -> (char) c)
     .forEach(System.out::println);

Use Case Examples:

  • Count specific characters:
    • long countA = input.chars().filter(ch -> ch == 'a').count();
  • Check if all characters are digits:
    • String str = "12345";
boolean allDigits = str.chars().allMatch(Character::isDigit);
  • Convert to uppercase:
    • String upper = input.chars()
                    .map(Character::toUpperCase)
                    .mapToObj(c -> String.valueOf((char)c))
                    .collect(Collectors.joining());

Note: String.codePoints() is another method which handles Unicode supplementary characters properly.

What is a Substring?

A substring is a contiguous sequence of characters within a string. For a string of length n, there are n*(n+1)/2 possible substrings.

Example:

String input = "abc";
All Substrings = [a, ab, abc, b, bc, c]

Java Code to Print All Substrings:

public class SubstringExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String input = "abc";

        for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
            for (int j = i + 1; j <= input.length(); j++) {
                System.out.println(input.substring(i, j));
            }
        }
    }
}

Output:

a
ab
abc
b
bc
c

Time Complexity: O(nÂ²) where n is the length of the string

Store Substrings in a List:

List<String> substrings = new ArrayList<>();
for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
    for (int j = i + 1; j <= input.length(); j++) {
        substrings.add(input.substring(i, j));
    }
}
System.out.println(substrings);

What is an Inner Class?

An inner class is a class defined inside another class. You can access its methods or variables by first creating an instance of the outer class, then the inner class.

Example: Non-static Inner Class

public class Outer {
    private String outerField = "Outer Field";

    class Inner {
        void display() {
            System.out.println("Accessing from Inner: " + outerField);
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Outer outer = new Outer();
        Outer.Inner inner = outer.new Inner();
        inner.display();
    }
}

Output:

Accessing from Inner: Outer Field

Static Inner Class Example:

public class Outer {
    static class StaticInner {
        void display() {
            System.out.println("Inside Static Inner");
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Outer.StaticInner inner = new Outer.StaticInner();
        inner.display();
    }
}

Output:

Inside Static Inner

Accessing Inner Class Fields:

class Outer {
    class Inner {
        int value = 42;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Outer outer = new Outer();
        Outer.Inner inner = outer.new Inner();
        System.out.println(inner.value);
    }
}

Reflection Access (Advanced):

Outer.Inner innerObj = new Outer().new Inner();
Field field = innerObj.getClass().getDeclaredField("value");
field.setAccessible(true);
System.out.println("Value: " + field.get(innerObj));

ğŸ”¹ What is ExecutorService?

ExecutorService is an advanced Java concurrency API to manage and control thread execution through a thread pool.

Why use it?

  • Efficient thread reuse
  • Better control of async tasks
  • Lifecycle management of threads

ğŸ”¹ Ways to Create ExecutorService:

ExecutorService service1 = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor();
ExecutorService service2 = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(5);
ExecutorService service3 = Executors.newCachedThreadPool();

ğŸ”¹ Commonly Used Methods:

  • execute(Runnable task): Executes a Runnable task without expecting a result.
  • <T> submit(Callable<T> task): Submits a task and returns a Future for result.
  • invokeAll(Collection<? extends Callable<T>>): Executes a batch of tasks and waits for all.
  • invokeAny(Collection<? extends Callable<T>>): Executes batch but returns result of the fastest one.
  • shutdown(): Initiates an orderly shutdown after existing tasks complete.
  • shutdownNow(): Attempts to stop all actively executing tasks.
  • isShutdown() / isTerminated(): To check service state.
  • awaitTermination(timeout, unit): Blocks until termination or timeout.

ğŸ”¹ Example: Using submit()

ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(3);

Callable<String> task = () -> {
    Thread.sleep(1000);
    return "Task completed";
};

Future<String> future = executor.submit(task);
System.out.println(future.get());

executor.shutdown();

ğŸ”¹ Example: Using invokeAll()

List<Callable<String>> tasks = List.of(
    () -> "Task1",
    () -> "Task2",
    () -> "Task3"
);

ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(2);
List<Future<String>> futures = executor.invokeAll(tasks);

for (Future<String> future : futures) {
    System.out.println(future.get());
}

executor.shutdown();

ğŸ”¹ Example: Using invokeAny()

String result = executor.invokeAny(List.of(
    () -> {
        Thread.sleep(300);
        return "Fastest";
    },
    () -> {
        Thread.sleep(1000);
        return "Slow";
    }
));
System.out.println("Result: " + result);

ğŸ›‘ Shutdown vs ShutdownNow:

  • shutdown(): Waits for running tasks to finish
  • shutdownNow(): Interrupts all running tasks immediately

ğŸ”¹ What is a Marker Interface?

A marker interface is an interface with no methods or fields. It serves as a tag or marker to inform the compiler or JVM that the class implementing this interface has a special behavior.

ğŸ”¹ Purpose of Marker Interface:

  • Used for **type identification**
  • Gives permission to JVM or frameworks to treat the class in a special way
  • Can be used by frameworks to apply **conditional logic**

ğŸ”¹ Common Marker Interfaces in Java:

  • java.io.Serializable â€“ Marks a class to be serializable
  • java.lang.Cloneable â€“ Marks a class to support cloning via Object.clone()
  • java.util.EventListener â€“ Marks class as event listener

ğŸ”¹ Example: Custom Marker Interface

// 1. Create a marker interface
public interface Auditable {}

// 2. Implement in a class
public class User implements Auditable {
    private String name;
    private String email;
}

// 3. Framework logic checking the marker
if (object instanceof Auditable) {
    System.out.println("Audit this entity");
}

ğŸ”¹ When to Use Marker Interface?

  • When annotation-based approach isn't suitable (e.g., for legacy systems)
  • To enable conditional processing by a framework or utility
  • To convey metadata without using annotations

âœ… Tip: In modern Java (Java 5+), annotations are often preferred over marker interfaces for flexibility and readability.

ğŸ”¹ What is Spring Cloud?

Spring Cloud provides tools for developers to quickly build distributed systems and microservices using Spring Boot. It handles common patterns such as configuration management, service discovery, circuit breakers, routing, etc.

ğŸ”¹ Key Components of Spring Cloud

  • 1. Spring Cloud Config â€“ Centralized configuration management
  • 2. Eureka â€“ Service Discovery
  • 3. Spring Cloud Gateway â€“ API Gateway
  • 4. Spring Cloud LoadBalancer â€“ Client-side load balancing
  • 5. Hystrix (Netflix OSS) â€“ Circuit Breaker (now replaced by Resilience4j)
  • 6. Feign â€“ Declarative REST client
  • 7. Zipkin / Sleuth â€“ Distributed Tracing
  • 8. Spring Cloud Bus â€“ Event/message broadcasting

ğŸ”¹ Spring Cloud Config Example

application.yml (Spring Cloud Config Server)

server:
  port: 8888

spring:
  cloud:
    config:
      server:
        git:
          uri: https://github.com/your-config-repo

Client - bootstrap.yml

spring:
  application:
    name: userservice
  cloud:
    config:
      uri: http://localhost:8888

ğŸ”¹ Eureka Service Discovery

@EnableEurekaServer // on discovery server
@SpringBootApplication
public class EurekaServerApp {}

@EnableEurekaClient // on microservice
@SpringBootApplication
public class UserServiceApp {}

ğŸ”¹ Feign Client Example

@FeignClient(name = "orderservice")
public interface OrderClient {
    @GetMapping("/orders/{userId}")
    List<Order> getOrders(@PathVariable Long userId);
}

ğŸ”¹ Gateway Route Example

spring:
  cloud:
    gateway:
      routes:
        - id: user-service
          uri: lb://USER-SERVICE
          predicates:
            - Path=/users/**

ğŸ”¹ Sleuth + Zipkin Example

spring:
  zipkin:
    base-url: http://localhost:9411
  sleuth:
    sampler:
      probability: 1.0

â¡ï¸ Add dependencies: spring-cloud-starter-zipkin and spring-cloud-starter-sleuth

ğŸ”¹ Resilience4j Circuit Breaker Example

@CircuitBreaker(name = "userService", fallbackMethod = "fallbackMethod")
public String getData() {
    return restTemplate.getForObject("http://SLOW-SERVICE/data", String.class);
}

public String fallbackMethod(Exception e) {
    return "Fallback response";
}

ğŸ”¹ Spring Cloud Bus

It can propagate config changes across microservices using Kafka or RabbitMQ.

spring:
  cloud:
    bus:
      enabled: true

Endpoint to refresh: POST /actuator/bus-refresh

âœ… Summary

  • Spring Cloud helps manage the complexity of distributed systems.
  • Provides out-of-the-box solutions for service discovery, config, gateway, circuit breakers, etc.
  • Most modules integrate easily with Spring Boot using starters.

ğŸ”¹ Spring Cloud + Microservices = Seamless Distributed Systems

Each Spring Cloud component is designed to solve a common challenge in a microservices-based architecture.

1ï¸âƒ£ Spring Cloud Config Server

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Centralized configuration for all microservices
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: Externalize configs in Git/Cloud Storage for all environments (dev, qa, prod)
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: No need to redeploy services on config change (with Spring Cloud Bus)

2ï¸âƒ£ Eureka Server (Service Discovery)

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Register and discover microservices dynamically
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: No hardcoded URLs; load-balanced calls using service names
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Improves scalability and dynamic routing

3ï¸âƒ£ Spring Cloud Gateway (API Gateway)

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Entry point for all external traffic to microservices
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: Route requests, apply filters, authentication, throttling
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Decouple external consumers from internal services

4ï¸âƒ£ OpenFeign (Declarative REST Client)

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Simplify REST client communication between services
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: Annotated interfaces calling other microservices
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Less boilerplate, integrates with Eureka & Ribbon

5ï¸âƒ£ Spring Cloud LoadBalancer

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Distribute client requests across multiple service instances
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: RestTemplate, WebClient, Feign clients
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Helps with fault tolerance and scaling

6ï¸âƒ£ Spring Cloud Sleuth + Zipkin

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Distributed tracing between microservices
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: Trace user request flow across multiple services
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Debugging and latency tracking

7ï¸âƒ£ Spring Cloud Bus

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Broadcast config or event changes across services using Kafka/RabbitMQ
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: Refresh config across services on git update
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Dynamic configuration without service restarts

8ï¸âƒ£ Spring Cloud Stream

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Messaging abstraction for asynchronous communication
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: Kafka/RabbitMQ publishers and consumers
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Event-driven architecture support

9ï¸âƒ£ Spring Cloud Circuit Breaker (Resilience4j)

  • ğŸ“Œ Purpose: Prevent failure propagation by cutting off unresponsive services
  • ğŸ“Œ Use Case: Wrap service calls in fallback logic
  • ğŸ“Œ Benefit: Increases system resilience

ğŸ§© Summary Table â€“ Spring Cloud to Microservice Mapping

Spring Cloud Component Microservice Concern Solved
Spring Cloud Config Central Configuration
Eureka Service Discovery
Gateway Routing, Security, Throttling
Feign Service-to-Service Calls
LoadBalancer Client-Side Load Balancing
Sleuth & Zipkin Tracing & Monitoring
Bus Broadcast Config Changes
Stream Event-Driven Messaging
Resilience4j Fault Tolerance 


// Java 8 Stream approach to find second highest number
import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.Optional;

public class SecondHighestFinder {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int[] numbers = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 50};

        Optional secondHighest = Arrays.stream(numbers)
            .boxed()
            .distinct() // remove duplicates
            .sorted((a, b) -> b - a) // descending order
            .skip(1) // skip the first (highest)
            .findFirst(); // get the second highest

        secondHighest.ifPresentOrElse(
            value -> System.out.println("Second highest number is: " + value),
            () -> System.out.println("No second highest number found")
        );
    }
}
âœ… Output:
Second highest number is: 40
ğŸ” Explanation:
  • .boxed() â†’ Convert int to Integer for stream operations
  • .distinct() â†’ Remove duplicate elements
  • .sorted((a, b) -> b - a) â†’ Sort in descending order
  • .skip(1) â†’ Skip the first (highest) element
  • .findFirst() â†’ Get the second element in sorted stream

ğŸ§  Difference Between Abstraction and Encapsulation:
Aspect Abstraction Encapsulation
Definition Hiding internal details and showing only essential features Wrapping data and methods into a single unit (class)
Goal To focus on what an object does To protect the internal state of the object
Implementation Achieved using abstract classes and interfaces Achieved using access modifiers like private, public, etc.
Use Case Designing systems/interfaces Hiding sensitive data from outside
ğŸ“¦ Encapsulation Example: 

public class Employee {
    private String name; // private field - encapsulated

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }

    public void setName(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }
}
ğŸ” Abstraction Example: 

abstract class Animal {
    abstract void makeSound(); // abstract method - only behavior defined
}

class Dog extends Animal {
    @Override
    void makeSound() {
        System.out.println("Bark");
    }
}

ğŸ”š Summary: Abstraction focuses on "what" the object does, while Encapsulation is about "how" to protect the objectâ€™s state.

ğŸ” Key Differences:
Feature Hashtable ConcurrentHashMap
Thread Safety Synchronized on the whole map (less efficient) Thread-safe using segment-level locking (more efficient)
Null Keys/Values Does not allow null key or null value Does not allow null key or null value
Performance Poor under high concurrency Better under high concurrency
Introduced In Legacy, since Java 1.0 Java 1.5 (java.util.concurrent)
ğŸ“¦ Hashtable Example: 

Hashtable<String, String> table = new Hashtable<>();
table.put("A", "Apple");
System.out.println(table.get("A"));
âš™ï¸ ConcurrentHashMap Example: 

ConcurrentHashMap<String, String> map = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();
map.put("B", "Banana");
System.out.println(map.get("B"));
ğŸ’¡ Tip: Always prefer ConcurrentHashMap for concurrent/multi-threaded applications in modern Java.

âœ… What is a Singleton Class?
A singleton class in Java allows only one instance of the class to be created in the entire application.

â˜• Basic Singleton Implementation: 

public class Singleton {
  private static Singleton instance;

  private Singleton() {}

  public static Singleton getInstance() {
    if (instance == null) {
      instance = new Singleton();
    }
    return instance;
  }
}
âš ï¸ Ways to Break Singleton:
  • Reflection: Can access private constructor
  • Serialization: Creates a new instance during deserialization
  • Cloning: Can create copy of the object
  • Multithreading: Multiple threads may create multiple instances simultaneously
ğŸ›¡ï¸ How to Prevent Breaking Singleton:
  • Reflection: Throw exception in constructor if instance already exists
  • Serialization: Implement readResolve()
  • Cloning: Override clone() and throw exception
  • Multithreading: Use synchronized block or double-checked locking
ğŸ”’ Double-Checked Locking (Thread Safe Singleton): 

public class Singleton {
  private static volatile Singleton instance;

  private Singleton() {}

  public static Singleton getInstance() {
    if (instance == null) {
      synchronized (Singleton.class) {
        if (instance == null) {
          instance = new Singleton();
        }
      }
    }
    return instance;
  }
}
  • Reduces performance overhead using double check
  • volatile ensures visibility and avoids instruction reordering
âœ”ï¸ Best Practices:
  • Use Enum Singleton for simplest and safest approach
ğŸ” Enum Singleton: 

public enum Singleton {
  INSTANCE;
}

This is reflection-safe, serialization-safe, and thread-safe by default.

âœ… Why Encode Data in REST APIs?
Data encoding ensures safe and secure transmission of information over the network, especially in:
  • URL Parameters
  • Request/Response Bodies
  • Headers
1ï¸âƒ£ URL Encoding:
  • Use for query parameters and form data
  • Special characters like spaces, &, =, etc. are encoded (e.g., space = %20)

// Example: "name=John Doe&age=25" becomes:
URLEncoder.encode("John Doe", StandardCharsets.UTF_8.toString());
2ï¸âƒ£ Base64 Encoding:
  • Used to encode binary data (e.g., files, images) or credentials (Basic Auth)
  • Data gets converted to a base64 string

String original = "user:password";
String encoded = Base64.getEncoder().encodeToString(original.getBytes());
3ï¸âƒ£ JSON Encoding:
  • JSON itself is a text-based encoding format for structured data
  • Spring Boot automatically serializes objects to JSON using Jackson

// Automatically converted to JSON
@PostMapping("/save")
public ResponseEntity<User> save(@RequestBody User user) {
  return ResponseEntity.ok(userService.save(user));
}
4ï¸âƒ£ Custom Encoding (Encryption):
  • For sensitive data, encrypt before sending
  • Use AES, RSA, or JWT for secure encoding

// AES Encryption Example
Cipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance("AES");
cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, secretKey);
byte[] encrypted = cipher.doFinal(data.getBytes());
5ï¸âƒ£ Header Encoding:
  • Custom or authorization headers often use encoded values
  • Example: Basic Auth header

Authorization: Basic dXNlcjpwYXNzd29yZA==
ğŸš€ Summary:
  • URLEncoder for URL params
  • Base64 for credentials/files
  • JSON for request/response body
  • Encryption for security-sensitive data

ğŸ“Œ Problem: Generate all permutations of a given string.

âœ… Java Code: 

public class Permutations {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String str = "ABC";
        printPermutations(str, "");
    }

    public static void printPermutations(String str, String result) {
        if (str.isEmpty()) {
            System.out.println(result);
            return;
        }

        for (int i = 0; i < str.length(); i++) {
            char ch = str.charAt(i);
            String remaining = str.substring(0, i) + str.substring(i + 1);
            printPermutations(remaining, result + ch);
        }
    }
}
ğŸ“Œ Output for "ABC": 

ABC
ACB
BAC
BCA
CAB
CBA
ğŸ’¡ Note:
  • This solution works for strings with distinct characters.
  • For strings with duplicate characters, use a Set to avoid duplicate permutations.

ğŸ“Œ Problem: Find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

âœ… Java Code: 

import java.util.HashSet;

public class LongestSubstring {

    public static int lengthOfLongestSubstring(String s) {
        int left = 0, right = 0, maxLen = 0;
        HashSet<Character> set = new HashSet<>();

        while (right < s.length()) {
            char ch = s.charAt(right);
            if (!set.contains(ch)) {
                set.add(ch);
                maxLen = Math.max(maxLen, right - left + 1);
                right++;
            } else {
                set.remove(s.charAt(left));
                left++;
            }
        }

        return maxLen;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String input = "abcabcbb";
        System.out.println("Longest length: " + lengthOfLongestSubstring(input));
    }
}
ğŸ“Œ Output: 

Longest length: 3
ğŸ’¡ Explanation:
  • Input: "abcabcbb"
  • The longest substring without repeating characters is "abc", so length = 3
  • This uses the sliding window technique with a HashSet for O(n) performance.

ğŸ“Œ JVM (Java Virtual Machine) Architecture

The JVM is the engine that runs Java bytecode. Its architecture includes the following main components:

ğŸ§© Components of JVM:
  • 1. Class Loader Subsystem: Loads, links, and initializes classes.
  • 2. Method Area: Stores class metadata, static variables, and constants.
  • 3. Heap: Stores objects and instance variables. Shared across threads.
  • 4. Java Stack: Stores frames (method calls) per thread. Each frame has:
    • Local Variables
    • Operand Stack
    • Return Address
  • 5. Program Counter (PC) Register: Holds the address of the currently executing instruction per thread.
  • 6. Native Method Stack: For native (non-Java) method calls like C/C++.
  • 7. Execution Engine: Executes bytecode.
    • Interpreter â€“ Reads bytecode line by line
    • JIT Compiler â€“ Improves performance by compiling repeated bytecode into native code
  • 8. Native Interface: Interface to call native libraries (JNI).
  • 9. Garbage Collector: Automatically deallocates memory used by unreferenced objects.
ğŸ§  JVM Internal Flow:
  1. Java source code (.java) â†’ compiled to bytecode (.class)
  2. Bytecode is loaded by the Class Loader
  3. Stored in Method Area & Heap
  4. Execution Engine runs bytecode using stack, PC, and native stack
  5. Garbage Collector cleans unused objects
ğŸ“ Summary:
JVM provides memory management, execution, and runtime environment for Java programs. It abstracts away the platform specifics.

ğŸ–¼ï¸ Want Diagram? I can generate a JVM architecture diagram if you'd like. Just say the word! ğŸ˜Š

ğŸ§± LinkedList Node Class:
```java class Node { int data; Node next; Node(int data) { this.data = data; this.next = null; } } ```
ğŸ” Custom LinkedList:
```java class MyLinkedList { Node head; public void add(int data) { Node newNode = new Node(data); if (head == null) { head = newNode; } else { Node current = head; while (current.next != null) { current = current.next; } current.next = newNode; } } public void printList() { Node current = head; while (current != null) { System.out.print(current.data + " "); current = current.next; } System.out.println(); } } ```
ğŸ“š Custom Stack (LIFO):
```java class MyStack { Node top; public void push(int data) { Node newNode = new Node(data); newNode.next = top; top = newNode; } public int pop() { if (top == null) throw new RuntimeException("Stack is empty!"); int val = top.data; top = top.next; return val; } public boolean isEmpty() { return top == null; } } ```
ğŸš¦ Custom Queue (FIFO):
```java class MyQueue { Node front, rear; public void enqueue(int data) { Node newNode = new Node(data); if (rear == null) { front = rear = newNode; } else { rear.next = newNode; rear = newNode; } } public int dequeue() { if (front == null) throw new RuntimeException("Queue is empty!"); int val = front.data; front = front.next; if (front == null) rear = null; return val; } public boolean isEmpty() { return front == null; } } ```
ğŸ§ª Usage Example:
```java public class TestCustomDS { public static void main(String[] args) { // LinkedList MyLinkedList list = new MyLinkedList(); list.add(1); list.add(2); list.add(3); list.printList(); // 1 2 3 // Stack MyStack stack = new MyStack(); stack.push(10); stack.push(20); System.out.println(stack.pop()); // 20 // Queue MyQueue queue = new MyQueue(); queue.enqueue(100); queue.enqueue(200); System.out.println(queue.dequeue()); // 100 } } ``` ğŸ“Œ Summary:
  • ğŸ“š Stack uses LIFO â€” push at top, pop from top
  • ğŸš¦ Queue uses FIFO â€” enqueue at rear, dequeue from front
  • ğŸ”— LinkedList stores data dynamically using node pointers

ğŸ’¡ Reason:
Java's Garbage Collector (GC) automatically reclaims memory of unreferenced objects. However, **OutOfMemoryError** can still occur due to reasons like:

ğŸš¨ Common Causes:
  • 1. Memory Leak: Unused objects are still referenced, preventing GC from reclaiming them.
  • 2. Large Data Structures: Storing large collections (like lists, maps) in memory without limit.
  • 3. Infinite Object Creation: In loops or recursive calls without base case.
  • 4. Incorrect JVM Heap Settings: Heap size is too small to hold all objects.
  • 5. Improper Cleanup: Holding on to references like static fields, thread-locals, caches etc.
  • 6. Permanent Generation / Metaspace Overflow: Too many loaded classes or large method metadata (especially in older Java versions).

ğŸ“ Example: ```java List memoryHog = new ArrayList<>(); while (true) { memoryHog.add(new byte[1024 * 1024]); // 1 MB } ```
ğŸ’¥ Output: ``` Exception in thread "main" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space ```
ğŸ› ï¸ Solutions:
  • âœ… Fix memory leaks by reviewing references.
  • âœ… Use proper data structures (bounded queues, weak references).
  • âœ… Increase heap size using JVM options: -Xmx1024m, -Xms512m
  • âœ… Use memory profiling tools like VisualVM, JProfiler.
ğŸ” Summary:
  • Garbage Collection reclaims only unreferenced memory.
  • If objects are still referenced or memory grows uncontrollably â€” GC cannot help.
  • Hence, memory leaks or huge object graphs lead to OutOfMemoryError.

Java 8 introduced powerful enhancements in the Collections framework:

  • 1. forEach()
    - Allows easy iteration over elements using lambda.
    list.forEach(System.out::println);

  • 2. removeIf()
    - Removes elements that satisfy a predicate.
    list.removeIf(s -> s.length() > 5);

  • 3. replaceAll()
    - Replaces each element using a unary operator.
    list.replaceAll(String::toUpperCase);

  • 4. sort(Comparator)
    - Allows lambda-based sorting directly on List.
    list.sort((a, b) -> a.compareTo(b));

  • 5. Map's new methods:
    • forEach(BiConsumer)
    • getOrDefault()
    • putIfAbsent()
    • merge()
    • compute(), computeIfAbsent(), computeIfPresent()
    • replaceAll()

  • 6. Stream API
    - Not part of Collections per se but enables powerful operations on collections.
    list.stream().filter(s -> s.startsWith("A")).collect(Collectors.toList());

  • 7. Default and Static methods in interfaces:
    - Java 8 added ability to add default implementation inside interfaces like Collection, List, Map, etc.

  • 8. Spliterator
    - For parallel traversal and processing.
    Spliterator spliterator = list.spliterator();
ğŸ“ Summary:
  • Java 8 made collections more expressive and concise using functional programming.
  • Stream API and enhanced collection methods reduced boilerplate significantly.
  • Maps became much more powerful with conditional operations.

ğŸ’¡ Java 8 focuses more on functional-style exception handling:

  • 1. Exception Handling in Lambda Expressions
    - Lambda expressions can throw exceptions, but they must be unchecked or explicitly handled.
    list.forEach(item -> { try { if(item == null) throw new RuntimeException("Null found"); } catch(Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } });

  • 2. Functional Interfaces donâ€™t support checked exceptions directly
    - You need to wrap them manually or use a custom wrapper.
    interface CheckedFunction { R apply(T t) throws Exception; }

  • 3. Optional - Null-Safe Handling
    - Use Optional to avoid NullPointerException.
    Optional value = Optional.ofNullable(getValue());
    value.orElse("default");

  • 4. Stream API Exception Wrapping
    - When using streams, exceptions must be handled inside lambdas.
    list.stream().map(item -> {
      try {
        return riskyCall(item);
      } catch (Exception e) {
        return "default";
      }
    }).collect(Collectors.toList());

  • 5. Custom Wrappers for Checked Exceptions in Functional Context
    - Example for rethrowing a checked exception:
    static <T, R> Function<T, R> wrap(CheckedFunction<T, R> func) { return i -> { try { return func.apply(i); } catch (Exception e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } }; }
âœ… Summary:
  • Java 8 encourages safe programming using Optional instead of null checks.
  • Lambda expressions require creative handling of checked exceptions.
  • Custom wrappers help manage checked exceptions in streams and functional interfaces.

ğŸ’¡ Use an abstract class when:
  • 1. You want to share common code:
    Abstract class allows you to define methods with a default implementation.
    abstract class Animal {
    void breathe() { System.out.println("Breathing..."); }
    abstract void sound();
    }

  • 2. You need to declare non-static/non-final fields:
    Abstract classes can have instance variables to maintain state.

  • 3. You want to control inheritance:
    Abstract classes support constructors and can enforce inheritance structure better.

  • 4. You require version compatibility:
    Adding new methods in an abstract class with default behavior is safer than changing interfaces (unless using Java 8+ default methods).

  • 5. You want to provide template methods:
    Abstract classes support the Template Method Pattern where a base class defines a skeleton of an operation.
ğŸš« Avoid Abstract Class when:
  • You only need method signatures (use interface instead).
  • You want multiple inheritance (Java allows multiple interfaces, but not multiple classes).
âœ… Summary:
  • Use Abstract Class: When you have common behavior and state to share.
  • Use Interface: When you only define capabilities/behavior contracts.

ğŸ’¥ What is Deadlock?
Deadlock is a situation where two or more threads are blocked forever, each waiting on the other to release a lock.

ğŸ§µ Example of Deadlock: 

class A {
  synchronized void methodA(B b) {
    System.out.println("Thread 1: Holding A and waiting for B");
    b.last();
  }

  synchronized void last() {
    System.out.println("Inside A.last()");
  }
}

class B {
  synchronized void methodB(A a) {
    System.out.println("Thread 2: Holding B and waiting for A");
    a.last();
  }

  synchronized void last() {
    System.out.println("Inside B.last()");
  }
}
âš ï¸ Problem: If Thread 1 holds lock on A and waits for B, and Thread 2 holds lock on B and waits for A â†’ deadlock!

âœ… How to Avoid Deadlock:
  • 1. Lock ordering: Always acquire locks in a consistent global order across all threads.
  • 2. Use tryLock(): Use ReentrantLock.tryLock() to avoid waiting indefinitely.
  • 3. Timeout: Set a timeout to prevent infinite waiting on a lock.
  • 4. Avoid nested locks: Try to acquire only one lock at a time whenever possible.
  • 5. Detect deadlocks: Use Java tools like jconsole or VisualVM to detect deadlock threads.
ğŸ” Example using tryLock to prevent deadlock: 

ReentrantLock lock1 = new ReentrantLock();
ReentrantLock lock2 = new ReentrantLock();

if (lock1.tryLock(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS)) {
  if (lock2.tryLock(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS)) {
    try {
      // do work
    } finally {
      lock2.unlock();
      lock1.unlock();
    }
  }
}

ğŸ“Œ Definition:
A hashing collision occurs when two different objects produce the same hash code, and thus they are mapped to the same bucket in a hash-based data structure like HashMap or HashSet.

ğŸ“¦ Example: 

class CustomKey {
  int id;

  CustomKey(int id) {
    this.id = id;
  }

  @Override
  public int hashCode() {
    return 1; // Same hash for every object
  }

  @Override
  public boolean equals(Object obj) {
    return this.id == ((CustomKey)obj).id;
  }
}
If you insert multiple CustomKey objects into a HashMap, theyâ€™ll all go into the same bucket â†’ Collision.

ğŸ§  Why It's a Problem:
  • Reduces performance to O(n) from O(1) for lookup/insert.
  • Increased risk of DOS attacks via hash flooding (intentionally causing collisions).
ğŸ›¡ï¸ How Java Handles It (HashMap):
  • Initially uses a linked list to handle collisions in the same bucket.
  • If the number of entries in a bucket exceeds a threshold (usually 8), it converts to a balanced tree (red-black tree) to improve performance.
âœ… Best Practices to Avoid Collisions:
  • Override both hashCode() and equals() properly.
  • Use prime numbers and good distribution logic in hashCode() implementation.
  • Keep hash-based collections like HashMap, HashSet properly sized.

ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ« What is a SQL JOIN?
A SQL JOIN is used to combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column between them.

ğŸ§± Sample Tables: 

Table: Employees
+----+--------+------------+
| ID | Name   | Dept_ID    |
+----+--------+------------+
| 1  | Alice  | 101        |
| 2  | Bob    | 102        |
| 3  | Carol  | 103        |
| 4  | David  | null       |
+----+--------+------------+

Table: Departments
+---------+--------------+
| Dept_ID | Dept_Name    |
+---------+--------------+
| 101     | HR           |
| 102     | IT           |
| 104     | Finance      |
+---------+--------------+
1ï¸âƒ£ INNER JOIN
Returns records that have matching values in both tables. 

SELECT e.Name, d.Dept_Name
FROM Employees e
INNER JOIN Departments d
ON e.Dept_ID = d.Dept_ID;
âœ… Output: Only employees with a matching department.
2ï¸âƒ£ LEFT JOIN (or LEFT OUTER JOIN)
Returns all records from the left table and matched records from the right table. 

SELECT e.Name, d.Dept_Name
FROM Employees e
LEFT JOIN Departments d
ON e.Dept_ID = d.Dept_ID;
âœ… Output: All employees. If no match, Dept_Name is NULL.
3ï¸âƒ£ RIGHT JOIN (or RIGHT OUTER JOIN)
Returns all records from the right table and the matched records from the left table. 

SELECT e.Name, d.Dept_Name
FROM Employees e
RIGHT JOIN Departments d
ON e.Dept_ID = d.Dept_ID;
âœ… Output: All departments. If no match, Name is NULL.
4ï¸âƒ£ FULL JOIN (or FULL OUTER JOIN)
Returns all records when there is a match in either table. 

SELECT e.Name, d.Dept_Name
FROM Employees e
FULL OUTER JOIN Departments d
ON e.Dept_ID = d.Dept_ID;
âœ… Output: All employees and departments with or without a match.
5ï¸âƒ£ CROSS JOIN
Returns the Cartesian product of both tables (every row from one joined with every row of the other). 

SELECT e.Name, d.Dept_Name
FROM Employees e
CROSS JOIN Departments d;
âœ… Output: All combinations of employees and departments.
6ï¸âƒ£ SELF JOIN
A self join is a regular join but the table is joined with itself. 

SELECT A.Name AS Employee1, B.Name AS Employee2
FROM Employees A, Employees B
WHERE A.Dept_ID = B.Dept_ID AND A.ID <> B.ID;
âœ… Output: Employees in the same department.

ğŸ’¡ What is Indexing?
An Index in SQL is a performance optimization feature that allows the database to find and access data quickly, just like an index in a book.

âš¡ Why Use Indexing?
  • ğŸ” Faster SELECT queries
  • ğŸ“¦ Efficient searching & filtering
  • ğŸ§­ Helps on large datasets and WHERE conditions
  • ğŸ“Š Improves performance of JOINs, ORDER BY, GROUP BY
ğŸ§ª Example:
Suppose you have a large Employees table with 10 million rows. 

CREATE TABLE Employees (
  ID INT PRIMARY KEY,
  Name VARCHAR(100),
  Email VARCHAR(100),
  Salary DECIMAL(10,2)
);
Searching by email without index: 

SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE Email = 'user@example.com';
-- â³ Slow full table scan
Now, add an index: 

CREATE INDEX idx_email ON Employees(Email);
After indexing: 

SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE Email = 'user@example.com';
-- âš¡ Faster! Uses binary search on index
ğŸ›‘ When NOT to Use Indexing?
  • Too many indexes = slower INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE
  • On small tables â€“ overhead isn't worth it
  • On columns with low selectivity (e.g. gender, status)
ğŸ“š Types of Indexes:
  • PRIMARY Index â€“ Automatically created on primary key
  • UNIQUE Index â€“ Ensures all values are unique
  • COMPOSITE Index â€“ On multiple columns
  • FULLTEXT Index â€“ For text search (MySQL)
  • SPATIAL Index â€“ For geo-data
ğŸ§  Summary:
  • âœ… Index improves read/query performance
  • âš ï¸ Can slow down writes (insert/update/delete)
  • ğŸ¯ Use on frequently searched or joined columns

ğŸ§  Requirement:
Find the 4th highest salary from the Employees table.

âœ… Query using DISTINCT and LIMIT / OFFSET (MySQL): 

SELECT DISTINCT Salary
FROM Employees
ORDER BY Salary DESC
LIMIT 1 OFFSET 3;
-- This returns the 4th highest salary (0-indexed)
âœ… Query using Subquery (Works in most DBs like Oracle, PostgreSQL): 

SELECT MIN(Salary) AS FourthHighestSalary
FROM (
  SELECT DISTINCT Salary
  FROM Employees
  ORDER BY Salary DESC
  LIMIT 4
) AS TopFour;
âœ… Query using ROW_NUMBER() (PostgreSQL, SQL Server, etc): 

SELECT Salary
FROM (
  SELECT Salary, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY Salary DESC) AS rn
  FROM Employees
) AS RankedSalaries
WHERE rn = 4;
ğŸ“Œ Note: If salaries are not unique and you want the 4th **distinct** salary, use DENSE_RANK() instead of ROW_NUMBER().

No, Java does not allow safe forceful termination of threads.

  • ğŸ›‘ Thread.stop() is deprecated due to unsafe behavior.
  • âœ… Use Thread.interrupt() and cooperative checks inside your thread logic.
  • âœ… Use Future.cancel(true) for interruptible tasks via ExecutorService.
  • ğŸ§  Design tasks to check for interruption and exit cleanly.

while (!Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted()) {
   // safe logic
}

ğŸ“Œ What is Inheritance?
Inheritance is a mechanism in Java where one class inherits the properties (fields and methods) of another class.

âœ… Benefits:
  • Code reusability
  • Method overriding (polymorphism)
  • Better maintainability
ğŸ”° Syntax: 
class Parent { }
class Child extends Parent { }
ğŸ§© Types of Inheritance in Java:
  • Single Inheritance âœ…
  • Multilevel Inheritance âœ…
  • Hierarchical Inheritance âœ…
  • Multiple Inheritance âŒ (Not supported with classes, only with interfaces)
ğŸ¤” What if Parent throws Exception?
  • If the parent method throws a checked exception, the child must either declare it or handle it.
  • If the parent method throws an unchecked exception (like NullPointerException), the child doesn't need to declare or handle it explicitly.
âœ… Example: 
class Parent {
    void show() throws Exception {
        System.out.println("Parent show");
        throw new Exception("Checked Exception");
    }
}

class Child extends Parent {
    @Override
    void show() throws Exception { // Must declare or handle
        System.out.println("Child show");
        super.show();
    }
}
âœ… Example with Unchecked Exception: 
class Parent {
    void display() {
        throw new NullPointerException("NPE");
    }
}

class Child extends Parent {
    @Override
    void display() {
        System.out.println("Child display");
        super.display(); // No need to handle
    }
}
âš ï¸ Summary:
  • Checked exceptions must be declared or handled in child if overridden.
  • Unchecked exceptions donâ€™t need to be declared or handled in child.

ğŸš« No, you cannot start a thread twice in Java.

Once a thread has been started and completed execution, calling start() again on the same thread instance will throw a java.lang.IllegalThreadStateException.

âœ… Example: 
public class MyThread extends Thread {
    public void run() {
        System.out.println("Running thread...");
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        MyThread t1 = new MyThread();
        t1.start(); // âœ… First time, will work

        t1.start(); // âŒ Second time, throws exception
    }
}
ğŸ›‘ Output: 
Running thread...
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalThreadStateException
      at java.lang.Thread.start(Thread.java:708)
âš ï¸ Why?
  • Each thread object can be started only once.
  • If you need to run it again, create a new Thread instance.
âœ… Correct Way: 
MyThread t1 = new MyThread();
t1.start();

MyThread t2 = new MyThread(); // New instance
t2.start();

ğŸ”„ What is Synchronization?
Synchronization is a way to control access to shared resources by multiple threads to avoid data inconsistency or race conditions.
ğŸ§© 1. Synchronized Instance Method
This locks the current object (`this`) so that only one thread can access any synchronized method at a time on the same object. 
public class Counter {
    private int count = 0;

    public synchronized void increment() {
        count++;
    }
}
âœ… All synchronized methods share the same lock on the current object.
ğŸ”’ 2. Synchronized Block
Use this when you only want a specific portion of the code to be synchronized rather than the whole method. 
public void increment() {
    synchronized(this) {
        count++;
    }
}
âœ… More efficient than synchronizing the whole method.
ğŸ§Š 3. Static Synchronized Method
This locks the class object (`ClassName.class`) instead of the current object. 
public class Counter {
    private static int count = 0;

    public static synchronized void increment() {
        count++;
    }
}
âœ… Useful when working with static data.
ğŸ§± 4. Synchronization on Custom Object
You can lock on any object. 
private final Object lock = new Object();

public void increment() {
    synchronized(lock) {
        count++;
    }
}
âœ… Helps in fine-grained locking.
âš ï¸ Caveats & Notes:
  • Synchronization adds overhead.
  • Don't synchronize on objects that can be externally accessed (like `String`, as they are interned).
  • Can cause deadlocks if not designed carefully.
ğŸ§ª Example Use Case: 
public class MyThread extends Thread {
    Counter counter;

    MyThread(Counter c) {
        this.counter = c;
    }

    public void run() {
        for(int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
            counter.increment();
        }
    }
}

public class Counter {
    private int count = 0;

    public synchronized void increment() {
        count++;
    }

    public int getCount() {
        return count;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        Counter c = new Counter();
        MyThread t1 = new MyThread(c);
        MyThread t2 = new MyThread(c);
        t1.start();
        t2.start();
        t1.join();
        t2.join();
        System.out.println("Count: " + c.getCount());
    }
}
ğŸ§¾ Without synchronization, the result may be less than 2000 due to race condition.

Java threads can exist in one of the following states defined by the `Thread.State` enum:
1ï¸âƒ£ NEW
When a thread object is created but not yet started. 
Thread t = new Thread();  // State is NEW
2ï¸âƒ£ RUNNABLE
The thread is ready to run and waiting for CPU time. It may be running or waiting in the thread scheduler. 
t.start();  // Now in RUNNABLE state
3ï¸âƒ£ BLOCKED
The thread is waiting to acquire a lock (monitor) that another thread holds. 
synchronized(lock) {
    // Thread 1 has acquired lock
    // Thread 2 trying to enter same block is BLOCKED
}
4ï¸âƒ£ WAITING
The thread is waiting indefinitely for another thread to perform a particular action (like notify). 
synchronized(lock) {
    lock.wait();  // Thread enters WAITING state
}
5ï¸âƒ£ TIMED_WAITING
Waiting for a specific amount of time (sleep, join with timeout, wait with timeout). 
Thread.sleep(1000);  // TIMED_WAITING
thread.join(500);    // TIMED_WAITING
lock.wait(2000);     // TIMED_WAITING
6ï¸âƒ£ TERMINATED
The thread has completed execution or has been aborted due to an exception. 
public void run() {
    System.out.println("Done");
}
// After run completes â†’ TERMINATED
ğŸ§ª Check Thread State 
Thread t = new Thread(() -> {});
System.out.println(t.getState()); // NEW
t.start();
System.out.println(t.getState()); // RUNNABLE or others
ğŸ“Œ Summary Table:
State Description
NEW Thread created, not yet started
RUNNABLE Ready to run or running
BLOCKED Waiting for monitor lock
WAITING Waiting indefinitely
TIMED_WAITING Waiting with timeout
TERMINATED Finished execution

âœ… Yes, we can create a constructor as private in Java.
ğŸ“Œ What Happens If Constructor is Private?
  • It **restricts object creation** from outside the class.
  • Used in **Singleton**, **Factory Pattern**, and **Utility classes** (like `java.lang.Math` or `Collections`).
  • You canâ€™t do: MyClass obj = new MyClass(); from outside the class.
âœ… Example: Singleton Pattern Using Private Constructor 
public class MySingleton {
  private static MySingleton instance;

  private MySingleton() {
    // private constructor
  }

  public static MySingleton getInstance() {
    if (instance == null) {
      instance = new MySingleton();
    }
    return instance;
  }
}
ğŸ”’ Attempting to create object outside will fail: 
MySingleton obj = new MySingleton();  // âŒ Compile-time error
ğŸ›  Use Cases of Private Constructors:
  • Singleton Design Pattern
  • Utility/helper classes
  • Static factory methods
  • Prevent instantiation of abstract base classes or constants-only classes

ğŸ“Œ In Java, the catch blocks are executed from top to bottom, and the first block that matches the thrown exception type will handle it.
âœ… Correct Order:
  • Catch blocks should go from most specific to most general.
  • If a more general exception (like Exception) comes before a specific one (like ArithmeticException), it will cause a compile-time error.
ğŸ” Example: 
try {
    int x = 10 / 0;
} catch (ArithmeticException e) {
    System.out.println("Caught ArithmeticException");
} catch (Exception e) {
    System.out.println("Caught general Exception");
}
âœ… Output: Caught ArithmeticException
âŒ Wrong Order Example (Causes Compile Error): 
try {
    int x = 10 / 0;
} catch (Exception e) {
    System.out.println("General Exception");
} catch (ArithmeticException e) { // âŒ Unreachable
    System.out.println("Specific ArithmeticException");
}
ğŸ’¡ Why? The general Exception block will catch everything, so specific blocks after it are unreachable.
âœ… Rule to Remember: Catch blocks must go from:
  • IOException â†’ RuntimeException â†’ Exception â†’ Throwable

Java provides a hierarchy of exception classes to handle various kinds of errors.

ğŸ”½ Here's a simple diagram representation: 

                      â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
                      â”‚ Throwable  â”‚
                      â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
               â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
         â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â–¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”            â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â–¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
         â”‚  Error    â”‚            â”‚ Exception   â”‚
         â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜            â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                                   â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â–¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
                            â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤ RuntimeException â”‚
                            â”‚      â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                            â”‚     â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â–¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
                            â”‚     â”‚ NullPointer... â”‚
                            â”‚     â”‚ ArrayIndex...  â”‚
                            â”‚     â”‚ IllegalArg...  â”‚
                            â”‚     â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                            â”‚
                            â””â”€â”€ Checked Exceptions:
                                  â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
                                  â”‚ IOException  â”‚
                                  â”‚ SQLException â”‚
                                  â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
ğŸ” Top Level: Throwable
  • The superclass of all errors and exceptions.
â¡ï¸ Error: Represents serious problems that a reasonable application should not try to catch.
  • OutOfMemoryError, StackOverflowError, etc.
â¡ï¸ Exception: Conditions that a program might want to catch.
  • Checked: Must be declared or handled (e.g., IOException, SQLException).
  • Unchecked (Runtime): Not required to handle (e.g., NullPointerException, ArithmeticException).
âœ… Summary:
  • Error â€“ for JVM errors (e.g., memory issues)
  • Checked Exception â€“ must handle explicitly
  • Unchecked Exception â€“ runtime issues like logic errors

ğŸ”¹ What are Generics?
Generics enable types (classes and interfaces) to be parameters when defining classes, interfaces and methods. They allow for type-safe data structures.
âœ… Why Generics?
  • Compile-time type checking
  • Avoids type casting
  • Code reusability
ğŸ”§ Example 1: Generic Class 

public class Box<T> {
    private T item;

    public void set(T item) {
        this.item = item;
    }

    public T get() {
        return item;
    }
}

Box<String> stringBox = new Box<>();
stringBox.set("Hello");
System.out.println(stringBox.get());  // Output: Hello
ğŸ” Example 2: Generic Method 

public class GenericMethodExample {
    public static <T> void printArray(T[] array) {
        for (T item : array) {
            System.out.println(item);
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Integer[] intArray = {1, 2, 3};
        String[] strArray = {"A", "B", "C"};
        printArray(intArray);
        printArray(strArray);
    }
}
ğŸ§  Bounded Types: 

public class NumberBox<T extends Number> {
    private T num;

    public void set(T num) {
        this.num = num;
    }

    public T get() {
        return num;
    }
}
ğŸ”¹ This restricts T to subclasses of `Number`.
â™»ï¸ Wildcards:
  • ? â€“ unknown type
  • ? extends T â€“ upper bound
  • ? super T â€“ lower bound

// List of unknown type
public void printList(List<?> list) {
    for (Object obj : list) {
        System.out.println(obj);
    }
}
ğŸ“Œ Summary:
  • Use Generics to enforce compile-time safety
  • Reusability and abstraction
  • Wildcard types offer flexibility

ğŸ”¹ Definition:
Covariant return types allow an overridden method to return a subtype of the return type declared in the original method of the superclass.
âœ… When is it used?
  • Used during method overriding
  • Makes code more readable and flexible
  • Introduced in Java 5
ğŸ”§ Example: 

class Animal {
    String sound() {
        return "Some sound";
    }
}

class Dog extends Animal {
    @Override
    String sound() {
        return "Bark";
    }
}

// Covariant return type example
class AnimalFactory {
    Animal getAnimal() {
        return new Animal();
    }
}

class DogFactory extends AnimalFactory {
    @Override
    Dog getAnimal() {
        return new Dog(); // Valid: Dog is a subtype of Animal
    }
}
âš ï¸ Without Covariant Return (Before Java 5)
  • Return types must match exactly during overriding
  • No subtype return allowed
ğŸ“Œ Summary:
  • Supports polymorphism in a more type-safe way
  • Allows overridden methods to be more specific
  • Improves API design by reducing the need for casting

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Step 1: Create a class 

class Person {
    String firstName;
    String lastName;

    public Person(String firstName, String lastName) {
        this.firstName = firstName;
        this.lastName = lastName;
    }

    public String getFirstName() { return firstName; }
    public String getLastName() { return lastName; }

    @Override
    public String toString() {
        return firstName + " " + lastName;
    }
}
ğŸ” Step 2: Sort using Comparator (Java 8) 

List<Person> people = Arrays.asList(
    new Person("John", "Doe"),
    new Person("Alice", "Smith"),
    new Person("John", "Adams"),
    new Person("Alice", "Brown")
);

people.sort(Comparator
    .comparing(Person::getFirstName)
    .thenComparing(Person::getLastName)
);

people.forEach(System.out::println);
ğŸ“¦ Output: 

Alice Brown
Alice Smith
John Adams
John Doe
âœ… Summary:
  • Use Comparator.comparing() for clean, functional-style sorting.
  • thenComparing() allows secondary sorting criteria.
  • This approach is null-safe if used with Comparator.nullsFirst() or nullsLast().

ğŸ” Definition:

try-with-resources is a feature introduced in Java 7 that automatically closes resources like InputStream, BufferedReader, FileWriter, etc., after the try block, even if an exception occurs.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Syntax Example: 

import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.FileReader;
import java.io.IOException;

public class TryWithResourcesExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("file.txt"))) {
            String line = reader.readLine();
            System.out.println(line);
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}
ğŸ“˜ Notes:
  • Any object used in try-with-resources must implement AutoCloseable (or Closeable).
  • Closes resources automatically at the end of try block.
  • Reduces boilerplate code (no need for finally block).
âœ… Advantages:
  • Clean and concise code.
  • Prevents resource leaks.
  • Supports multiple resources in one try block.
ğŸ“¦ Java 9 Enhancement:

From Java 9 onward, you can use variables declared outside of try in the try-with-resources block if they are effectively final. 


BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("file.txt"));
try (reader) {
    // works in Java 9+
}
      


class MyThread extends Thread {
    public void run() {
        System.out.println("Thread running via Thread class");
    }
}

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        MyThread t = new MyThread();
        t.start();
    }
}
      


class MyRunnable implements Runnable {
    public void run() {
