        System.out.println("Thread running via Runnable");
    }
}

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Thread t = new Thread(new MyRunnable());
        t.start();
    }
}
      


public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Thread t = new Thread(() -> System.out.println("Thread via Lambda"));
        t.start();
    }
}
      


import java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService;
import java.util.concurrent.Executors;

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        ExecutorService service = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor();
        service.execute(() -> System.out.println("Thread via ExecutorService"));
        service.shutdown();
    }
}
      


import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        ExecutorService service = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor();
        Callable task = () -> "Callable Result";
        Future<String> future = service.submit(task);
        System.out.println(future.get());
        service.shutdown();
    }
}

Used to submit a task and get a Future object.
- Accepts both Runnable and Callable.
- Returns a Future which can be used to get the result or check task completion.
- Useful for tasks that return a value or may throw exceptions.

Example: 

ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(1);
Future<String> future = executor.submit(() -> {
    return "Hello from submit!";
});
System.out.println(future.get()); // prints: Hello from submit!
executor.shutdown();

Used to execute a task without expecting a result.
- Accepts only Runnable.
- Doesnâ€™t return any value (no Future).
- Suitable for fire-and-forget type tasks.

Example: 

ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(1);
executor.execute(() -> System.out.println("Hello from execute!"));
executor.shutdown();

Aspect submit() execute()
Return Type Future void
Supports Callable âœ… âŒ
Exception Handling Captured in Future Throws at runtime
Use Case Need result Just run the task

This is the core pattern used.
- A pool of worker threads is created.
- Tasks are submitted and assigned to threads from the pool.
- Prevents the overhead of creating a new thread per task.
- Enhances performance and resource management.

Real usage: Executors.newFixedThreadPool()

Used for task execution policies.
- Different implementations of Executor provide different strategies.
- For example: CachedThreadPool, FixedThreadPool, SingleThreadExecutor.
- Each strategy controls how threads are allocated and reused.

Every task is treated as a command object.
- Implemented using Runnable or Callable.
- Encapsulates all information needed to perform an action (task).
- Executor executes the command independently.

Used internally to decouple task submission and execution.
- Tasks (producers) are submitted to a queue.
- Worker threads (consumers) take tasks from the queue and execute them.
- Improves throughput and responsiveness.

No, fields don't have to be final, but it's highly recommended. Using final gives compile-time safety and ensures the field is not reassigned.

- Internal code might reassign the field by mistake.
- Doesn't guarantee immutability at compile time.
- Less clarity and safety in multi-threaded environments.

- Declare class as final.
- Declare all fields as private final.
- Initialize them in the constructor only.
- Donâ€™t expose setters.
- Return defensive copies for mutable fields.

substring() is used to extract a portion of a string. It takes beginIndex and endIndex and returns the characters in that range.

Internally, it creates a new char[] that contains only the substring characters. It does not share the original array like it used to in Java 7.

- Java 7: Shares char[] â†’ risk of memory leak
- Java 8: Copies to new char[] â†’ safe and clean
- Preferred for modern apps and memory-safe logic. 

String str1 = "abc";
- Stored in **String Constant Pool** (inside Heap).
- If another `"abc"` literal exists, it will be **reused**.
- Memory efficient. 

String str2 = new String("abc");
- Always creates a **new object** in the Heap.
- Even if "abc" exists in the string pool.
- Not memory efficient. 


String str1 = "abc";
String str2 = new String("abc");

System.out.println(str1 == str2);      // false (different objects)
System.out.println(str1.equals(str2)); // true (same value)
- == compares object **references**
- equals() compares **values**

Use intern() method:

String str3 = new String("abc").intern();
System.out.println(str1 == str3); // true
- `intern()` checks if literal is in pool â†’ returns reference. 


@Test
void testExceptionThrown() {
    IllegalArgumentException ex = assertThrows(IllegalArgumentException.class, () -> {
        myService.validateInput(null);
    });
    assertEquals("Input cannot be null", ex.getMessage());
}
- âœ… Checks both **type** and **message** of the exception 


import static org.assertj.core.api.Assertions.assertThatThrownBy;

@Test
void testUsingAssertJ() {
    assertThatThrownBy(() -> myService.validateInput(null))
        .isInstanceOf(IllegalArgumentException.class)
        .hasMessage("Input cannot be null");
}
- âœ… Clean, readable and **chained assertion** style 


@Test
void testControllerException() throws Exception {
    mockMvc.perform(get("/api/test/exception"))
           .andExpect(status().isBadRequest())
           .andExpect(jsonPath("$.message").value("Invalid input"));
}
- âœ… Use this to test **@ControllerAdvice**, exception handlers, etc.

A bean is simply a Java object managed by Spring. Beans represent the core building blocks of a Spring application.

Example: 

@Component
public class MyService {
    // business logic
}

The ApplicationContext is the heart of the Spring IoC container. It is responsible for instantiating, configuring, and managing beans.

Example: 

ApplicationContext context = 
    new AnnotationConfigApplicationContext(AppConfig.class);
MyService service = context.getBean(MyService.class);

DI is the process where Spring injects dependencies into a class (like service into controller) instead of the class creating them itself.

Example: 

@Service
public class OrderService {
    private final PaymentService paymentService;

    @Autowired
    public OrderService(PaymentService paymentService) {
        this.paymentService = paymentService;
    }
}
Spring provides the PaymentService at runtime ğŸ¯

This defines how Spring should create, configure, and assemble the beans (via XML, annotations, or Java Config).

Example using Java Config: 

@Configuration
public class AppConfig {
    @Bean
    public MyService myService() {
        return new MyService();
    }
}

ğŸ§  Learn & Explain
  • Help you learn new topics (science, space, finance, etc.)
  • Break down complex concepts into simple terms
  • Create quizzes, mock interviews, flashcards
âœï¸ Write & Create
  • Draft emails, resumes, blogs, and cover letters
  • Create technical documentation and user guides
  • Write stories, poems, lyrics, or fun content
ğŸ¨ Design & Visuals
  • Generate diagrams, flowcharts, and architecture layouts
  • Help with UI/UX design ideas
  • Generate or edit images
ğŸ“Š Analyze & Automate
  • Write scripts for automation, scraping, or data analysis
  • Optimize SQL queries, debug issues
  • Assist in performance tuning and reports
ğŸ˜Œ Just Chat
  • Talk about movies, motivation, productivity, etc.
  • Be a thinking buddy or just keep you company

  1. 1. Bean
    A Bean is an object managed by the Spring container. These are the building blocks of your application, defined with annotations like @Component, @Service, @Repository, or in XML config.
  2. 2. ApplicationContext
    It's the heart of Spring IOC. It creates, wires, configures, and manages the lifecycle of beans. It also provides features like internationalization, event propagation, and resource loading.
  3. 3. BeanFactory
    It's the root interface for accessing the Spring container. It lazily loads beans.
    ApplicationContext is a superset of BeanFactory and is generally preferred.
  4. 4. Dependency Injection (DI)
    Core of IOC. The control of object creation and injection is handed over to the Spring container.
    Two types: Constructor Injection and Setter Injection.
  5. 5. Configuration Metadata
    Defines how beans are configured: XML, Java-based config (using @Configuration), or annotations.
  6. 6. Bean Definition
    Contains metadata like class name, scope, lifecycle callbacks, and dependencies for a bean, used internally by Spring.
  7. 7. BeanPostProcessor
    Interface used to intercept bean creation to modify or wrap bean instances, e.g., for proxying or custom logic.
  8. 8. BeanFactoryPostProcessor
    Similar to BeanPostProcessor, but it allows modifying the Bean definitions before the beans are instantiated.
  9. 9. IoC Container
    The container (like ApplicationContext) that manages the entire lifecycle of beans and handles the inversion of control.
ğŸ‘‰ TL;DR: Spring IOC is a powerful mechanism where the container handles object creation and dependency management, letting developers focus on business logic.

  • 1. Isolation: Each microservice runs in its own container, with its own environment, dependencies, and libraries â€” avoiding conflicts.
  • 2. Portability: Containers include everything the service needs, making it easy to run the same microservice across dev, QA, staging, and prod environments.
  • 3. Scalability: Containers are lightweight and fast to start, so microservices can scale in and out easily based on traffic.
  • 4. Resource Efficiency: Containers use fewer resources than virtual machines and allow better utilization of server capacity.
  • 5. DevOps Friendly: Works great with CI/CD pipelines, Docker, Kubernetes â€” supporting rapid development, testing, and deployment cycles.
  • 6. Rollback & Versioning: Containers can be versioned and rolled back easily using image tags.
  • 7. Easy Monitoring & Logging: Tools like Prometheus, Grafana, and ELK work seamlessly with containerized microservices for better observability.
  • 8. Faster Recovery: In case of failure, containers can be restarted or replaced quickly using orchestration tools like Kubernetes.

In short: Containers give microservices agility, efficiency, and independence â€” exactly what you need to run them in a distributed environment like the cloud.

  • 100 Continue: The server has received the request headers, and the client should proceed to send the request body.
  • 101 Switching Protocols: The requester has asked the server to switch protocols.

  • 200 OK: The request succeeded.
  • 201 Created: The request succeeded and a resource was created.
  • 202 Accepted: The request has been accepted for processing, but the processing is not completed.
  • 204 No Content: The server successfully processed the request, but is not returning any content.

  • 301 Moved Permanently: The URL of the requested resource has been changed permanently.
  • 302 Found: The resource resides temporarily under a different URI.
  • 304 Not Modified: The resource has not been modified since the last request.

  • 400 Bad Request: The server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax.
  • 401 Unauthorized: The client must authenticate itself to get the requested response.
  • 403 Forbidden: The client does not have access rights to the content.
  • 404 Not Found: The server cannot find the requested resource.
  • 405 Method Not Allowed: The method is not allowed for the requested URL.
  • 409 Conflict: The request conflicts with the current state of the server.
  • 429 Too Many Requests: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time.

  • 500 Internal Server Error: The server encountered an unexpected condition.
  • 501 Not Implemented: The server does not support the functionality required to fulfill the request.
  • 502 Bad Gateway: The server, while acting as a gateway or proxy, received an invalid response.
  • 503 Service Unavailable: The server is not ready to handle the request (e.g. maintenance or overload).
  • 504 Gateway Timeout: The server did not receive a timely response from an upstream server.

Description: Used to represent a task to be executed by a thread. It has no return type and no checked exception.
void run()

Example: 

Runnable task = () -> System.out.println("Running in a thread");
Thread t = new Thread(task);
t.start();

Description: Similar to Runnable, but it can return a result and throw a checked exception.
T call() throws Exception

Example: 

Callable<String> task = () -> {
    return "Result from callable";
};

ExecutorService executor = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor();
Future<String> future = executor.submit(task);
System.out.println(future.get()); // Output: Result from callable
executor.shutdown();

Description: Defines custom comparison logic for sorting.
int compare(T o1, T o2)

Example: 

List<String> names = Arrays.asList("Narahari", "Ravi", "Anil");
names.sort((s1, s2) -> s1.length() - s2.length());
System.out.println(names); // Sorted by length

Description: Used to define the natural order of objects.
int compareTo(T o)

Example: 

class Employee implements Comparable<Employee> {
    int id;
    String name;
    public Employee(int id, String name) {
        this.id = id;
        this.name = name;
    }

    public int compareTo(Employee other) {
        return this.id - other.id;
    }
}
List<Employee> list = List.of(new Employee(2, "A"), new Employee(1, "B"));
Collections.sort(list); // Sorted by id

Explanation:
Java does not recommend forcefully stopping threads (like using Thread.stop()). Instead, we use interrupt() to request a thread to stop, and the thread should handle that request cooperatively.

Code Example: 

class MyTask implements Runnable {
    public void run() {
        while (!Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted()) {
            System.out.println("Running...");
            try {
                Thread.sleep(1000);
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                System.out.println("Thread was interrupted during sleep");
                Thread.currentThread().interrupt(); // Re-set the interrupt flag
                break;
            }
        }
        System.out.println("Thread exiting...");
    }
}

Thread t = new Thread(new MyTask());
t.start();

// Sleep main for 3 seconds then interrupt
Thread.sleep(3000);
t.interrupt();

Three ways to check interruption:
  • Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted() â†’ Checks and does not clear the flag
  • Thread.interrupted() â†’ Checks and clears the interrupt status
  • Catch InterruptedException if blocking methods are used

if (Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted()) {
    System.out.println("Thread was interrupted");
}
        


pipeline {
  agent any

  environment {
    IMAGE_NAME = "my-spring-boot-app"
    DOCKER_REGISTRY = "docker.io/your-username"
  }

  stages {
    stage('Checkout') {
      steps {
        git 'https://github.com/your-repo.git'
      }
    }

    stage('Build') {
      steps {
        sh 'mvn clean install'
      }
    }

    stage('Unit Test') {
      steps {
        sh 'mvn test'
      }
    }

    stage('Docker Build & Push') {
      steps {
        script {
          docker.build("${IMAGE_NAME}:latest")
                .push("${DOCKER_REGISTRY}/${IMAGE_NAME}:latest")
        }
      }
    }

    stage('Deploy') {
      steps {
        echo 'Deploy to server or Kubernetes...'
      }
    }
  }

  post {
    success {
      echo 'âœ… Build completed successfully!'
    }
    failure {
      echo 'âŒ Build failed.'
    }
  }
}
ğŸ”§ Features Covered:
  • Git Checkout
  • Maven Build & Test
  • Docker Image Build & Push
  • Deployment Stage
  • Post build notifications

ğŸ“Œ Checked Exceptions
  • Inherit from java.lang.Exception (except RuntimeException)
  • Must be either caught or declared in the method signature
  • Used for recoverable conditions
  • Examples: IOException, SQLException, ParseException

public void readFile(String filePath) throws IOException {
    BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(filePath));
    // read file...
}
âš ï¸ Unchecked Exceptions
  • Inherit from java.lang.RuntimeException
  • No need to catch or declare in method signature
  • Used for programming errors like logic mistakes or improper API use
  • Examples: NullPointerException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, IllegalArgumentException 

public void printLength(String input) {
    System.out.println(input.length()); // may throw NullPointerException
}
âœ… Summary
Aspect Checked Unchecked
Inheritance Exception RuntimeException
Handled/Declared? Yes No
Common Usage Recoverable errors Programming errors
Examples IOException, SQLException NullPointerException, IllegalStateException

âœ… Common & Essential String Methods
  • length() â€“ Returns the length of the string
  • charAt(int index) â€“ Returns the character at the specified index
  • substring(int begin, int end) â€“ Returns a substring
  • equals(Object obj) â€“ Compares content of strings
  • equalsIgnoreCase(String another) â€“ Case-insensitive equality check
  • compareTo(String another) â€“ Lexicographically compares two strings
  • contains(CharSequence s) â€“ Checks if a string contains a sequence
  • indexOf(String str) â€“ Returns index of first occurrence
  • toLowerCase() / toUpperCase() â€“ Case transformation
  • replace(CharSequence target, CharSequence replacement) â€“ Replaces characters
  • split(String regex) â€“ Splits string around matches
  • trim() â€“ Removes leading/trailing whitespaces
âœ¨ Java 11+ String Methods
  • isBlank() â€“ Returns true if string is empty or contains only white space
  • lines() â€“ Returns a stream of lines from the string
  • repeat(int count) â€“ Returns a string repeated count times
  • strip() â€“ Removes leading/trailing whitespaces (Unicode-aware, better than trim())
  • stripLeading() â€“ Removes leading whitespaces
  • stripTrailing() â€“ Removes trailing whitespaces

// Java 11+ Example
String text = "  Hello World  \nWelcome to Java!";
System.out.println(text.strip());               // Removes spaces
System.out.println(text.lines().count());       // Counts lines
System.out.println("Java".repeat(3));           // JavaJavaJava
System.out.println("  ".isBlank());             // true
ğŸ§  Tips
  • Prefer isBlank() over trim().isEmpty()
  • Use strip() instead of trim() for Unicode whitespace
  • Use repeat() for padding or repeating strings easily

ğŸ”¸ Static Methods in Interface (Since Java 8)
  • Can have method body.
  • Belong to the interface, not to implementing classes.
  • Can be called using InterfaceName.methodName().

interface MyInterface {
    static void printInfo() {
        System.out.println("Static method in interface");
    }
}

// Usage
MyInterface.printInfo(); // âœ…
ğŸ”’ Private Methods in Interface (Since Java 9)
  • Used to share common code between default and static methods.
  • Not accessible outside the interface.
  • Improves modularity and avoids duplication.

interface MyInterface {
    default void show() {
        log("Showing...");
    }

    private void log(String msg) {
        System.out.println("Log: " + msg);
    }
}
âœ¨ Key Benefits
  • Encapsulation inside interface.
  • Utility-like functionality via static methods.
  • Code reusability using private helper methods.
  • Encourages cleaner design and better structure.

ğŸ“¦ Step 1: Create Model

class Employee {
    private int id;
    private String name;
    private String department;
    private double salary;

    // constructor, getters, setters

    public Employee(int id, String name, String department, double salary) {
        this.id = id;
        this.name = name;
        this.department = department;
        this.salary = salary;
    }

    public String getDepartment() { return department; }
    public double getSalary() { return salary; }
    public String getName() { return name; }

    @Override
    public String toString() {
        return name + " - " + department + " - â‚¹" + salary;
    }
}
ğŸš€ Step 2: Use Java 8 Stream

List<Employee> employees = Arrays.asList(
    new Employee(1, "Alice", "HR", 45000),
    new Employee(2, "Bob", "HR", 60000),
    new Employee(3, "Charlie", "IT", 75000),
    new Employee(4, "David", "IT", 85000),
    new Employee(5, "Eve", "Finance", 70000)
);

Map<String, Employee> highestPaidByDept = employees.stream()
    .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(
        Employee::getDepartment,
        Collectors.collectingAndThen(
            Collectors.maxBy(Comparator.comparingDouble(Employee::getSalary)),
            Optional::get
        )
    ));

highestPaidByDept.forEach((department, employee) -> 
    System.out.println("Highest paid in " + department + " department: " + employee)
);
ğŸ” Explanation:
  • We first create a list of Employee objects.
  • We use Collectors.groupingBy to group employees by their department.
  • For each department, we use Collectors.maxBy to find the employee with the highest salary.
  • Finally, we print out the highest paid employee from each department.

ğŸ”„ Streams

A stream in Java is a sequence of elements supporting sequential and parallel aggregate operations. It allows for easy manipulation of data without altering the original source.

ğŸ¯ Key Features of Streams:
  • Streams operate sequentially by default.
  • When using a Stream, operations are executed in a single thread, meaning that data is processed one element at a time.
  • They are designed to process data in a functional style using methods like map(), filter(), and collect().
  • They can be infinite (e.g., generating infinite streams), but their execution is typically finite.
ğŸ“š Example of Regular Stream:

List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
int sum = numbers.stream()
    .filter(n -> n > 2)
    .mapToInt(Integer::intValue)
    .sum();
System.out.println("Sum of numbers > 2: " + sum); // Output: 12
âš¡ Parallel Streams

Parallel streams are an extension of the Stream API, where the stream operations can be executed in parallel across multiple threads. This can significantly improve performance on large data sets with complex operations, especially on multi-core processors.

ğŸ¯ Key Features of Parallel Streams:
  • Parallel Streams use the common ForkJoinPool to perform operations in parallel across multiple threads.
  • They divide the data into multiple parts, process them simultaneously, and combine the results.
  • Parallelism works best for computationally expensive operations on large datasets.
  • While parallel streams offer performance improvement, they may be less efficient for smaller datasets or operations that are not CPU-intensive.
ğŸ“š Example of Parallel Stream:

List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
int sum = numbers.parallelStream()
    .filter(n -> n > 2)
    .mapToInt(Integer::intValue)
    .sum();
System.out.println("Sum of numbers > 2: " + sum); // Output: 12
âš–ï¸ Key Differences
Feature Stream Parallel Stream
Execution Sequential (single thread) Parallel (multiple threads)
Performance Good for small datasets Better for large datasets or computationally expensive tasks
Order of Execution Maintains order Does not guarantee order unless specifically controlled (e.g., forEachOrdered())
Thread Safety Single thread Multiple threads (must ensure thread safety for mutable shared resources)
ğŸš¦ When to Use Streams vs Parallel Streams
  • Use regular streams when you're working with small or moderately sized datasets or when thread safety is a concern.
  • Use parallel streams when you're working with large datasets and when the operations are CPU-bound (e.g., sorting, complex filtering) that can benefit from parallelism.
  • Be cautious with parallel streams for IO-bound tasks (e.g., database access, file reading), as the overhead of thread management might outweigh the benefits.

ğŸ”„ What is ForkJoinPool?

ForkJoinPool is a specialized thread pool designed for tasks that can be recursively split into smaller tasks and later joined back together. It is optimized for parallelism and allows tasks to be forked and later joined in a recursive manner.

ğŸ¯ Key Features of ForkJoinPool:
  • Uses the work-stealing algorithm where idle threads steal work from busy threads.
  • Best suited for divide-and-conquer tasks, like recursive algorithms.
  • It can dynamically adjust the number of threads based on available CPUs and workload.
ğŸ“š Example of ForkJoinPool:

import java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask;
import java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool;

public class ForkJoinExample {

    // A task that calculates the sum of a range of numbers
    static class SumTask extends RecursiveTask {
        private final int[] arr;
        private final int start, end;

        public SumTask(int[] arr, int start, int end) {
            this.arr = arr;
            this.start = start;
            this.end = end;
        }

        @Override
        protected Integer compute() {
            if (end - start <= 10) { // If the task is small enough, process it sequentially
                int sum = 0;
                for (int i = start; i < end; i++) {
                    sum += arr[i];
                }
                return sum;
            } else {
                int mid = (start + end) / 2;
                SumTask task1 = new SumTask(arr, start, mid);
                SumTask task2 = new SumTask(arr, mid, end);
                
                task1.fork();  // Fork task1
                int task2Result = task2.fork().join();  // Fork and join task2
                int task1Result = task1.join();  // Join task1
                
                return task1Result + task2Result;
            }
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int[] numbers = new int[100];
        for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
            numbers[i] = i + 1;  // Filling array with numbers 1 to 100
        }
        
        ForkJoinPool pool = new ForkJoinPool(); // Create ForkJoinPool
        SumTask task = new SumTask(numbers, 0, numbers.length);
        int result = pool.invoke(task); // Invoke the task
        System.out.println("Sum of numbers: " + result);
    }
}
âš¡ ForkJoinPool Features

The ForkJoinPool utilizes a work-stealing algorithm to balance the workload across threads. When a thread completes its task, it can "steal" tasks from other threads, ensuring efficient usage of all threads.

âš–ï¸ When to Use ForkJoinPool
  • When you have tasks that can be split into smaller tasks (divide-and-conquer pattern).
  • When you need parallelism and want to utilize multiple processors efficiently.
  • When the task is computationally expensive and can benefit from parallel execution.
ğŸš¦ Key Considerations
  • ForkJoinPool is most effective when the tasks are recursive and independent, like in divide-and-conquer algorithms.
  • It's not ideal for IO-bound tasks, as the overhead of managing threads may negate any performance gains.
  • The pool is designed to scale efficiently with the number of available CPU cores.

ğŸ”„ What is Future in Java?

Future is an interface that represents the result of an asynchronous computation. It allows you to check if the computation is complete, wait for its completion, and retrieve the result.

ğŸ¯ Key Features of Future:
  • Provides methods like get() to wait for the result, and isDone() to check if the task is completed.
  • Does not allow you to modify the task after it's submitted.
  • Can be used with ExecutorService to execute asynchronous tasks.
ğŸ“š Example of Future:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class FutureExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws ExecutionException, InterruptedException {
        ExecutorService executor = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor();

        Callable task = () -> {
            TimeUnit.SECONDS.sleep(2);
            return 123;
        };

        Future future = executor.submit(task); // Submitting a task for execution

        // Waiting for the task to complete and get the result
        Integer result = future.get();
        System.out.println("Task result: " + result); // Output after 2 seconds: 123

        executor.shutdown();
    }
}
âš¡ What is CompletableFuture in Java?

CompletableFuture is an extension of the Future interface that allows you to manually complete the future. It provides a way to write asynchronous, non-blocking code using lambda expressions and offers more flexibility than Future.

ğŸ¯ Key Features of CompletableFuture:
  • Can be manually completed using complete() method.
  • Supports chaining of asynchronous tasks with methods like thenApply(), thenAccept(), and thenCompose().
  • Supports both synchronous and asynchronous computations, and you can combine multiple futures.
ğŸ“š Example of CompletableFuture:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class CompletableFutureExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws ExecutionException, InterruptedException {
        // Creating a CompletableFuture
        CompletableFuture future = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> {
            try {
                TimeUnit.SECONDS.sleep(2); // Simulate a task
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
            }
            return 123;
        });

        // Applying a function after completion
        future.thenApply(result -> {
            System.out.println("Processed result: " + result * 2); // Output: 246
            return result * 2;
        });

        // Block and get the result
        Integer result = future.get(); 
        System.out.println("Final result: " + result); // Output: 123
    }
}
âš–ï¸ Key Differences Between Future and CompletableFuture
Feature Future CompletableFuture
Completion Cannot be manually completed Can be manually completed using complete()
Task Chaining Not supported Supports chaining using methods like thenApply(), thenAccept()
Asynchronous Tasks Can execute asynchronously but with limited functionality Better support for asynchronous tasks with more flexibility
Exception Handling Limited exception handling Provides better exception handling using handle() and exceptionally()
ğŸš¦ When to Use Future vs CompletableFuture
  • Use Future when you need a simple asynchronous task that doesn't require further manipulation or chaining.
  • Use CompletableFuture when you need to combine multiple asynchronous tasks, or when you need more control over task completion and chaining of results.

ğŸ”„ CPU-bound Tasks

For CPU-bound tasks (tasks that perform heavy computations), the ideal thread pool size is typically equal to the number of available CPU cores. This prevents excessive context switching and optimizes performance.

ğŸ¯ Formula:
  • Thread pool size = number of CPU cores
ğŸ“š Example:

int availableCores = Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors();
int threadPoolSize = availableCores; // Set thread pool size equal to CPU cores
ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(threadPoolSize);
ğŸ”„ IO-bound Tasks

For IO-bound tasks (tasks that spend time waiting for external resources like database queries or file I/O), the number of threads can exceed the number of CPU cores, as threads may often be idle waiting for the resource.

ğŸ¯ Formula:
  • Thread pool size = 2 * number of CPU cores (or 3 * number of CPU cores)
ğŸ“š Example:

int availableCores = Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors();
int threadPoolSize = 2 * availableCores; // For IO-bound tasks, set thread pool size to 2 times CPU cores
ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(threadPoolSize);
ğŸ”„ Mixed Tasks (CPU-bound + IO-bound)

For mixed tasks (both CPU-bound and IO-bound), you may combine both strategies. Use the number of CPU cores for CPU-bound tasks and a larger pool size for IO-bound tasks.

ğŸ¯ Formula:
  • Thread pool size = number of CPU cores + factor for IO-bound tasks
ğŸ“š Example:

int availableCores = Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors();
int threadPoolSize = availableCores + 2 * availableCores; // For mixed tasks
ExecutorService executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(threadPoolSize);
ğŸ”„ Task Execution Time

If tasks have varying execution times, you may need to adjust the thread pool size dynamically based on the task duration and system performance.

ğŸ¯ Formula:
  • Monitor task execution time and adjust the pool size as needed.
ğŸ”„ System Resources

Be mindful of system resource limits such as available memory and CPU utilization. Too many threads can lead to excessive memory consumption and resource contention.

ğŸ¯ Formula:
  • Set thread pool size based on system resource limits (e.g., memory and CPU usage).
ğŸ”„ Java Thread Pool Example

You can define a thread pool size using the ExecutorService interface like this:


int availableCores = Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors();
int threadPoolSize = 2 * availableCores; // Example for IO-bound tasks
ExecutorService executor = new ThreadPoolExecutor(
    availableCores, // Core pool size
    threadPoolSize, // Max pool size
    60L,            // Keep-alive time
    TimeUnit.SECONDS,
    new LinkedBlockingQueue<>()
);
ğŸ”„ Performance Monitoring

Monitor the performance of your thread pool under various sizes. Use tools like JConsole, VisualVM, or custom logging to track CPU utilization, task completion time, and throughput.

ğŸ¯ Formula:
  • Test and monitor the system performance.
  • Adjust thread pool size based on real-world load and performance metrics.
âš–ï¸ Summary
  • CPU-bound tasks: Thread pool size = number of CPU cores.
  • IO-bound tasks: Thread pool size = 2 to 3 times the number of CPU cores.
  • Mixed tasks: Combine strategies based on task type.
  • System resources: Adjust based on memory and CPU limits.
  • Testing and monitoring: Continuously monitor and adjust thread pool size based on performance.

ğŸ”„ Problem Statement

We need to print even and odd numbers alternately using threads and inter-thread communication in an effective way. One thread will print even numbers and the other will print odd numbers, ensuring they alternate properly.

ğŸ¯ Key Concepts
  • Inter-thread Communication: Threads communicate using wait() and notify() methods.
  • Synchronization: Threads are synchronized using a common lock object to ensure only one thread executes at a time.
  • Alternating Execution: One thread waits for the other to finish before continuing, ensuring even and odd numbers are printed in the correct order.
ğŸ“š Example Code

class EvenOddPrinter {
    private int number = 1;
    private final int MAX = 10;
    private final Object lock = new Object();

    // Thread for printing even numbers
    public void printEven() {
        synchronized (lock) {
            while (number <= MAX) {
                if (number % 2 != 0) {
                    try {
                        lock.wait();
                    } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                        Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
                    }
                }
                if (number <= MAX) {
                    System.out.println("Even: " + number);
                    number++;
                }
                lock.notify();
            }
        }
    }

    // Thread for printing odd numbers
    public void printOdd() {
        synchronized (lock) {
            while (number <= MAX) {
                if (number % 2 == 0) {
                    try {
                        lock.wait();
                    } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                        Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
                    }
                }
                if (number <= MAX) {
                    System.out.println("Odd: " + number);
                    number++;
                }
                lock.notify();
            }
        }
    }
}

public class EvenOddUsingThreads {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        EvenOddPrinter printer = new EvenOddPrinter();

        // Create and start even and odd threads
        Thread evenThread = new Thread(() -> printer.printEven());
        Thread oddThread = new Thread(() -> printer.printOdd());

        evenThread.start();
        oddThread.start();
    }
}
ğŸ”„ Explanation
  • Shared Resource (number): Both threads use the shared number variable to print the next even or odd number.
  • Synchronization: We use the lock object for synchronization to ensure only one thread prints at a time.
  • Inter-thread Communication: The wait() method is used to make the thread wait if it's not its turn to print (even or odd), and notify() is used to wake up the other thread.
  • Alternating Execution: Threads alternate printing even and odd numbers by notifying each other when theyâ€™re done.
ğŸ”„ Example Output

Even: 2
Odd: 1
Even: 4
Odd: 3
Even: 6
Odd: 5
Even: 8
Odd: 7
Even: 10
âš¡ Key Points
  • Thread Synchronization: By synchronizing on a common lock, we ensure that only one thread executes at a time, avoiding race conditions.
  • Efficient Inter-thread Communication: Using wait() and notify(), we effectively manage the order of execution between the threads.
  • Alternating Numbers: The threads alternate printing even and odd numbers based on the number variable and ensure synchronization with wait() and notify().

ğŸ”„ Understanding the Object Class Methods

The Object class is the root class for all classes in Java. Every class implicitly inherits from Object, and therefore, every class has access to its methods. Some common methods from the Object class include:

  • toString(): Provides a string representation of an object.
  • equals(): Checks if two objects are equal.
  • hashCode(): Provides a hash code representation of an object.
  • clone(): Creates and returns a copy of an object.
  • finalize(): Called before an object is garbage collected.
ğŸ¯ Can We Override These Methods in an Interface?

In Java, interfaces cannot directly override methods from the Object class. However, an interface can declare abstract methods, which can be implemented by the classes that implement the interface. These methods can have signatures similar to those of the methods in the Object class.

âš¡ Interface Example

Here is an example showing how an interface can define methods with the same signature as those in the Object class: 


interface MyInterface {
    String toString(); // Abstract method similar to Object's toString()
    boolean equals(Object obj); // Abstract method similar to Object's equals()
    int hashCode(); // Abstract method similar to Object's hashCode()
}

class MyClass implements MyInterface {
    @Override
    public String toString() {
        return "This is MyClass object";
    }

    @Override
    public boolean equals(Object obj) {
        if (this == obj) return true;
        if (obj == null || getClass() != obj.getClass()) return false;
        MyClass myClass = (MyClass) obj;
        return true; // Example comparison logic
    }

    @Override
    public int hashCode() {
        return 42; // Example hash code
    }
}
ğŸ”„ Why Can't Interfaces Override Methods of Object Class Directly?
  • Inheritance vs Implementation: An interface only defines behavior (abstract methods), but it doesnâ€™t provide any implementation. The methods of the Object class are already implemented, and interfaces cannot provide default implementations for methods that already exist in the base class.
  • Default Methods: Java 8 introduced default methods, which allow interfaces to provide a body for methods. However, even default methods cannot override methods from the Object class because they exist at the class level, not the interface level.
âš¡ Default Methods (Java 8 and Beyond)

Interfaces can provide default implementations for methods (using the default keyword), but this still does not allow interfaces to override methods from the Object class. You can implement similar methods in interfaces, but overriding Object class methods is not allowed. 


interface MyInterface {
    default String defaultToString() {
        return "Default toString implementation";
    }
}
âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • No Direct Overriding: Interfaces cannot override methods from the Object class, as interfaces are designed to define behavior without implementation.
  • Method Declarations: You can declare methods in an interface that have the same signatures as the methods in the Object class, but you must implement them in a class.
  • Default Methods: You can provide default implementations for methods in interfaces, but you still can't override Object class methods.

ğŸ”„ Understanding @Autowired

The @Autowired annotation in Spring is used to automatically wire dependencies into a Spring bean. It allows Spring to manage the lifecycle and injection of dependencies, reducing the need for manual configuration. However, there are certain drawbacks when overusing or improperly using this annotation.

ğŸ¯ Disadvantages of @Autowired
  • Lack of Control: With @Autowired, Spring automatically injects the dependencies, which reduces control over the instantiation process. This can make debugging and understanding the application flow more challenging, as dependencies are not explicitly managed.
  • Potential for NullPointerExceptions: If there are no suitable beans in the application context, Spring will throw a NoSuchBeanDefinitionException. Additionally, if the @Autowired field is not correctly initialized (for example, in the case of a non-required dependency), it could lead to NullPointerException errors at runtime.
  • Hard to Test: When you use @Autowired, the injected dependencies are tightly coupled to the Spring context, which can make unit testing harder. To properly test classes with @Autowired dependencies, you need to use Spring's testing framework or mock dependencies, adding complexity to tests.
  • Ambiguity in Autowiring: When there are multiple candidates for autowiring, Spring may struggle to determine which bean to inject. This can lead to an UnsatisfiedDependencyException or incorrect bean injection if the right qualifier is not provided.
  • Overuse of Annotations: Relying too much on @Autowired can lead to a "magic" codebase where it's unclear how dependencies are being injected. This can reduce readability and maintainability, especially for larger applications.
  • Constructor Injection Preferred: While @Autowired can be used on fields, it is generally recommended to use it on constructor-based injection to make the dependencies immutable and to promote better design. Using @Autowired on fields can lead to mutable and less predictable objects.
  • Circular Dependency Issues: @Autowired can sometimes cause circular dependencies when two or more beans depend on each other. While Spring tries to resolve these, it can lead to unexpected behavior or errors.
âš¡ Example of Autowiring Issues

Consider the following example where a circular dependency occurs:


@Component
class A {
    @Autowired
    private B b;
}

@Component
class B {
    @Autowired
    private A a;
}

This leads to a circular dependency because both classes depend on each other. Spring will throw an exception unless @Lazy or other strategies are used to break the circular reference.

âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • When to Use Carefully: Use @Autowired wisely, especially when dealing with complex or large applications. Prefer constructor-based injection where possible.
  • Testability: For easier testing, prefer constructor injection to allow easy mocking of dependencies and more explicit control over bean wiring.
  • Handle Ambiguity: If you have multiple candidates for injection, consider using the @Qualifier annotation to specify which bean should be injected.
  • Avoid Circular Dependencies: Watch out for circular dependencies, and if they arise, consider refactoring your code or using Spring's @Lazy annotation to resolve them.

ğŸ”„ What is Circular Dependency?

A circular dependency occurs when two or more beans in the Spring context depend on each other, either directly or indirectly. This creates a cycle where each bean needs the other to be created, leading to an infinite loop of bean instantiation, which causes Spring to throw an exception.

ğŸ¯ Example of Circular Dependency

Consider the following scenario where two beans, A and B, depend on each other: 


@Component
class A {
    @Autowired
    private B b;
}

@Component
class B {
    @Autowired
    private A a;
}

In this case, A depends on B, and B depends on A, creating a circular dependency. Spring will not be able to instantiate these beans and will throw a BeanCurrentlyInCreationException.

âš¡ How to Resolve Circular Dependencies

There are several ways to resolve circular dependencies in Spring:

1. Use @Lazy Annotation

The @Lazy annotation can be used to delay the instantiation of one of the beans in the circular dependency. This helps Spring avoid the circular creation problem by not requiring the beans to be created immediately.


@Component
class A {
    @Autowired
    @Lazy
    private B b;
}

@Component
class B {
    @Autowired
    private A a;
}

Here, B will be created first, and A will be lazily injected into it, resolving the circular dependency.

2. Use Constructor Injection

Instead of field injection (which is the default with @Autowired), using constructor injection can help resolve circular dependencies more explicitly. If two beans depend on each other, Spring can use setter injection to inject the second bean after the first is created.


@Component
class A {
    private final B b;
    
    @Autowired
    public A(B b) {
        this.b = b;
    }
}

@Component
class B {
    private final A a;
    
    @Autowired
    public B(A a) {
        this.a = a;
    }
}

In this example, Spring will handle the circular dependency by creating both beans and wiring them together after they are instantiated.

3. Use Setter Injection

Another approach is to use setter injection, which allows Spring to instantiate the beans first and then inject the dependencies via setters. This method breaks the circular dependency because Spring can instantiate both beans before injecting the circular dependencies.


@Component
class A {
    private B b;
    
    @Autowired
    public void setB(B b) {
        this.b = b;
    }
}

@Component
class B {
    private A a;
    
    @Autowired
    public void setA(A a) {
        this.a = a;
    }
}

In this case, Spring creates both A and B and then injects the dependencies using the setter methods.

4. Refactor Your Code

Sometimes, circular dependencies indicate that your applicationâ€™s design could be improved. Refactoring your code by introducing new beans or restructuring the dependencies can be a clean way to eliminate circular dependencies altogether. This may involve splitting a class into smaller, more manageable parts or changing how beans depend on each other.

For example, you could introduce an additional bean that contains the shared logic between A and B, removing the direct dependency between them.

âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • Lazy Initialization: Use the @Lazy annotation to delay the creation of one bean in the circular dependency cycle, allowing Spring to resolve the issue.
  • Constructor Injection: Use constructor injection to explicitly define the dependencies, allowing Spring to manage circular dependencies in a more controlled manner.
  • Setter Injection: Use setter injection to resolve circular dependencies by allowing Spring to instantiate beans first and inject dependencies afterward.
  • Refactor Code: If circular dependencies persist, it may be an indication that the design should be refactored to simplify the dependencies between the beans.

ğŸ”„ What is Feign Client?

Feign is a declarative web service client developed by Netflix. It simplifies the process of making HTTP requests by providing a higher-level abstraction over traditional HTTP clients like RestTemplate. Feign integrates seamlessly with Spring Cloud, and you can use it to call RESTful APIs in a declarative manner.

ğŸ¯ Feign Client vs RestTemplate

While both RestTemplate and Feign allow making HTTP requests, Feign offers several advantages over RestTemplate:

  • Declarative Approach: Feign uses interfaces to define HTTP requests, making the code more readable and compact. With RestTemplate, you need to manually handle HTTP calls and manage the response, which is more verbose.
  • Integration with Spring Cloud: Feign integrates tightly with Spring Cloud, providing out-of-the-box features like service discovery and load balancing through @LoadBalanced and Ribbon.
  • Support for Hystrix: Feign supports circuit breakers (Hystrix) for resilience, allowing you to handle failures gracefully in microservices architectures.
  • Configuration Flexibility: Feign allows easy customization of HTTP request behavior, error handling, and other client-side features, making it more flexible than RestTemplate in many scenarios.
âš¡ Feign Client Configuration

Feign provides several ways to configure its behavior. Here are the common configuration options:

1. Enable Feign Client

To enable Feign clients in your Spring Boot application, you need to add the @EnableFeignClients annotation in your main application class: 


@SpringBootApplication
@EnableFeignClients
public class MyApplication {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SpringApplication.run(MyApplication.class, args);
    }
}
2. Defining Feign Client Interface

To use Feign, you define an interface and annotate it with @FeignClient. You specify the name of the service or the target URL:


@FeignClient(name = "user-service")
public interface UserServiceClient {
    @GetMapping("/users/{id}")
    User getUser(@PathVariable("id") Long id);
}
3. Customizing Feign Client Configuration

You can customize the Feign client by providing a configuration class. This allows you to control aspects like timeouts, logging, and interceptors:


@Configuration
public class FeignConfig {
    @Bean
    public RequestInterceptor requestInterceptor() {
        return template -> template.header("Authorization", "Bearer token");
    }

    @Bean
    public Logger.Level feignLoggerLevel() {
        return Logger.Level.FULL; // Enable full logging for debugging
    }
}

To use this configuration with your Feign client, you can specify the configuration class in the @FeignClient annotation: 


@FeignClient(name = "user-service", configuration = FeignConfig.class)
public interface UserServiceClient {
    @GetMapping("/users/{id}")
    User getUser(@PathVariable("id") Long id);
}
4. Handling Errors

Feign provides custom error handling through the ErrorDecoder interface. You can define custom error handling logic for different HTTP status codes:


@Bean
public ErrorDecoder errorDecoder() {
    return new ErrorDecoder.Default();
}
âš¡ How Feign Helps Over RestTemplate

Feign simplifies interaction with REST APIs by abstracting away much of the boilerplate code that RestTemplate requires. Here's how Feign compares to RestTemplate:

1. Declarative and Readable Code

With Feign, you define HTTP requests in interfaces, making the code cleaner and more maintainable. In contrast, RestTemplate requires writing explicit code for sending HTTP requests and processing responses, which can get cumbersome.

2. Built-in Integration with Spring Cloud

Feign integrates seamlessly with Spring Cloud, enabling you to use service discovery (e.g., Eureka), load balancing (e.g., Ribbon), and fault tolerance (e.g., Hystrix) out of the box. RestTemplate requires additional configuration to achieve the same level of functionality.

3. Simplified Error Handling

Feign allows you to define custom error handling via the ErrorDecoder interface. With RestTemplate, you need to handle errors manually using try-catch blocks or ResponseEntity.

4. Readability and Testing

Feign's declarative approach makes it easier to read and test. When you use Feign, you can easily mock the interface methods in unit tests. On the other hand, with RestTemplate, you have to manually create and configure HTTP requests and responses, making testing more difficult.

âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • Declarative API Calls: Feign simplifies making HTTP calls by using interfaces and annotations, reducing boilerplate code compared to RestTemplate.
  • Built-in Features: Feign integrates with Spring Cloud for service discovery, load balancing, and fault tolerance, providing a more comprehensive solution than RestTemplate.
  • Configuration Flexibility: Feign allows customization of logging, timeouts, error handling, and headers, offering more flexibility than RestTemplate.
  • Readable and Maintainable: Feign code is more readable and maintainable compared to RestTemplate, especially for large microservices architectures.

ğŸ”„ Scenario: Service A Calling Service B and Exception Occurrence

When one service (Service A) calls another service (Service B) in a distributed system, and Service B raises an exception, it typically impacts Service A. The exception can either be a runtime exception (such as a NullPointerException) or a checked exception (such as a HttpClientErrorException) depending on the error scenario.

ğŸ¯ What Happens When Service B Raises an Exception?

If Service B throws an exception during the invocation, it propagates to Service A. The calling service (Service A) can either catch the exception or let it propagate further depending on the handling strategy implemented.

ğŸ“š Example Scenario

Service A calls Service B to fetch user details. However, Service B encounters an error (e.g., a database error or a bad request) and throws an exception. Here's a simple example:


@Service
public class ServiceA {
    @Autowired
    private ServiceB serviceB;

    public void getUserDetails() {
        try {
            User user = serviceB.getUserById(1);
            System.out.println(user);
        } catch (ServiceBException e) {
            System.out.println("Error occurred while fetching user details from Service B: " + e.getMessage());
        }
    }
}

@Service
public class ServiceB {
    public User getUserById(int id) throws ServiceBException {
        // Simulating an error scenario in Service B
        if (id <= 0) {
            throw new ServiceBException("Invalid user ID");
        }
        return new User(id, "John Doe");
    }
}

class ServiceBException extends Exception {
    public ServiceBException(String message) {
        super(message);
    }
}

class User {
    private int id;
    private String name;

    // Constructor, getters, setters, etc.
}

In the example above, Service A calls Service B's getUserById() method, which throws a ServiceBException if the user ID is invalid. Service A catches the exception and handles the error gracefully.

âš¡ How to Handle This Scenario?

To handle such scenarios efficiently, here are a few common strategies you can use:

1. Exception Handling in Service A

Service A can catch exceptions thrown by Service B and handle them appropriately. In the example above, Service A catches the ServiceBException and prints a message. You can also choose to return a default value or retry the operation.

2. Retry Logic with @Retryable or Circuit Breaker

If the exception is transient, you can implement retry logic using the @Retryable annotation or use a circuit breaker pattern to prevent continuous calls when the service is down:


@Retryable(maxAttempts = 3, value = ServiceBException.class, backoff = @Backoff(delay = 2000))
public User getUserByIdWithRetry(int id) throws ServiceBException {
    return serviceB.getUserById(id);
}

This will retry the method up to 3 times with a 2-second delay between attempts if a ServiceBException is thrown.

3. Using Circuit Breaker Pattern

If Service B is down or failing repeatedly, a Circuit Breaker pattern can prevent Service A from making repeated calls to Service B. You can implement this with Spring Cloud Circuit Breaker (e.g., Hystrix or Resilience4j).


@CircuitBreaker(name = "userService", fallbackMethod = "fallbackGetUserById")
public User getUserByIdWithCircuitBreaker(int id) throws ServiceBException {
    return serviceB.getUserById(id);
}

public User fallbackGetUserById(int id, Throwable ex) {
    // Fallback logic in case of failure
    return new User(-1, "Fallback User");
}

Here, if Service B fails repeatedly, the fallbackGetUserById method will be called as a fallback, ensuring Service A still gets a response.

4. Global Exception Handling with @ControllerAdvice (for Web Services)

If Service A and Service B are part of a web application, you can define global exception handling with @ControllerAdvice: 


@ControllerAdvice
public class GlobalExceptionHandler {

    @ExceptionHandler(ServiceBException.class)
    public ResponseEntity handleServiceBException(ServiceBException ex) {
        return new ResponseEntity<>(ex.getMessage(), HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR);
    }
}

This approach ensures that if any method in your controllers throws a ServiceBException, the global exception handler will manage it and send a proper HTTP response.

âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • Catch and Handle Exceptions: Catch exceptions in Service A and handle them appropriately (logging, retry, fallback, etc.).
  • Retry Mechanism: Implement retry logic with the @Retryable annotation for transient errors.
  • Circuit Breaker: Use a circuit breaker pattern (e.g., Hystrix, Resilience4j) to prevent repeated failures from overwhelming Service A.
  • Global Exception Handling: For web applications, use @ControllerAdvice for consistent global exception handling.

ğŸ”„ What is Microservices Architecture?

Microservices architecture is an approach to building applications as a suite of small, independent services that communicate over a network. Each microservice focuses on a specific business capability and can be developed, deployed, and scaled independently.

ğŸ¯ Key Best Practices for Microservices

Building microservices requires careful planning and adherence to best practices to ensure the system is scalable, maintainable, and resilient. Here are the key best practices:

1. Design Microservices Around Business Domains

Microservices should be designed around business capabilities or domains (e.g., user management, payment processing). This helps in organizing services based on business functionality rather than technical concerns.

Example: Instead of creating a monolithic service for all customer-related features, break it down into services like "Customer", "Order", "Inventory", etc.

2. Keep Microservices Small and Focused

Each microservice should be small, focused on a single responsibility, and loosely coupled with other services. This makes them easier to maintain, test, and scale.

Example: A "User" microservice should handle all user-related operations such as registration, authentication, and profile management, but it should not manage orders or payments.

3. Use a Gateway for API Aggregation

Instead of exposing each microservice directly to the clients, use an API Gateway to aggregate the APIs from various microservices. This simplifies communication between clients and services and provides additional features such as authentication, rate-limiting, and logging.

Example: Use tools like Spring Cloud Gateway or Netflix Zuul as API Gateways to manage requests.

4. Implement API Versioning

When making changes to an API, itâ€™s important to version your APIs to prevent breaking existing clients. This can be achieved through URL versioning, request header versioning, or content negotiation.

Example: A versioned URL could look like /api/v1/user and /api/v2/user.

5. Use Asynchronous Communication

Microservices often communicate with each other using REST or messaging protocols. Using asynchronous communication (e.g., using RabbitMQ, Kafka) helps decouple services and improve performance.

Example: Use Kafka to publish events like "Order Created", allowing other microservices (e.g., Payment, Inventory) to process them asynchronously.

6. Implement Fault Tolerance and Resilience

Microservices must handle failures gracefully to maintain system stability. Implement techniques such as retry logic, circuit breakers, and timeouts to handle failure scenarios.

Example: Use Hystrix (from Spring Cloud) to implement a circuit breaker and fallback mechanism if a microservice is down.

7. Automate Testing and Continuous Integration

Microservices should be continuously tested using unit tests, integration tests, and contract tests to ensure reliability. Implementing continuous integration (CI) pipelines ensures that all services are tested, built, and deployed automatically.

Example: Use tools like Jenkins, GitLab CI, or Travis CI for automated builds and tests.

8. Implement Distributed Tracing

To monitor and troubleshoot microservices effectively, implement distributed tracing. This helps track requests as they propagate across different services, enabling better insight into latency and bottlenecks.

Example: Use tools like Zipkin or Jaeger to collect distributed traces.

9. Decentralize Data Management

Each microservice should own its own data store to maintain independence. Avoid shared databases between services to prevent tight coupling and ensure scalability.

Example: The "User" microservice should have its own database, while the "Order" microservice has a separate one.

10. Monitor and Log Every Microservice

Implement logging and monitoring in every microservice. Centralized logging and monitoring provide visibility into system behavior and help detect and diagnose issues quickly.

Example: Use ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) or Prometheus with Grafana for centralized logging and monitoring.

11. Use Service Discovery

In microservices, services should be able to discover each other dynamically without hard-coded addresses. This can be achieved using a service discovery tool like Eureka or Consul.

Example: Service A can register itself with a service registry, and Service B can discover and communicate with Service A via the registry.

12. Manage Configuration Centrally

To maintain consistency across environments, centralize configuration management. Tools like Spring Cloud Config or Consul allow for centralized management of properties and settings.

Example: Use Spring Cloud Config Server to store configuration files, allowing each service to retrieve configurations from a central location.

âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • Business Domain Driven Design: Align microservices with business capabilities.
  • Small and Focused Services: Keep microservices small and focused on a single responsibility.
  • API Gateway: Use an API Gateway to manage client requests and expose the services.
  • Asynchronous Communication: Leverage asynchronous communication to decouple services.
  • Fault Tolerance: Implement resilience patterns like retries, circuit breakers, and timeouts.
  • Decentralized Data: Ensure each microservice owns its data store.
  • Continuous Integration: Implement CI/CD pipelines and automated testing.
  • Service Discovery: Use service discovery for dynamic communication between services.
  • Centralized Monitoring: Use centralized logging and monitoring to track service health and performance.

ğŸ”„ What is Microservices Architecture?

Microservices architecture is an approach to building applications as a suite of small, independent services that communicate over a network. Each microservice focuses on a specific business capability and can be developed, deployed, and scaled independently.

ğŸ¯ Key Best Practices for Microservices

Building microservices requires careful planning and adherence to best practices to ensure the system is scalable, maintainable, and resilient. Here are the key best practices:

1. Design Microservices Around Business Domains

Microservices should be designed around business capabilities or domains (e.g., user management, payment processing). This helps in organizing services based on business functionality rather than technical concerns.

Example: Instead of creating a monolithic service for all customer-related features, break it down into services like "Customer", "Order", "Inventory", etc.

2. Keep Microservices Small and Focused

Each microservice should be small, focused on a single responsibility, and loosely coupled with other services. This makes them easier to maintain, test, and scale.

Example: A "User" microservice should handle all user-related operations such as registration, authentication, and profile management, but it should not manage orders or payments.

3. Use a Gateway for API Aggregation

Instead of exposing each microservice directly to the clients, use an API Gateway to aggregate the APIs from various microservices. This simplifies communication between clients and services and provides additional features such as authentication, rate-limiting, and logging.

Example: Use tools like Spring Cloud Gateway or Netflix Zuul as API Gateways to manage requests.

4. Implement API Versioning

When making changes to an API, itâ€™s important to version your APIs to prevent breaking existing clients. This can be achieved through URL versioning, request header versioning, or content negotiation.

Example: A versioned URL could look like /api/v1/user and /api/v2/user.

5. Use Asynchronous Communication

Microservices often communicate with each other using REST or messaging protocols. Using asynchronous communication (e.g., using RabbitMQ, Kafka) helps decouple services and improve performance.

Example: Use Kafka to publish events like "Order Created", allowing other microservices (e.g., Payment, Inventory) to process them asynchronously.

6. Implement Fault Tolerance and Resilience

Microservices must handle failures gracefully to maintain system stability. Implement techniques such as retry logic, circuit breakers, and timeouts to handle failure scenarios.

Example: Use Hystrix (from Spring Cloud) to implement a circuit breaker and fallback mechanism if a microservice is down.

7. Automate Testing and Continuous Integration

Microservices should be continuously tested using unit tests, integration tests, and contract tests to ensure reliability. Implementing continuous integration (CI) pipelines ensures that all services are tested, built, and deployed automatically.

Example: Use tools like Jenkins, GitLab CI, or Travis CI for automated builds and tests.

8. Implement Distributed Tracing

To monitor and troubleshoot microservices effectively, implement distributed tracing. This helps track requests as they propagate across different services, enabling better insight into latency and bottlenecks.

Example: Use tools like Zipkin or Jaeger to collect distributed traces.

9. Decentralize Data Management

Each microservice should own its own data store to maintain independence. Avoid shared databases between services to prevent tight coupling and ensure scalability.

Example: The "User" microservice should have its own database, while the "Order" microservice has a separate one.

10. Monitor and Log Every Microservice

Implement logging and monitoring in every microservice. Centralized logging and monitoring provide visibility into system behavior and help detect and diagnose issues quickly.

Example: Use ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) or Prometheus with Grafana for centralized logging and monitoring.

11. Use Service Discovery

In microservices, services should be able to discover each other dynamically without hard-coded addresses. This can be achieved using a service discovery tool like Eureka or Consul.

Example: Service A can register itself with a service registry, and Service B can discover and communicate with Service A via the registry.

12. Manage Configuration Centrally

To maintain consistency across environments, centralize configuration management. Tools like Spring Cloud Config or Consul allow for centralized management of properties and settings.

Example: Use Spring Cloud Config Server to store configuration files, allowing each service to retrieve configurations from a central location.

âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • Business Domain Driven Design: Align microservices with business capabilities.
  • Small and Focused Services: Keep microservices small and focused on a single responsibility.
  • API Gateway: Use an API Gateway to manage client requests and expose the services.
  • Asynchronous Communication: Leverage asynchronous communication to decouple services.
  • Fault Tolerance: Implement resilience patterns like retries, circuit breakers, and timeouts.
  • Decentralized Data: Ensure each microservice owns its data store.
  • Continuous Integration: Implement CI/CD pipelines and automated testing.
  • Service Discovery: Use service discovery for dynamic communication between services.
  • Centralized Monitoring: Use centralized logging and monitoring to track service health and performance.

ğŸ”„ What is PUT?

PUT is an HTTP method used to update or create a resource. When you use PUT, you're replacing the entire resource with the data in the request body. If the resource doesn't exist, it may create a new one (depending on the server configuration).

ğŸ¯ Key Characteristics of PUT:
  • Idempotent: Calling PUT multiple times will always produce the same result (i.e., the resource will be in the same state).
  • Replaces the entire resource: PUT typically requires that the entire resource be sent, even if only a small change is required.
  • Creates or updates a resource: PUT can be used to create a new resource or update an existing one.
ğŸ“š Example of PUT Request:

PUT /users/123 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "id": 123,
  "name": "John Doe",
  "email": "john@example.com",
  "address": "123 Main St"
}

In this example, the entire user resource (with the id 123) is updated. If the resource doesnâ€™t exist, it will be created with the provided data.

ğŸ”„ What is PATCH?

PATCH is an HTTP method used for making partial updates to a resource. Unlike PUT, which replaces the entire resource, PATCH allows you to update only specific fields of a resource.

ğŸ¯ Key Characteristics of PATCH:
  • Non-idempotent: While PATCH can be idempotent, it is not required to be. Calling PATCH multiple times could lead to different results.
  • Partial updates: PATCH only requires the fields that need to be updated, not the entire resource.
  • More efficient for partial updates: PATCH can be more efficient than PUT when only a small part of the resource needs to be updated.
ğŸ“š Example of PATCH Request:

PATCH /users/123 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "address": "456 New Address"
}

In this example, only the "address" field of the user resource with id 123 is updated, and other fields (such as name and email) remain unchanged.

âš¡ Key Differences Between PUT and PATCH
Feature PUT PATCH
Operation Replaces the entire resource Partially updates a resource
Idempotency Idempotent (multiple requests yield the same result) Not necessarily idempotent
Resource requirement Requires sending the entire resource Only requires sending the fields that need to be updated
Efficiency Can be inefficient for partial updates More efficient for partial updates
ğŸš¦ When to Use PUT vs PATCH
  • Use PUT when you need to update the entire resource or when you need to replace an existing resource entirely.
  • Use PATCH when you only need to update a part of the resource and want to minimize the data sent over the network.
âš¡ Best Practices
  • For complete resource updates, use PUT.
  • For partial resource updates (e.g., just updating an email or address), use PATCH.
  • Make sure to handle resource validation on both PUT and PATCH to avoid inconsistent states.
  • While PUT is generally idempotent, PATCH should be designed in a way that avoids unintended side effects from repeated requests.

ğŸ”„ What are Query Parameters?

Query parameters are key-value pairs that are appended to the URL after the question mark (?) and are used to pass additional data to the server. They are commonly used in HTTP requests to send information like search criteria, filters, or pagination options.

ğŸ¯ Example of Query Parameters

https://example.com/search?query=java&category=programming&page=1

In this URL, query=java, category=programming, and page=1 are the query parameters.

âš¡ Maximum Length of a URL (Including Query Parameters)

The number of query parameters you can include in a URL depends on the maximum URL length supported by the browser and server. The total URL length includes the domain, path, query string, and other components.

ğŸ¯ Maximum URL Length
  • Browser Limits: Different browsers have different limits for the maximum URL length. For example:
    • Internet Explorer: 2,083 characters
    • Chrome, Firefox, Safari: Around 8,000 to 10,000 characters
  • Server Limits: The server may also impose its own limit on the URL length. For example, Apache and Nginx may have a default limit of 8,000 to 16,000 characters for the entire URL.
âš–ï¸ How Many Query Parameters Can You Pass?

Technically, the number of query parameters you can pass is limited by the total length of the URL, which includes the parameters, the URL path, and other parts of the URL.

For example, if your URL limit is 2,083 characters and your domain name takes up 30 characters, you would have 2,053 characters left for the path and query parameters. If each parameter takes 30 characters (e.g., key and value), you could pass approximately 68 parameters in the URL.

ğŸ“š Example of a Long URL with Many Query Parameters

https://example.com/search?param1=value1¶m2=value2¶m3=value3&...¶m100=value100

In this example, the URL includes 100 query parameters. You'd need to ensure that the URL length does not exceed the browser or server limits.

ğŸš¦ When to Avoid Large URLs
  • When you have a large number of query parameters, consider using POST requests instead of GET requests. POST requests allow you to send large amounts of data in the body of the request, which doesn't have the same URL length limitations.
  • If your parameters are sensitive, consider using the request body (via POST) instead of query parameters, which may expose sensitive data in the URL.
  • For large datasets, consider passing data in a more structured format like JSON in the request body rather than as a long list of query parameters.
âš¡ Key Takeaways
  • The number of query parameters is limited by the overall URL length, which can vary depending on the browser and server.
  • The typical practical limit for query parameters is between 1,000 to 2,000 characters, depending on the browser/server limits.
  • For large amounts of data, consider using POST requests or another method (e.g., request body) to avoid URL length limitations.

ğŸ”„ What is Data Hiding?

Data hiding is one of the fundamental concepts of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) that allows an object to restrict access to its internal state and data. This is achieved by using access modifiers to control access to the fields (variables) and methods of a class. Data hiding helps protect the integrity of the data by preventing external classes from directly modifying it.

ğŸ¯ Key Characteristics of Data Hiding:
  • Encapsulation: Data hiding is a core part of encapsulation, which bundles the data (variables) and methods (functions) that operate on the data into a single unit (class).
  • Access Control: By using access modifiers like private, protected, and public, we can restrict or allow access to the fields of a class.
  • Getter and Setter Methods: To provide controlled access to private data, getter and setter methods are used. These methods allow you to access or modify the private fields indirectly.
âš¡ Example of Data Hiding

In the following example, we use the private access modifier to hide the internal state (variables) of the class. We then use public getter and setter methods to control access to these variables.


class Person {
  // Private variables - data hiding
  private String name;
  private int age;
  
  // Public getter method to access the private variable 'name'
  public String getName() {
    return name;
  }
  
  // Public setter method to modify the private variable 'name'
  public void setName(String name) {
    this.name = name;
  }
  
  // Public getter method to access the private variable 'age'
  public int getAge() {
    return age;
  }
  
  // Public setter method to modify the private variable 'age'
  public void setAge(int age) {
    if(age > 0) {
      this.age = age;
    } else {
      System.out.println("Age cannot be negative or zero.");
    }
  }
}

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Person person = new Person();
    
    // Setting values using setter methods
    person.setName("John");
    person.setAge(25);
    
    // Accessing values using getter methods
    System.out.println("Name: " + person.getName());
    System.out.println("Age: " + person.getAge());
  }
}

In the above example: - The fields name and age are private, which means they cannot be accessed directly from outside the Person class. - The getName() and getAge() methods allow controlled access to the private fields, providing data hiding. - The setter method setAge() ensures that only valid values (positive age) can be set.

âš–ï¸ Benefits of Data Hiding
  • Control: Data hiding allows the class to control how its internal state is modified by providing validation through setter methods.
  • Security: By hiding the internal state, you prevent unauthorized or unintended modifications from outside the class.
  • Maintainability: Changes to the internal implementation of a class can be made without affecting other parts of the program, as long as the interface (getter/setter methods) remains the same.
ğŸš¦ When to Use Data Hiding
  • Use data hiding when you want to encapsulate the internal state of a class and provide controlled access to it.
  • Use getter and setter methods to expose specific fields when needed and apply any business logic or validation inside them.
  • Use private access for fields that should not be directly accessed or modified from outside the class.

ğŸ”„ What Happens When a Value is Overridden in HashMap?

In a `HashMap`, each key maps to exactly one value. If you put a value for a key that already exists in the map, the new value will override the old value associated with that key. This is because the key is unique, and each key can only hold one value at a time.

ğŸ¯ How HashMap Handles Overridden Values
  • When a new value is put for an existing key, the map removes the old value and replaces it with the new one.
  • HashMap does not store multiple values for the same key, so the old value is lost and replaced.
  • If you need to keep multiple values for the same key, you can use a `List` or `Set` as the value type.
âš¡ Example of Overriding Values in HashMap

import java.util.HashMap;

public class HashMapOverrideExample {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    HashMap map = new HashMap<>();

    // Put some initial values
    map.put("key1", "value1");
    map.put("key2", "value2");

    // Override value for "key1"
    map.put("key1", "newValue1");

    // Retrieve the overridden value
    String value = map.get("key1");

    System.out.println("The overridden value for key1: " + value); // Output: newValue1
  }
}

In this example: - Initially, the value for "key1" is set to "value1". - The second `put()` call overrides the value for "key1" with "newValue1". - Calling `map.get("key1")` returns "newValue1" because it was the last value associated with that key.

âš–ï¸ How to Retrieve the Overridden Value
