    private int count = 0;

    public void increment() {
        count++; // Not thread-safe
    }

    public int getCount() {
        return count;
    }
}

public class RaceConditionExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {
        Counter counter = new Counter();

        Thread t1 = new Thread(() -> {
            for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) counter.increment();
        });

        Thread t2 = new Thread(() -> {
            for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) counter.increment();
        });

        t1.start();
        t2.start();
        t1.join();
        t2.join();

        System.out.println("Final Count: " + counter.getCount()); // Expected: 2000, Actual: Less than 2000
    }
}

Even though 2000 increments are expected, due to race conditions, the actual count is often less.

âœ… Solution: Synchronization

public synchronized void increment() {
    count++;
}
ğŸ›  Alternative Solutions
  • Use Atomic Variables: AtomicInteger
  • Locks: ReentrantLock for advanced scenarios
  • Thread-safe Collections: ConcurrentHashMap, etc.
ğŸ§  Key Takeaways
  • Avoid shared mutable state across threads.
  • Always synchronize or use concurrency-safe constructs.
  • Race conditions are tricky to debug due to timing sensitivity.

ğŸ“Œ Traditional File Reading - BufferedReader

try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("data.txt"))) {
    String line;
    while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
        System.out.println(line);
    }
}

BufferedReader is efficient because it reads large chunks at a time and buffers the data internally, reducing disk access.

ğŸ“Œ Traditional File Writing - BufferedWriter

try (BufferedWriter writer = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("output.txt"))) {
    writer.write("Hello, World!");
    writer.newLine();
    writer.write("Java I/O is cool.");
}

BufferedWriter writes to the file efficiently by reducing the number of disk I/O operations.

ğŸ“¦ Using Java NIO (Non-blocking I/O)

Path path = Paths.get("data.txt");
List<String> lines = Files.readAllLines(path);
lines.forEach(System.out::println);

java.nio.file.Files offers utility methods to read/write files efficiently with fewer lines of code.


Path outputPath = Paths.get("output.txt");
Files.write(outputPath, Arrays.asList("Line 1", "Line 2"), StandardOpenOption.CREATE);
ğŸš€ For Very Large Files: Use Streams

try (Stream<String> stream = Files.lines(Paths.get("bigfile.txt"))) {
    stream.forEach(System.out::println);
}

This reads lines lazily and is memory-efficient, ideal for huge files.

âœ… Best Practices
  • Always close resources using try-with-resources.
  • Use buffering (BufferedReader/BufferedWriter) for performance.
  • Use Files.lines() or Streams for large files to avoid memory issues.
  • For multithreaded or async file operations, explore java.nio.channels.

ğŸ“Œ Problem with Exceptions in parallelStream()

When using parallelStream(), exceptions thrown inside the stream may be wrapped in a CompletionException or UncheckedExecutionException, making debugging tricky.

ğŸš« Without Handling

List<String> data = List.of("A", "B", null, "C");

data.parallelStream()
    .map(String::toLowerCase)  // Will throw NullPointerException
    .forEach(System.out::println);

This will crash with a NullPointerException.

âœ… Safe Handling with Wrapper

data.parallelStream()
    .map(item -> {
        try {
            return item.toLowerCase();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            System.err.println("Error processing: " + item);
            return "DEFAULT";
        }
    })
    .forEach(System.out::println);

Wrap the logic inside a try-catch to handle each element gracefully.

ğŸ” Using Utility Wrapper Function

public static <T, R> Function<T, R> safe(Function<T, R> function, R fallback) {
    return input -> {
        try {
            return function.apply(input);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            return fallback;
        }
    };
}

data.parallelStream()
    .map(safe(String::toLowerCase, "fallback"))
    .forEach(System.out::println);

Use reusable wrappers for cleaner code and better error management.

ğŸ’¡ Important Notes
  • Do not throw checked exceptions in lambdas without wrapping.
  • Use logging inside catch blocks to debug errors properly.
  • Use ExceptionUtils (from Apache Commons Lang) if you want more detailed stack traces.

ğŸ“Œ What Is synchronized(this)?

synchronized(this) synchronizes the block of code on the current instance of the object. It means **only one thread per object** can enter that block at a time.

ğŸ§  Example

public class Printer {
    public void print() {
        synchronized (this) {
            System.out.println("Thread " + Thread.currentThread().getName() + " is printing...");
            try {
                Thread.sleep(1000);
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
            }
            System.out.println("Thread " + Thread.currentThread().getName() + " finished printing.");
        }
    }
}

If multiple threads use the same instance of Printer, only one can enter the synchronized block at a time.

âœ… When Should You Use It?
  • When you're synchronizing access to a shared resource on a **per-object** basis.
  • If every thread has its own object, they won't block each other.
âš ï¸ Drawbacks
  • Can lead to performance bottlenecks if overused, since threads will block unnecessarily.
  • Not useful for static members â€” use synchronized(ClassName.class) instead for class-level locking.
ğŸ”„ Comparison

// Object-level lock
synchronized(this) {
    // only one thread per instance can enter
}

// Class-level lock
synchronized(Printer.class) {
    // only one thread for the entire class can enter
}

ğŸ” synchronized(this)

This applies a **lock on the current object instance**. Only one thread per instance can execute the synchronized block at a time. 


public class Printer {
    public void print() {
        synchronized(this) {
            System.out.println("Instance sync: " + Thread.currentThread().getName());
        }
    }
}
  • ğŸ”¸ Lock is instance-level (per object).
  • ğŸ”¸ Threads accessing different instances wonâ€™t block each other.
  • ğŸ”¸ Suitable for non-static data or behavior.
ğŸ” synchronized static methods or synchronized(ClassName.class)

Applies a **lock on the class's Class object**. All instances share this lock. 


public class Printer {
    public static synchronized void print() {
        System.out.println("Class-level sync: " + Thread.currentThread().getName());
    }
}
  • ğŸ”¹ Lock is class-level â€” one lock for all instances.
  • ğŸ”¹ If one thread is executing the static method, no other thread can access it even on a different object.
  • ğŸ”¹ Best for static data or global configuration.
ğŸ“Œ Summary
Aspect synchronized(this) synchronized static
Lock Type Instance Lock Class Lock
Scope Single Object All Objects of Class
Access Multiple threads can access other instances Only one thread across all instances
Use Case Non-static resource Static/shared resource

ğŸ’£ What is SQL Injection?
  • SQL Injection is a type of security vulnerability where an attacker injects malicious SQL statements into an applicationâ€™s input fields.
  • This allows the attacker to manipulate database queries, access unauthorized data, or even destroy the database.
âš ï¸ Vulnerable Example in Java

This example is vulnerable because it directly concatenates user input into the SQL query:


String username = request.getParameter("username");
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = '" + username + "'";

Statement stmt = connection.createStatement();
ResultSet rs = stmt.executeQuery(query);

Problem: If someone enters ' OR '1'='1 as username, it becomes:


SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = '' OR '1'='1'

This returns all users, bypassing authentication.

âœ… How to Prevent SQL Injection

Use PreparedStatement instead of string concatenation. It safely escapes user input:


String username = request.getParameter("username");
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = ?";
PreparedStatement pstmt = connection.prepareStatement(query);
pstmt.setString(1, username);
ResultSet rs = pstmt.executeQuery();
ğŸ” Best Practices to Prevent SQL Injection
  • âœ… Always use PreparedStatement or JPA/Hibernate
  • âŒ Never build SQL queries using string concatenation
  • âœ… Use ORM frameworks like Spring Data JPA
  • âœ… Validate and sanitize user inputs
  • âœ… Use stored procedures (with parameters)
  • âœ… Keep DB permissions minimal (least privilege)
ğŸ›¡ï¸ Spring Boot & JPA Are Safe by Default
  • If you're using Spring Data JPA and method naming like: 
    
User findByUsername(String username);
    then it is already safe against SQL injection.
ğŸ“Œ Summary
  • SQL Injection is dangerous â€” can expose or damage your DB.
  • It happens when user input is directly added to SQL queries.
  • Use PreparedStatements or JPA to stay safe.

ğŸ“Œ What is Covariant Return Type?
  • In Java, a covariant return type means that a method in a subclass can return a more specific type than the method it overrides in the parent class.
  • This feature was introduced in Java 5.
  • It improves code flexibility and allows better use of inheritance.
ğŸ§ª Simple Example

class Animal { }

class Dog extends Animal { }

class AnimalFactory {
    Animal getAnimal() {
        return new Animal();
    }
}

class DogFactory extends AnimalFactory {
    @Override
    Dog getAnimal() {
        return new Dog(); // âœ… Covariant return type
    }
}
ğŸ” Key Points
  • Both methods have the same name and parameters.
  • The return type in the subclass is a subtype of the return type in the parent class.
  • This avoids the need for casting and improves type safety.
âŒ Without Covariant Return

Before Java 5, you'd have to return the superclass and cast it:


Animal animal = dogFactory.getAnimal();
Dog dog = (Dog) animal; // Unsafe & ugly
âœ… With Covariant Return

No need for casting when you return subtype directly:


Dog dog = dogFactory.getAnimal(); // Clean & safe
ğŸ“Œ Where Itâ€™s Used
  • Overriding methods in inheritance hierarchy
  • Builder patterns or Factory patterns
  • Generic types (though theyâ€™re a separate concept)
ğŸ¯ Summary
  • Covariant return types allow overridden methods to return more specific types.
  • This leads to cleaner, safer, and more flexible code.
  • Java ensures type compatibility during compile time.

ğŸ” Default Tomcat Thread Configuration
  • Spring Boot 3 uses Apache Tomcat as the default embedded servlet container.
  • By default, Tomcat uses a thread pool to handle incoming HTTP requests.
  • Default thread settings in server.tomcat:

# Default values
server.tomcat.threads.max=200
server.tomcat.threads.min-spare=10
  • max-threads: The maximum number of request processing threads (default = 200)
  • min-spare-threads: Minimum number of threads always kept alive (default = 10)
ğŸ“ˆ What Happens When Concurrent Users Increase?
  • Each incoming HTTP request is handled by a thread from the Tomcat thread pool.
  • If all max-threads are busy, incoming requests are queued.
  • Tomcat uses an accept-count queue to hold incoming connections.
  • If the queue is also full, requests are rejected (HTTP 503).
ğŸ› ï¸ Customizing Tomcat Thread Pool

In application.properties or application.yml:


# Increase max threads and accept count
server.tomcat.threads.max=500
server.tomcat.threads.min-spare=50
server.tomcat.accept-count=200
ğŸ§  Important Concepts
  • max-threads: Total threads for serving requests
  • accept-count: Queue size for incoming requests waiting for a thread
  • min-spare-threads: Minimum threads available at all times
ğŸš€ Tips to Handle High Load
  • Use async processing (`@Async`, `WebFlux`) where possible
  • Optimize request handling logic and DB access
  • Use load balancers (e.g., Nginx) to distribute load
  • Monitor with tools like Spring Boot Actuator or Prometheus + Grafana
ğŸ“¦ Summary
  • Spring Boot 3's default max Tomcat threads = 200
  • You can increase threads using application.properties
  • If threads are full, requests wait in queue (accept-count)
  • More threads = more memory, so scale wisely

ğŸ” What is NGINX?
  • NGINX (pronounced â€œengine-xâ€) is a high-performance, open-source web server and reverse proxy server.
  • It is also used as a load balancer, HTTP cache, and media streaming server.
  • Popular due to its speed, low memory usage, and scalability.
ğŸ“¦ What Can NGINX Do?
  • ğŸŒ Serve static content (HTML, CSS, JS, images)
  • ğŸ” Act as a reverse proxy (forwards client requests to backend servers)
  • âš–ï¸ Load balancing (distribute traffic across multiple servers)
  • ğŸ”’ Handle SSL/TLS termination (HTTPS support)
  • ğŸ“¤ Caching (to reduce load on backend)
  • ğŸ” Act as a basic security layer (rate-limiting, IP blocking, etc.)
ğŸ› ï¸ Example: Spring Boot Behind NGINX

Suppose your Spring Boot app is running on port 8080:


server {
    listen 80;

    server_name myapp.com;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:8080;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
    }
}
ğŸš€ How NGINX Helps?
  • ğŸ” Reverse Proxy: Hides backend services and improves security
  • âš–ï¸ Load Balancer: Distributes load across multiple instances of your app
  • ğŸŒ Static File Hosting: Quickly serves frontend resources without hitting the backend
  • ğŸ§Š Caching: Speeds up repeated requests
  • ğŸ“‰ Reduces Backend Load: Only forwards necessary traffic
  • ğŸ” Secures Apps: Handles HTTPS and limits request rates
ğŸ“Œ When to Use NGINX?
  • When you're hosting a production Spring Boot or any backend app
  • To improve performance and scalability of your web services
  • To manage SSL certificates (HTTPS)
  • When you want to serve frontend + backend in one domain
ğŸ“Š Summary
  • NGINX is a powerful web server and reverse proxy.
  • It boosts performance, adds security, and helps scale applications.
  • Often used in modern production setups with Spring Boot, Node.js, React, etc.

ğŸ“Œ Reverse Proxy: The Concept
  • A Reverse Proxy is a server that sits between clients (e.g., browsers) and your backend servers (e.g., Spring Boot app).
  • It receives requests from clients and forwards them to the appropriate backend server.
  • It then sends the backend's response back to the client â€” the client doesn't know about the backend at all.
ğŸ” How It Works
Client --> Reverse Proxy (NGINX) --> Spring Boot App (port 8080)
  • Client sends request to http://myapp.com (NGINX)
  • NGINX forwards it to http://localhost:8080 (Spring Boot)
  • Spring Boot responds â†’ NGINX â†’ Client
ğŸ”’ Benefits of Using Reverse Proxy
  • ğŸ” Security: Backend app is not exposed to the internet
  • ğŸŒ SSL Termination: Handles HTTPS at NGINX, not app level
  • âš–ï¸ Load Balancing: NGINX can forward traffic to multiple app instances
  • ğŸ“¤ Caching: Frequently requested data can be cached at proxy level
  • ğŸ›¡ï¸ Rate Limiting: Protects your app from request floods
ğŸ§ª Example NGINX Config for Reverse Proxy

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name myapp.com;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:8080;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
    }
}
ğŸ“Š Summary
  • A reverse proxy like NGINX receives client requests and forwards them to a backend server.
  • It improves security, performance, and scalability.
  • Commonly used in front of Spring Boot, Node.js, Python Flask, etc.

ğŸ“Œ Overview
  • Yes, you can use React as the view layer in your Spring Boot application instead of Thymeleaf.
  • React is a modern front-end JavaScript library that allows for building rich, interactive Single Page Applications (SPAs), whereas Thymeleaf is a server-side templating engine.
ğŸ“Œ How to Integrate React with Spring Boot
  • Develop your React application as a standalone project. You can use tools like create-react-app to bootstrap your project.
  • Build your React app into static files (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) using npm run build.
  • Serve the static files by placing them in Spring Bootâ€™s src/main/resources/static folder or use a dedicated static file server (like NGINX) as a reverse proxy.
  • Use Spring Boot to expose RESTful APIs that your React app calls to fetch or update data.
ğŸ“Œ Benefits of Using React Over Thymeleaf
  • Rich User Experience: React enables highly interactive and dynamic UI experiences.
  • Client-Side Rendering: Offloads rendering logic to the client, potentially reducing server load.
  • Separation of Concerns: Clearly separates the front-end from the back-end, allowing teams to develop and deploy independently.
  • Modern Ecosystem: Reactâ€™s ecosystem with libraries like Redux, React Router, etc., provides extra tools for scaling complex applications.
ğŸ“Œ Deployment Options
  • Monolithic Deployment: Bundle the built React app as static resources inside your Spring Boot app.
  • Decoupled Deployment: Host the React app on a separate server or content delivery network (CDN) while keeping Spring Boot as a backend API provider.
ğŸ“Œ Summary
  • React can completely replace Thymeleaf for the front-end part of your Spring Boot 3 application.
  • This approach is especially ideal if you want to build a highly responsive SPA with a RESTful backend.
  • Choose between a monolithic or decoupled deployment based on your project needs.

ğŸ“Œ Goal

Integrate a React frontend with a Spring Boot 3 backend so that the frontend communicates via REST APIs.

ğŸ§± Project Structure
my-app/
â”œâ”€â”€ backend/         <-- Spring Boot App
â”œâ”€â”€ frontend/        <-- React App
ğŸ§ª Step 1: Create the Spring Boot App

Use Spring Initializr or your IDE to create a Spring Boot 3 app with dependencies:

  • Spring Web
  • Spring Boot DevTools
  • Spring Data JPA (optional)

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api")
public class GreetingController {
    
    @GetMapping("/greet")
    public String greet() {
        return "Hello from Spring Boot!";
    }
}
âš›ï¸ Step 2: Create the React App

In the root directory:

npx create-react-app frontend

Inside frontend/src/App.js:


import { useEffect, useState } from 'react';

function App() {
  const [message, setMessage] = useState("");

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch('/api/greet')
      .then(res => res.text())
      .then(data => setMessage(data));
  }, []);

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{message}</h1>
    </div>
  );
}

export default App;
âš™ï¸ Step 3: Configure Proxy in React

Edit frontend/package.json to proxy API requests to Spring Boot:


"proxy": "http://localhost:8080",
ğŸ—ï¸ Step 4: Build React and Copy to Spring Boot
  • Run: cd frontend && npm run build
  • Copy frontend/build contents to backend/src/main/resources/static
ğŸ§ª Step 5: Run Spring Boot
  • Start the Spring Boot app.
  • Open http://localhost:8080 and you'll see your React app served by Spring Boot!
ğŸš€ Bonus: Live Development (Optional)
  • Run React frontend with npm start
  • Run Spring Boot backend with mvn spring-boot:run
  • React will forward all API calls to Spring Boot via the proxy.
ğŸ“Š Summary
  • React and Spring Boot can be integrated via REST APIs.
  • Use proxy for development and serve static files in production.
  • This setup supports full-stack development with modern UI and robust backend.

ğŸ“Œ Introduction

Since Java 8, interfaces can contain two new types of methods:

  • default methods (with a default implementation)
  • static methods (interface-level utility methods)
ğŸŸ¦ Default Methods

Allow interfaces to have method implementations without breaking existing implementations of the interface.


public interface Vehicle {
    default void start() {
        System.out.println("Starting vehicle...");
    }
}

Key Uses:

  • Backward compatibility without forcing changes in all implementing classes
  • Add new functionality to an interface after it's released
ğŸ§  Real-Life Example

public interface NotificationService {
    void send(String message);

    default void log(String message) {
        System.out.println("LOG: " + message);
    }
}

public class EmailService implements NotificationService {
    public void send(String message) {
        System.out.println("Sending email: " + message);
    }
}

Output: Calls to log() will work without needing EmailService to override it.

ğŸŸ§ Static Methods

Static methods in interfaces are similar to utility methods â€” they belong to the interface, not instances.


public interface MathUtils {
    static int square(int x) {
        return x * x;
    }
}

Usage: MathUtils.square(5)

  • Called directly on the interface (not on implementing classes)
  • Cannot be overridden
ğŸ” Differences Summary
Feature Default Method Static Method
Where defined? In interface with default keyword In interface with static keyword
Accessed via Object of implementing class Interface name
Can override? âœ… Yes âŒ No
Use case Add new methods without breaking old code Utility/helper methods scoped to the interface
ğŸš¦ When to Use What?
  • Use default methods when adding new behavior to an existing interface.
  • Use static methods when you want utility/helper functionality inside the interface.
  • Donâ€™t misuse default methods â€” complex logic in interface is an anti-pattern.
âš ï¸ Notes
  • If a class implements two interfaces with same default method â†’ must override it to resolve conflict.
  • Both types were introduced in Java 8.
  • From Java 9 onward, private methods inside interfaces are also allowed (to help reuse in default/static).

ğŸ“Œ What is Varargs?

Varargs (Variable Arguments) in Java allows you to pass zero or more arguments to a method of the same type. It helps when the number of arguments is not known in advance.


public void printNames(String... names) {
    for (String name : names) {
        System.out.println(name);
    }
}

Usage: printNames("Hari", "Rama", "Krishna");

ğŸ“Œ How Varargs Works?
  • Varargs are treated internally as an array.
  • Only one vararg is allowed per method.
  • It must be the last parameter in the method signature.

public void demo(int id, String... tags) {
    // tags is actually String[]
}
ğŸ§ª How Many Ways Can We Use Varargs?
  • âœ… With primitive types: int... nums
  • âœ… With objects/wrappers: Integer... values, String... args
  • âŒ Cannot use two varargs in one method: method(String... a, Integer... b) â†’ âŒ Compile error
ğŸŸ© Example with Wrapper Class

public void addScores(Integer... scores) {
    int total = 0;
    for (Integer score : scores) {
        total += score;
    }
    System.out.println("Total: " + total);
}
ğŸŸ¨ Example with Primitive Type

public void multiplyAll(int... nums) {
    int product = 1;
    for (int n : nums) {
        product *= n;
    }
    System.out.println("Product: " + product);
}
ğŸ“ Can I Pass Arrays to Varargs?

Yes, both individual values and pre-defined arrays can be passed:


printNames("Ravi", "Teja");
String[] people = {"Hari", "Om"};
printNames(people); // âœ…
ğŸš« Common Mistakes to Avoid
  • Don't place varargs in the middle of parameters: method(String... names, int id) â†’ âŒ
  • Only one vararg per method is allowed
ğŸ“¦ Does it work with all wrapper classes?

âœ… Yes! Works with all wrapper classes like:

  • Integer... nums
  • Double... values
  • Boolean... flags
  • Character... chars
  • Long... ids
ğŸ¯ Summary
  • Use type... varName to allow flexible number of arguments.
  • Must be last in method params.
  • Works with all primitives and wrapper types.
  • Internally treated as arrays.

ğŸ“Œ The Question

Can you replace String[] args with String... args in the main() method?

âœ… Yes! Java fully supports it.

ğŸŸ¢ Valid Syntax

public class App {
    public static void main(String... args) {
        for (String arg : args) {
            System.out.println(arg);
        }
    }
}

Note: String[] args and String... args are treated the same.

ğŸ§  Why It Works
  • In Java, String... args is just syntactic sugar for String[] args.
  • At runtime, the JVM passes the arguments as a String array.
  • Java allows both array-style and vararg-style parameters for main.
ğŸ” JVM Rules for `main()`
  • public: must be accessible to JVM
  • static: no object needed to run
  • void: returns nothing
  • Parameter: String[] args or String... args
ğŸš« What is Not Allowed?

// âŒ Not allowed
public static void main(Integer... args) {}
public void main(String... args) {}
private static void main(String... args) {}
âœ… When to Use Varargs in Main?
  • Mostly stylistic choice â€” same behavior, just cleaner looking for some devs.
  • No special performance or functional benefit.
ğŸ“¦ Summary
  • String... args is a valid replacement for String[] args
  • Java treats both as an array of strings
  • JVM fully supports varargs form in the main method

ğŸ“Œ The Question

What are the data types in Java?

âœ… Answer:

Java has two types of data types:

  1. Primitive Data Types: These include byte, short, int, long, float, double, char, and boolean. They store simple values and are not objects.
  2. Non-Primitive Data Types: These include String, Array, Class, and Interface. They are derived from primitive data types and provide more functionalities.

ğŸ“Œ The Question

What are wrapper classes?

âœ… Answer:

Wrapper classes provide an object representation of primitive data types, such as Integers, Doubles, and Booleans. These classes allow primitives to be used in collections and provide useful utility methods.

ğŸ“Œ The Question

Are there dynamic arrays in Java?

âœ… Answer:

Java arrays are fixed in size. However, ArrayList (from the Java.util package) provides a dynamic array implementation where elements can be added or removed dynamically.

ğŸ“Œ The Question

What is JVM?

âœ… Answer:

The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is a part of the Java Runtime Environment (JRE). It is responsible for executing Java bytecode by converting it into machine code specific to the operating system.

Java has two types of data types:

ğŸ“Œ 1. Primitive Data Types

These include byte, short, int, long, float, double, char, and boolean. They store simple values and are not objects. 

        
          byte myByte = 100;
          short myShort = 32000;
          int myInt = 2147483647;
          long myLong = 9223372036854775807L;
          float myFloat = 3.14F;
          double myDouble = 3.14159265359;
          char myChar = 'A';
          boolean myBoolean = true;
ğŸ“Œ 2. Non-Primitive Data Types

These include String, Array, Class, and Interface. They are derived from primitive data types and provide more functionalities. 

        
          String myString = "Hello, World!";
          int[] myArray = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
          MyClass myObject = new MyClass();
          MyInterface myInterface;
âœ… Conclusion
  • Primitive: Basic types, store values directly.
  • Non-Primitive: Derived types, references to objects.

Wrapper classes provide an object representation of primitive data types.

These classes allow primitives to be used in collections and provide useful utility methods. 

        
          Integer myInt = 10;
          Double myDouble = 3.14;
          Boolean myBoolean = true;

          //Example of autoboxing and unboxing
          int a = myInt; //unboxing
          Integer b = 20; //autoboxing
âœ… Conclusion

Wrapper classes encapsulate primitive types into objects.

Java arrays are fixed in size. However, ArrayList provides dynamic array implementation.

ArrayList allows elements to be added or removed dynamically. 

        
          import java.util.ArrayList;

          public class ArrayListExample {

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  // Creating an ArrayList
                  ArrayList<String> fruits = new ArrayList<>();

                  // Adding elements to the ArrayList
                  fruits.add("Apple");
                  fruits.add("Banana");
                  fruits.add("Orange");

                  // Accessing elements
                  String firstFruit = fruits.get(0); // Access the first element (Apple)
                  System.out.println("First fruit: " + firstFruit);

                  // Modifying elements
                  fruits.set(1, "Grapes"); // Replace "Banana" with "Grapes"

                  // Removing elements
                  fruits.remove(2); // Remove the third element (Orange)

                  // Getting the size of the ArrayList
                  int size = fruits.size(); // Get the number of elements (2)
                  System.out.println("Size of ArrayList: " + size);

                  // Iterating through the ArrayList
                  System.out.println("Fruits in the ArrayList:");
                  for (String fruit : fruits) {
                      System.out.println(fruit);
                  }
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

ArrayList is used for dynamic arrays in Java.

JVM (Java Virtual Machine) is a part of JRE.

It executes Java bytecode by converting it into machine code. 

        
          // Java source code (.java file)
          public class Example {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  System.out.println("Hello, JVM!");
              }
          }

          // Compilation using javac
          // javac Example.java  (creates Example.class - bytecode)

          // Execution using java
          // java Example  (JVM executes the bytecode)
âœ… Conclusion

JVM is responsible for Java's platform independence.

Java achieves platform independence through bytecode.

The compiler converts code into bytecode, which the JVM interprets. 

        
          // Java source code (.java)
          public class HelloWorld {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  System.out.println("Hello, World!");
              }
          }

          // Compilation to bytecode (.class)
          // javac HelloWorld.java

          // Bytecode (simplified representation - actual bytecode is binary)
          // class HelloWorld {
          //   public static void main(String[] args) {
          //     System.out.println("Hello, World!");
          //   }
          // }

          // JVM interprets bytecode to machine code
âœ… Conclusion

Java's "write once, run anywhere" capability is due to bytecode.

Local variables are declared inside methods or blocks. Global variables are declared inside a class but outside any method.

ğŸ“Œ Local Variables

Accessible only within their scope. 

        
          public void myMethod() {
              int localVar = 10; // Local variable
              System.out.println(localVar);
          }
ğŸ“Œ Global Variables

Accessible throughout the class. Also known as instance variables. 

        
          public class MyClass {
              int globalVar = 20; // Global variable

              public void myMethod() {
                  System.out.println(globalVar);
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion
  • Local: Method/block scope.
  • Global: Class scope.

Encapsulation is bundling data and methods into a single unit (class).

It restricts direct access to data using access modifiers. 

        
          public class MyClass {
              private String name; // Private variable

              public String getName() { // Public getter method
                  return name;
              }

              public void setName(String newName) { // Public setter method
                  this.name = newName;
              }
          }

          MyClass obj = new MyClass();
          obj.setName("John");
          System.out.println(obj.getName());
âœ… Conclusion

Encapsulation helps in data hiding and controlled access.

Function overloading allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters.

The compiler differentiates them based on the number or type of parameters. 

        
          public class MyClass {
              public int add(int a, int b) {
                  return a + b;
              }

              public double add(double a, double b) {
                  return a + b;
              }

              public String add(String a, String b) {
                  return a + b;
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj = new MyClass();
                  System.out.println(obj.add(2, 3));
                  System.out.println(obj.add(2.5, 3.5));
                  System.out.println(obj.add("Hello ", "World"));
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Function overloading provides methods with the same name but different signatures.

Overriding allows a subclass to provide a specific implementation of a method defined in its superclass.

It enables dynamic method dispatch (runtime polymorphism). 

        
          class Animal {
              public void makeSound() {
                  System.out.println("Generic animal sound");
              }
          }

          class Dog extends Animal {
              @Override
              public void makeSound() {
                  System.out.println("Woof!");
              }
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Animal myAnimal = new Animal();
                  Animal myDog = new Dog();

                  myAnimal.makeSound(); // Outputs: Generic animal sound
                  myDog.makeSound();    // Outputs: Woof! (Overridden method)
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Function overriding provides a specific implementation of a superclass method in a subclass.

The main method is static so that it can be called without creating an instance of the class.

This allows the program to start execution without object instantiation. 

        
          public class MainClass {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  System.out.println("Main method executed");
              }
          }
          //No object creation needed to run main method
âœ… Conclusion

The main method is static for ease of execution.

"throw" is used to explicitly throw an exception, while "throws" declares that a method may throw an exception.

Feature throw throws
Purpose Used to explicitly throw an exception Declares that a method may throw an exception
Usage throw new Exception("Error") public void myMethod() throws IOException
Number of Exceptions Can throw one exception at a time Can declare multiple exceptions using commas 
        
          public void myMethod(int num) throws IOException {
              if (num < 0) {
                  throw new IOException("Number cannot be negative");
              }
              // ...
          }

          try {
              myMethod(-5);
          } catch (IOException e) {
              System.out.println(e.getMessage());
          }
âœ… Conclusion

"throw" initiates an exception; "throws" indicates potential exceptions.

An exception is an event that occurs during the execution of a program that disrupts the normal flow of instructions.

Java provides a robust and object-oriented way to handle exceptional conditions. 

        
          try {
              // Code that might throw an exception
              int result = 10 / 0; // ArithmeticException
          } catch (ArithmeticException e) {
              // Handle the exception
              System.out.println("Cannot divide by zero!");
          } finally {
              // Code that always executes (optional)
              System.out.println("Finally block");
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Exceptions are runtime errors handled by try-catch-finally blocks.

Exception handling is the process of responding to the occurrence of exceptions â€“ exceptional events â€“ during a computer program's execution.

It involves using try, catch, and finally blocks to manage exceptions. 

        
          try {
              // Code that might throw an exception
              int[] arr = new int[5];
              System.out.println(arr[10]); // ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
          } catch (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
              // Handle the specific exception
              System.out.println("Array index out of bounds");
          } catch (Exception e) {
              // Handle any other exception (general exception handler)
              System.out.println("An error occurred: " + e.getMessage());
          } finally {
              // Code that always executes
              System.out.println("Finally block executed");
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Exception handling ensures graceful program execution despite errors.

Java exceptions are primarily categorized into Checked Exceptions and Unchecked Exceptions.

  • Checked Exceptions: Exceptions that are checked by the compiler during compilation. They must be declared in the throws clause of a method or handled using try-catch blocks. Examples: IOException, SQLException.
  • Unchecked Exceptions: Exceptions that are not checked by the compiler. They typically occur due to programming errors. Examples: ArithmeticException, NullPointerException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
  • Errors: Irrecoverable conditions that should not be caught. Examples: OutOfMemoryError, StackOverflowError. 
        
          // Checked Exception Example
          import java.io.File;
          import java.io.FileReader;
          import java.io.IOException;

          public class CheckedExceptionExample {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  File file = new File("example.txt");
                  try {
                      FileReader reader = new FileReader(file);  // Checked Exception: IOException
                      // ...
                      reader.close();
                  } catch (IOException e) {
                      System.out.println("An IOException occurred: " + e.getMessage());
                  }
              }
          }

          // Unchecked Exception Example
          public class UncheckedExceptionExample {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  int[] numbers = {1, 2, 3};
                  try {
                      System.out.println(numbers[5]);  // Unchecked Exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
                  } catch (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
                      System.out.println("An ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException occurred: " + e.getMessage());
                  }
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Java exceptions are classified into Checked, Unchecked, and Errors.

The finally block is used to execute code that must run regardless of whether an exception is thrown or caught.

It is commonly used for cleanup operations like closing resources. 

        
          import java.io.*;

          public class FinallyBlockExample {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  BufferedReader reader = null;
                  try {
                      reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("input.txt"));
                      String line = reader.readLine();
                      System.out.println(line);
                  } catch (IOException e) {
                      System.out.println("An IOException occurred: " + e.getMessage());
                  } finally {
                      try {
                          if (reader != null) {
                              reader.close(); // Close the resource
                          }
                      } catch (IOException e) {
                          System.out.println("Error closing reader: " + e.getMessage());
                      }
                  }
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

The finally block ensures resource cleanup in exception handling.

Yes, a try block can have multiple catch blocks.

Each catch block handles a different type of exception. 

        
          public class MultipleCatchExample {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  try {
                      int[] numbers = {1, 2, 3};
                      System.out.println(numbers[5]);  // ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
                      int result = 10 / 0;             // ArithmeticException
                  } catch (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
                      System.out.println("ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: " + e.getMessage());
                  } catch (ArithmeticException e) {
                      System.out.println("ArithmeticException: " + e.getMessage());
                  } catch (Exception e) {
                      System.out.println("General Exception: " + e.getMessage());
                  }
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Multiple catch blocks allow handling different exceptions separately.

Method overriding is providing a different implementation of a method in a subclass that is already defined in its superclass.

It allows a subclass to provide its own behavior. 

        
          class Animal {
              public void makeSound() {
                  System.out.println("Generic animal sound");
              }
          }

          class Dog extends Animal {
              @Override
              public void makeSound() {
                  System.out.println("Woof!");
              }
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Animal animal = new Animal();
                  Animal dog = new Dog();

                  animal.makeSound(); // Outputs: Generic animal sound
                  dog.makeSound();    // Outputs: Woof! (Overridden method)
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Method overriding enables dynamic polymorphism.

Method overloading is defining multiple methods in the same class with the same name but different parameters.

It allows methods to perform similar actions with different input types. 

        
          public class Calculator {
              public int add(int a, int b) {
                  return a + b;
              }

              public double add(double a, double b) {
                  return a + b;
              }

              public String add(String a, String b) {
                  return a + b;
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Calculator calc = new Calculator();
                  System.out.println(calc.add(2, 3));
                  System.out.println(calc.add(2.5, 3.5));
                  System.out.println(calc.add("Hello ", "World"));
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Method overloading provides methods with the same name but different signatures.

Overriding is providing a different implementation in a subclass, while overloading is having multiple methods with the same name but different parameters in the same class.

Feature Method Overriding Method Overloading
Occurrence In different classes (Inheritance) In the same class
Parameters Same parameters Different parameters
Purpose Providing specific implementation Performing similar operations with different data
Binding Runtime (Dynamic) Compile-time (Static) 
        
          // Overriding Example (from Q17)
          class Animal {
              public void makeSound() { ... }
          }
          class Dog extends Animal {
              @Override
              public void makeSound() { ... }
          }

          // Overloading Example (from Q18)
          class Calculator {
              public int add(int a, int b) { ... }
              public double add(double a, double b) { ... }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Overriding and overloading are distinct polymorphism concepts.

An abstract class is a class that cannot be instantiated.

It may contain abstract methods (methods without implementation) and concrete methods (methods with implementation). 

        
          abstract class MyAbstractClass {
              public abstract void myAbstractMethod(); // Abstract method (no implementation)

              public void myConcreteMethod() { // Concrete method (with implementation)
                  System.out.println("Concrete method in abstract class");
              }
          }

          class MySubclass extends MyAbstractClass {
              @Override
              public void myAbstractMethod() {
                  System.out.println("Implementation of abstract method in subclass");
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MySubclass obj = new MySubclass();
                  obj.myAbstractMethod();
                  obj.myConcreteMethod();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Abstract classes define common behavior for subclasses but cannot be instantiated directly.

An interface is a completely abstract class that specifies a contract for classes to implement.

It contains only abstract methods (until Java 8, which introduced default and static methods) and constants. 

        
          interface MyInterface {
              void myMethod(); // Abstract method (implicitly public abstract)
              int myConstant = 10; // Constant (implicitly public static final)
          }

          class MyClass implements MyInterface {
              @Override
              public void myMethod() {
                  System.out.println("Implementation of myMethod in MyClass");
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj = new MyClass();
                  obj.myMethod();
                  System.out.println(MyInterface.myConstant);
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Interfaces define a contract for classes to adhere to.

Abstract classes and interfaces both define abstract methods, but they have key differences in their purpose and capabilities.

Feature Abstract Class Interface
Instantiation Cannot be instantiated Cannot be instantiated
Methods Can have abstract and concrete methods Only abstract methods (until Java 8)
Variables Can have any type of variables Only constants (public static final)
Inheritance A class can inherit from only one abstract class A class can implement multiple interfaces
Purpose To define common behavior for subclasses To define a contract for classes to adhere to 
        
          // Abstract Class Example
          abstract class MyAbstractClass {
              abstract void myMethod();
          }

          // Interface Example
          interface MyInterface {
              void myMethod();
          }

          class MyClass extends MyAbstractClass implements MyInterface {
              @Override
              public void myMethod() {
                  // Implementation
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Abstract classes are for inheritance of behavior, while interfaces are for defining contracts.

String, StringBuilder, and StringBuffer are used to represent and manipulate sequences of characters, but they differ in mutability and thread safety.

Feature String StringBuilder StringBuffer
Mutability Immutable Mutable Mutable
Thread Safety Thread-safe Not thread-safe Thread-safe
Performance Slow (for modifications) Fast Slightly slower than StringBuilder 
        
          String str = "Hello";
          str = str + " World"; // Creates a new String object

          StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder("Hello");
          sb.append(" World"); // Modifies the existing StringBuilder object

          StringBuffer sbuf = new StringBuffer("Hello");
          sbuf.append(" World"); // Modifies the existing StringBuffer object (thread-safe)
âœ… Conclusion

Use String for immutable text, StringBuilder for mutable non-thread-safe text, and StringBuffer for mutable thread-safe text.

final, finally, and finalize are keywords in Java, but they serve different purposes.

Keyword Purpose
final Used to declare constants, prevent method overriding, and prevent class inheritance.
finally A block in exception handling that always executes, regardless of whether an exception is thrown or caught.
finalize A method in the Object class that is called by the garbage collector before an object is reclaimed (deprecated in Java 9). 
        
          final int x = 10; // Constant variable

          class MyClass {
              final void myMethod() { // Cannot be overridden
                  // ...
              }
          }

          try {
              // ...
          } catch (Exception e) {
              // ...
          } finally {
              // Always executes
          }

          @Override
          protected void finalize() throws Throwable { // Deprecated
              // Cleanup code
          }
âœ… Conclusion

final is for constants/preventing overriding/inheritance, finally is for exception handling, and finalize is for garbage collection (deprecated).

Access modifiers control the visibility of classes, methods, and variables.

Java provides four access modifiers:

  • public: Accessible from any class.
  • protected: Accessible within the same package and by subclasses in other packages.
  • default (no modifier): Accessible only within the same package.
  • private: Accessible only within the same class. 
        
          public class MyClass {
              public int publicVar;
              protected int protectedVar;
              int defaultVar;
              private int privateVar;

              public void myPublicMethod() { ... }
              protected void myProtectedMethod() { ... }
              void myDefaultMethod() { ... }
              private void myPrivateMethod() { ... }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Access modifiers control the level of encapsulation and visibility.

A package is a mechanism to organize Java classes into namespaces.

It helps in preventing naming conflicts and makes it easier to locate, use, load, and control access to classes. 

        
          package com.example.myapp; // Package declaration

          public class MyClass {
              // ...
          }

          import com.example.myapp.MyClass; // Importing a class

          public class AnotherClass {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj = new MyClass();
                  // ...
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Packages organize classes and provide namespace management.

Packages offer several advantages in Java development.

  • Namespace Management: Prevents naming conflicts by grouping classes with the same name into different packages.
  • Code Organization: Helps in organizing related classes and interfaces, making it easier to manage large projects.
  • Access Control: Provides access control through access modifiers (like default and protected) to restrict access to classes and members within a package.
  • Code Reusability: Packages allow classes to be reused in other applications. 
        
          // Example of package organization
          com.example.myapp
          â”œâ”€â”€ ui
          â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.java
          â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ TextField.java
          â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Window.java
          â”œâ”€â”€ logic
          â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Calculator.java
          â”‚   â””â”€â”€ DataProcessor.java
          â””â”€â”€ db
              â””â”€â”€ DatabaseConnection.java
âœ… Conclusion

Packages improve code organization, prevent naming collisions, and enhance code reusability.

Checked exceptions are checked at compile-time, while unchecked exceptions are checked at runtime.

Feature Checked Exception Unchecked Exception
Checking Time Compile-time Runtime
Handling Must be handled using try-catch or declared using throws Not required to be handled
Inheritance Inherits from Exception class (excluding RuntimeException) Inherits from RuntimeException class
Examples IOException, SQLException ArithmeticException, NullPointerException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException 
        
          // Checked Exception Example
          import java.io.FileReader;
          import java.io.IOException;

          public class CheckedExceptionExample {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  try {
                      FileReader reader = new FileReader("file.txt"); // IOException
                      // ...
                      reader.close();
                  } catch (IOException e) {
                      System.out.println("IOException occurred");
                  }
              }
          }

          // Unchecked Exception Example
          public class UncheckedExceptionExample {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  int result = 10 / 0; // ArithmeticException
                  System.out.println(result);
              } // No try-catch or throws required
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Checked exceptions are mandatory to handle, while unchecked exceptions are not.

Serialization is the process of converting an object's state to a byte stream, while deserialization is the reverse process.

Serialization is used to save objects to storage or transmit them across a network. 

        
          import java.io.*;

          class MyClass implements Serializable {
              String data = "Hello";
          }

          public class SerializationExample {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  // Serialization
                  try (FileOutputStream fileOut = new FileOutputStream("temp.ser");
                       ObjectOutputStream out = new ObjectOutputStream(fileOut)) {
                      MyClass obj = new MyClass();
                      out.writeObject(obj);
                      System.out.println("Object serialized");
                  } catch (IOException i) {
                      i.printStackTrace();
                  }

                  // Deserialization
                  try (FileInputStream fileIn = new FileInputStream("temp.ser");
                       ObjectInputStream in = new ObjectInputStream(fileIn)) {
                      MyClass obj = (MyClass) in.readObject();
                      System.out.println("Object deserialized: " + obj.data);
                  } catch (IOException i) {
                      i.printStackTrace();
                  } catch (ClassNotFoundException c) {
                      System.out.println("MyClass not found");
                      c.printStackTrace();
                  } catch (IOException i) {
                      i.printStackTrace();
                  }
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Serialization converts objects to bytes, and deserialization reconstructs objects from bytes.

The static keyword is used to declare members that belong to the class itself rather than to any specific instance of the class.

Static members are shared among all instances of the class. 

        
          public class MyClass {
              static int count = 0; // Static variable
              static void myStaticMethod() { // Static method
                  System.out.println("Static method");
              }

              public MyClass() {
                  count++;
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj1 = new MyClass();
                  MyClass obj2 = new MyClass();
                  System.out.println("Object count: " + count); // Output: Object count: 2
                  MyClass.myStaticMethod(); // Calling static method using class name
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Static members are class-level and shared across objects.

Static variables belong to the class, while non-static variables belong to the instance (object) of the class.

Feature Static Variable Non-Static Variable
Belongs to Class Instance (Object)
Memory Allocation Only once, when the class is loaded Each instance gets its own copy
Access Accessed using class name Accessed using object reference
Sharing Shared among all instances Unique to each instance 
        
          public class MyClass {
              static int staticVar = 10; // Static variable
              int nonStaticVar = 20;    // Non-static variable

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  System.out.println(MyClass.staticVar); // Accessing static variable
                  MyClass obj1 = new MyClass();
                  MyClass obj2 = new MyClass();
                  obj1.nonStaticVar = 25;
                  obj2.nonStaticVar = 30;
                  System.out.println(obj1.nonStaticVar); // Accessing non-static variable
                  System.out.println(obj2.nonStaticVar);
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Static variables are class-level shared data, while non-static variables are object-specific data.

No, we cannot override a static method in Java.

Method overriding occurs at runtime, while static methods are resolved at compile time using the class type.

However, you can redefine (hide) a static method in a subclass. 

        
          class Superclass {
              public static void myStaticMethod() {
                  System.out.println("Static method in Superclass");
              }
          }

          class Subclass extends Superclass {
              public static void myStaticMethod() { // Method Hiding (not Overriding)
                  System.out.println("Static method in Subclass");
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Superclass.myStaticMethod(); // Output: Static method in Superclass
                  Subclass.myStaticMethod();  // Output: Static method in Subclass
                  Superclass obj = new Subclass();
                  obj.myStaticMethod(); // Output: Static method in Superclass (compile-time resolution)
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Static methods cannot be overridden, but they can be hidden.

The this keyword is a reference variable that refers to the current object.

It is used to:

  • Differentiate between instance variables and method parameters with the same name.
  • Call one constructor from another constructor of the same class (constructor chaining).
  • Return the current object from a method. 
        
          public class MyClass {
              private String name;
              private int age;

              public MyClass(String name, int age) {
                  this.name = name; // Differentiate instance variable and parameter
                  this.age = age;
              }

              public MyClass() {
                  this("Default Name", 0); // Constructor chaining
              }

              public MyClass getObject() {
                  return this; // Return current object
              }

              public void display() {
                  System.out.println("Name: " + name + ", Age: " + age);
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj1 = new MyClass("John", 30);
                  MyClass obj2 = new MyClass();
                  obj1.display();
                  obj2.display();
                  MyClass obj3 = obj1.getObject();
                  obj3.display();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

The this keyword provides a way to refer to the current object.

Constructor chaining is the process of calling one constructor from another constructor within the same class.

It is achieved using the this() keyword. 

        
          public class MyClass {
              private String name;
              private int age;
              private String city;

              public MyClass() {
                  this("Default Name", 0, "Default City");
                  System.out.println("Default Constructor");
              }

              public MyClass(String name, int age) {
                  this(name, age, "Default City");
                  System.out.println("Name and Age Constructor");
              }

              public MyClass(String name, int age, String city) {
                  this.name = name;
                  this.age = age;
                  this.city = city;
                  System.out.println("All Arguments Constructor");
              }

              public void display() {
                  System.out.println("Name: " + name + ", Age: " + age + ", City: " + city);
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj1 = new MyClass();
                  MyClass obj2 = new MyClass("John", 30);
                  MyClass obj3 = new MyClass("Jane", 25, "New York");

                  obj1.display();
                  obj2.display();
                  obj3.display();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Constructor chaining allows calling one constructor from another using this().

The super keyword is a reference variable that refers to the superclass (parent class) object.

It is used to:

  • Call the superclass constructor.
  • Access superclass members (methods and variables) when they are hidden (overridden) in the subclass. 
        
          class Superclass {
              String message = "Superclass Message";

              public Superclass() {
                  System.out.println("Superclass Constructor");
              }

              public void display() {
                  System.out.println(message);
              }
          }

          class Subclass extends Superclass {
              String message = "Subclass Message";

              public Subclass() {
                  super(); // Call superclass constructor
                  System.out.println("Subclass Constructor");
              }

              public void display() {
                  super.display(); // Call superclass method
                  System.out.println(super.message); // Access superclass variable
                  System.out.println(message);
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Subclass obj = new Subclass();
                  obj.display();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

The super keyword provides a way to access superclass members and constructors.

Inheritance is a mechanism where a new class (subclass or derived class) inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class (superclass or base class).

It promotes code reusability and establishes an IS-A relationship. 

        
          class Animal {
              String name;

              public Animal(String name) {
                  this.name = name;
              }

              public void eat() {
                  System.out.println(name + " is eating");
              }
          }

          class Dog extends Animal {
              public Dog(String name) {
                  super(name); // Call superclass constructor
              }

              public void bark() {
                  System.out.println(name + " is barking");
              }
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Dog myDog = new Dog("Buddy");
                  myDog.eat();
                  myDog.bark();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Inheritance allows creating new classes based on existing ones.

Java supports single, multilevel, and hierarchical inheritance. It does not support multiple inheritance directly (through classes) to avoid the "diamond problem," but it can be achieved through interfaces.

  • Single Inheritance: A class inherits from only one superclass.
  • Multilevel Inheritance: A class inherits from a class, which in turn inherits from another class.
  • Hierarchical Inheritance: Multiple classes inherit from a single superclass. 
        
          // Single Inheritance
          class Animal { ... }
          class Dog extends Animal { ... }

          // Multilevel Inheritance
          class Vehicle { ... }
          class Car extends Vehicle { ... }
          class SportsCar extends Car { ... }

          // Hierarchical Inheritance
          class Shape { ... }
          class Circle extends Shape { ... }
          class Rectangle extends Shape { ... }

          // Multiple Inheritance (via Interfaces)
          interface Drawable { ... }
          interface Movable { ... }
          class MyClass implements Drawable, Movable { ... }
âœ… Conclusion

Java supports different inheritance types, with interfaces providing a way to achieve multiple inheritance.

Polymorphism means "many forms." In Java, it allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common type.

It is achieved through method overloading and method overriding. 

        
          class Animal {
              public void makeSound() {
                  System.out.println("Generic animal sound");
              }
          }

          class Dog extends Animal {
              @Override
              public void makeSound() {
                  System.out.println("Woof!");
              }
          }

          class Cat extends Animal {
              @Override
              public void makeSound() {
                  System.out.println("Meow!");
              }
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Animal animal = new Animal();
                  Animal dog = new Dog();
                  Animal cat = new Cat();

                  animal.makeSound(); // Generic animal sound
                  dog.makeSound();    // Woof! (Overridden method)
                  cat.makeSound();    // Meow! (Overridden method)
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Polymorphism enables objects of different types to be treated as objects of a common type.

Compile-time polymorphism (method overloading) is resolved at compile time, while runtime polymorphism (method overriding) is resolved at runtime.

Feature Compile-time Polymorphism Runtime Polymorphism
Mechanism Method Overloading Method Overriding
Resolution Compile time Runtime
Binding Static binding Dynamic binding
Flexibility Less flexible More flexible
Speed Faster Slower 
        
          // Compile-time Polymorphism (Method Overloading)
          class Calculator {
              int add(int a, int b) { ... }
              double add(double a, double b) { ... }
          }

          // Runtime Polymorphism (Method Overriding)
          class Animal {
              void makeSound() { ... }
          }
          class Dog extends Animal {
              @Override
              void makeSound() { ... }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Compile-time is about method variations, and runtime is about method specialization.

An object is an instance of a class.

It has a state (data) and behavior (methods). 

        
          class Dog {
              String breed; // State
              int age;

              void bark() { // Behavior
                  System.out.println("Woof!");
              }
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Dog myDog = new Dog(); // Creating an object
                  myDog.breed = "Labrador";
                  myDog.age = 3;
                  myDog.bark();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Objects are instances of classes with state and behavior.

A class is a blueprint or template for creating objects.

It defines the properties (data members) and behaviors (methods) that objects of that class will have. 

        
          class Car {
              String model;
              String color;

              void accelerate() {
                  System.out.println("Car is accelerating");
              }
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Car myCar = new Car(); // Creating an object of class Car
                  myCar.model = "Sedan";
                  myCar.color = "Red";
                  myCar.accelerate();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

A class is a blueprint for creating objects with common properties and behaviors.

Constructors are special methods used to initialize objects.

They have the same name as the class and do not have a return type. 

        
          class Person {
              String name;
              int age;

              // Constructor
              Person(String n, int a) {
                  name = n;
                  age = a;
              }

              void display() {
                  System.out.println("Name: " + name + ", Age: " + age);
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Person person1 = new Person("John", 30); // Calling constructor
                  Person person2 = new Person("Jane", 25);
                  person1.display();
                  person2.display();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Constructors initialize objects when they are created.

The default constructor is a constructor provided by the Java compiler if no constructor is explicitly defined in the class.

It has no parameters and initializes instance variables with default values. 

        
          class MyClass {
              int x;
              String s;

              void display() {
                  System.out.println("x: " + x + ", s: " + s);
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj = new MyClass(); // Calling default constructor
                  obj.display(); // Output: x: 0, s: null
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

The default constructor is provided automatically if no constructor is defined.

A parameterized constructor is a constructor that accepts one or more parameters.

It is used to initialize objects with specific values. 

        
          class Student {
              String name;
              int rollNo;

              // Parameterized constructor
              Student(String n, int r) {
                  name = n;
                  rollNo = r;
              }

              void display() {
                  System.out.println("Name: " + name + ", Roll No: " + rollNo);
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Student student1 = new Student("Alice", 101); // Calling parameterized constructor
                  Student student2 = new Student("Bob", 102);
                  student1.display();
                  student2.display();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Parameterized constructors initialize objects with provided values.

Yes, a class can have multiple constructors.

This is known as constructor overloading, and it is a form of polymorphism. 

        
          class Box {
              double width;
              double height;
              double depth;

              // Constructor 1
              Box() {
                  width = 1;
                  height = 1;
                  depth = 1;
              }

              // Constructor 2
              Box(double w) {
                  width = w;
                  height = w;
                  depth = w;
              }

              // Constructor 3
              Box(double w, double h, double d) {
                  width = w;
                  height = h;
                  depth = d;
              }

              void displayVolume() {
                  System.out.println("Volume: " + (width * height * depth));
              }

              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Box box1 = new Box();
                  Box box2 = new Box(5);
                  Box box3 = new Box(5, 10, 15);

                  box1.displayVolume();
                  box2.displayVolume();
                  box3.displayVolume();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

Classes can have multiple constructors with different parameters (constructor overloading).

A class is a blueprint or template, while an object is an instance of that class.

A class defines the properties and behaviors, while an object is a specific entity with values for those properties.

Feature Class Object
Definition Blueprint or template Instance of a class
Memory No memory allocated Memory is allocated
Physical Existence Logical entity Physical entity
Example Car (blueprint) MyCar (specific car) 
        
          class Car { // Class
              String model;
              String color;

              void accelerate() { ... }
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  Car myCar = new Car(); // Object
                  myCar.model = "Sedan";
                  myCar.color = "Red";
                  myCar.accelerate();
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

A class is a blueprint, and an object is a realization of that blueprint.

The new keyword is used to create a new instance (object) of a class.

It allocates memory for the object and returns a reference to that memory location. 

        
          class MyClass {
              // ...
          }

          public class Main {
              public static void main(String[] args) {
                  MyClass obj = new MyClass(); // Creating an object using new
                  // ...
              }
          }
âœ… Conclusion

The new keyword is essential for creating objects in Java.

A class is a blueprint or template for creating objects.

It defines the properties (data members) and behaviors (methods) that objects of that class will have. 

          
            class Car {
                String model;
                String color;

                void accelerate() {
                    System.out.println("Car is accelerating");
                }
            }

            public class Main {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    Car myCar = new Car();
                    myCar.model = "Sedan";
                    myCar.color = "Red";
                    myCar.accelerate();
                }
            }

A class is a blueprint for creating objects with common properties and behaviors.

Constructors are special methods used to initialize objects.

They have the same name as the class and do not have a return type. 

          
            class Person {
                String name;
                int age;

                // Constructor
                Person(String n, int a) {
                    name = n;
                    age = a;
                }

                void display() {
                    System.out.println("Name: " + name + ", Age: " + age);
                }

                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    Person person1 = new Person("John", 30);
                    Person person2 = new Person("Jane", 25);
                    person1.display();
                    person2.display();
                }
            }

Constructors initialize objects when they are created.

The default constructor is a constructor provided by the Java compiler if no constructor is explicitly defined in the class.

It has no parameters and initializes instance variables with default values. 

          
            class MyClass {
                int x;
                String s;

                void display() {
                    System.out.println("x: " + x + ", s: " + s);
                }

                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    MyClass obj = new MyClass();
                    obj.display();
                }
            }

The default constructor is provided automatically if no constructor is defined.

A parameterized constructor is a constructor that accepts one or more parameters.

It is used to initialize objects with specific values. 

          
            class Student {
                String name;
                int rollNo;

                // Parameterized constructor
                Student(String n, int r) {
                    name = n;
                    rollNo = r;
                }

                void display() {
                    System.out.println("Name: " + name + ", Roll No: " + rollNo);
                }

                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    Student student1 = new Student("Alice", 101);
                    Student student2 = new Student("Bob", 102);
                    student1.display();
                    student2.display();
                }
            }

Parameterized constructors initialize objects with provided values.

Yes, a class can have multiple constructors.

This is known as constructor overloading, and it is a form of polymorphism. 

          
            class Box {
                double width;
                double height;
                double depth;

                // Constructor 1
                Box() {
                    width = 1;
                    height = 1;
                    depth = 1;
                }

                // Constructor 2
                Box(double w) {
                    width = w;
                    height = w;
                    depth = w;
                }

                // Constructor 3
                Box(double w, double h, double d) {
                    width = w;
                    height = h;
                    depth = d;
                }

                void displayVolume() {
                    System.out.println("Volume: " + (width * height * depth));
                }

                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    Box box1 = new Box();
                    Box box2 = new Box(5);
                    Box box3 = new Box(5, 10, 15);

                    box1.displayVolume();
                    box2.displayVolume();
                    box3.displayVolume();
                }
            }

Classes can have multiple constructors with different parameters (constructor overloading).

A class is a blueprint or template, while an object is an instance of that class.

A class defines the properties and behaviors, while an object is a specific entity with values for those properties.

Feature Class Object
Definition Blueprint or template Instance of a class
Memory No memory allocated Memory is allocated
Physical Existence Logical entity Physical entity
Example Car (blueprint) MyCar (specific car) 
          
            class Car {  // Class
                String model;
                String color;

                void accelerate() { ... }
            }

            public class Main {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    Car myCar = new Car();  // Object
                    myCar.model = "Sedan";
                    myCar.color = "Red";
                    myCar.accelerate();
                }
            }

A class is a blueprint, and an object is a realization of that blueprint.

The new keyword is used to create a new instance (object) of a class.

It allocates memory for the object and returns a reference to that memory location. 

          
            class MyClass {
                // ...
            }

            public class Main {
                public static void main(String[] args) {
                    MyClass obj = new MyClass();  // Creating an object using new
                    // ...
                }
            }

The new keyword is essential for creating objects in Java.

Arrays have a fixed size, while ArrayLists are dynamic and can grow or shrink in size.

Feature Array ArrayList
Size Fixed Dynamic
Type Can hold both primitives and objects Can only hold objects
Functionality Less built-in methods More built-in methods (e.g., add, remove)
Performance Generally faster for fixed-size operations Slightly slower due to dynamic resizing 
          
            // Array Example
            int[] arr = new int[5];  // Fixed size
            arr[0] = 10;
            arr[1] = 20;
