public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
    FileChannel channel = FileChannel.open(Paths.get("file.txt"));
    ByteBuffer buffer = ByteBuffer.allocate(1024);
    while (channel.read(buffer) > 0) {
        buffer.flip();
        while (buffer.hasRemaining()) {
            System.out.print((char) buffer.get());
        }
        buffer.clear();
    }
    channel.close();
}
}

Definition: CompletableFuture is part of Javaâ€™s concurrency framework that enables asynchronous programming.

  • Allows non-blocking, event-driven programming using callbacks.
  • Provides methods like thenApply(), thenAccept(), handle(), and whenComplete().
  • Can run tasks in parallel and combine multiple async operations.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture;

public class CompletableFutureExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> {
        System.out.println("Fetching data...");
        return "Hello, World!";
    }).thenApply(data -> {
        return data.toUpperCase();
    }).thenAccept(System.out::println);
}
}

Definition: The JVM provides multiple garbage collectors to manage memory efficiently.

  • Serial Garbage Collector: A simple GC that uses a single thread. Best suited for small applications.
  • Parallel Garbage Collector: Uses multiple threads for garbage collection, improving performance on multi-core systems.
  • CMS (Concurrent Mark-Sweep) Garbage Collector: Minimizes application pause time by performing most GC work concurrently.
  • G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector: Collects regions with the most garbage first, optimizing for low-latency applications.
  • Z Garbage Collector (ZGC): Low-latency, scalable garbage collector introduced in Java 11.
  • Shenandoah Garbage Collector: Designed to reduce pause times by running most of its work concurrently.

Example: Setting a Garbage Collector in JVM

// Using G1 GC
java -XX:+UseG1GC -jar myApp.jar

// Using ZGC (Java 11+)
java -XX:+UseZGC -jar myApp.jar

// Using Parallel GC
java -XX:+UseParallelGC -jar myApp.jar

Definition: Dependency Injection (DI) is a design pattern used to achieve **loose coupling** in software components.

  • Reduces Dependencies: Objects receive their dependencies from an external source instead of creating them internally.
  • Easier Testing: DI allows for better unit testing by injecting mock dependencies.
  • Enhances Maintainability: Changing dependencies doesnâ€™t require modifying existing classes.

Example: Constructor-based Dependency Injection in Spring

@Component
class Service {
public void serve() {
    System.out.println("Service is serving...");
}
}

@Component
class Client {
private final Service service;

@Autowired // Constructor-based DI
public Client(Service service) {
    this.service = service;
}

public void doWork() {
    service.serve();
}
}

@SpringBootApplication
public class DiExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    ApplicationContext context = SpringApplication.run(DiExample.class, args);
    Client client = context.getBean(Client.class);
    client.doWork();
}
}

Definition: The Stream API in Java 8 provides a functional approach for processing sequences of elements, supporting **filtering, mapping, reducing**, and **parallel execution**.

  • Sequential Streams: Process elements one by one in a single thread.
  • Parallel Streams: Split data into multiple chunks and process in parallel using the ForkJoin framework.
  • Immutable Operations: Stream operations do not modify the original collection.
  • Laziness: Streams are lazy; computations occur only when needed.

Example of Sequential Stream:

import java.util.List;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;
import java.util.Arrays;

public class StreamExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    List names = Arrays.asList("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "David");
    List filteredNames = names.stream()
                                      .filter(name -> name.startsWith("A"))
                                      .collect(Collectors.toList());
    System.out.println(filteredNames);
}
}

Example of Parallel Stream:

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Arrays;

public class ParallelStreamExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    List names = Arrays.asList("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "David");

    names.parallelStream()
         .forEach(name -> System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " - " + name));
}
}

Key Differences:

  • Performance: Parallel streams can improve performance for large datasets.
  • Threading: Sequential streams use a single thread, while parallel streams use **ForkJoinPool**.
  • Order: Sequential streams maintain order; parallel streams may not.
  • Use Case: Parallel streams are useful for CPU-intensive operations but should be used cautiously for small datasets.

Definition: Double-Checked Locking is used in the Singleton design pattern to **ensure lazy initialization** while maintaining **thread safety** and **performance efficiency**.

Why Use It?

  • Thread Safety: Ensures only one instance of the class is created in a multi-threaded environment.
  • Performance Optimization: Reduces unnecessary synchronization after the instance is created.
  • Lazy Initialization: The instance is created only when needed.

Implementation:

class Singleton {
private static volatile Singleton instance;

private Singleton() { } // Private constructor

public static Singleton getInstance() {
    if (instance == null) {  // First check (no locking)
        synchronized (Singleton.class) {  // Synchronize block
            if (instance == null) {  // Second check (with locking)
                instance = new Singleton();
            }
        }
    }
    return instance;
}
}

How It Works:

  • First Check: If `instance` is **null**, only then acquire the lock.
  • Synchronization Block: Ensures **only one thread** can create the instance.
  • Second Check: **Prevents multiple instantiations** when multiple threads are waiting.
  • volatile Keyword: Ensures visibility of changes across threads.

Advantages:

  • âœ… Ensures **only one instance** is created.
  • âœ… **Thread-safe** without performance bottlenecks.
  • âœ… **Lazy initialization** saves memory.

âš ï¸ Drawbacks:

  • âŒ Requires `volatile`, which is only supported in Java 5+.
  • âŒ Slightly complex compared to simpler Singleton implementations.

Definition: The volatile keyword in Java ensures that a variable's value is always read from and written to **main memory**, preventing **thread visibility issues**.

Why Use It?

  • Thread Visibility: Changes made by one thread **immediately reflect** in other threads.
  • Prevents Caching Issues: Without volatile, a thread may use an **outdated** cached value.
  • Used in Double-Checked Locking: Ensures proper instance visibility in Singleton pattern.

Example Without volatile (Incorrect Behavior):

class SharedData {
static boolean flag = false;

public static void main(String[] args) {
    new Thread(() -> {
        while (!flag) { } // Might run indefinitely due to caching
        System.out.println("Flag changed!");
    }).start();

    try { Thread.sleep(1000); } catch (InterruptedException e) { }
    flag = true; // Another thread may not see this update!
}
}

Corrected Example With volatile:

class SharedData {
static volatile boolean flag = false; // Volatile ensures visibility

public static void main(String[] args) {
    new Thread(() -> {
        while (!flag) { } // Now properly detects the change
        System.out.println("Flag changed!");
    }).start();

    try { Thread.sleep(1000); } catch (InterruptedException e) { }
    flag = true; // Now immediately visible to other threads
}
}

How It Works:

  • Without volatile: The value might be cached **per thread**, causing stale reads.
  • With volatile: The value is **always read from main memory**, ensuring correctness.

When to Use volatile?

  • âœ… When multiple threads **read and write** a shared variable.
  • âœ… When **no locking mechanism** (like `synchronized`) is used.
  • âœ… In **Double-Checked Locking for Singleton**.

âš ï¸ Limitations:

  • âŒ Does **not** provide **atomicity** for compound actions (like x++).
  • âŒ Use AtomicInteger or synchronized for operations requiring **atomicity**.

Key Point: Private methods **cannot be overridden** in Java because they are **not inherited** by subclasses.

How It Works:

  • Private methods belong only to the class where they are declared.
  • Subclass methods with the same name are considered separate methods (not overrides).
  • No compile-time or runtime error occurs, but itâ€™s method hiding, not overriding.

Example (Incorrect Override Attempt):

class Parent {
private void show() { 
    System.out.println("Parent's private show()"); 
}
}
class Child extends Parent {
void show() { 
    System.out.println("Child's show()"); 
}
}
public class Main {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    Parent p = new Child();
    p.show(); // âŒ Compilation Error: Cannot find show() in Parent
}
}

Corrected Example:

class Parent {
private void show() { 
    System.out.println("Parent's private show()"); 
}
}
class Child extends Parent {
void show() { // This is a new method, not overriding
    System.out.println("Child's show()");
}
}
public class Main {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    Child c = new Child();
    c.show(); // âœ… "Child's show()"
}
}

Why?

  • Private methods are not inherited, so overriding is not possible.
  • When a method with the same name exists in a subclass, it is method hiding, not overriding.

âš ï¸ Important Note:

  • âŒ Overriding private methods will **not work** because they are not accessible outside the class.
  • âœ… If you need inheritance, use protected instead of private.

Key Difference: Calling start() creates a new thread, while calling run() executes in the same thread.

Behavior of start() vs run():

  • start() - Creates a new thread: The JVM calls run() method in a separate thread.
  • run() - Executes in the same thread: The run() method runs like a normal method, without multithreading.

Example (Calling run() Instead of start()):

class MyThread extends Thread {
public void run() {
    System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " is running.");
}
}
public class Main {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    MyThread t1 = new MyThread();
    MyThread t2 = new MyThread();
    
    t1.run(); // âŒ Runs in main thread (No new thread created)
    t2.run(); // âŒ Runs in main thread
}
}

Corrected Example (Using start()):

class MyThread extends Thread {
public void run() {
    System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " is running.");
}
}
public class Main {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    MyThread t1 = new MyThread();
    MyThread t2 = new MyThread();
    
    t1.start(); // âœ… Runs in a new thread
    t2.start(); // âœ… Runs in a new thread
}
}

Output Comparison:

  • Calling run(): Runs sequentially in the main thread.
  • Calling start(): Runs in parallel using multiple threads.

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • âŒ Calling run() directly does NOT start a new thread.
  • âœ… Always use start() to create a new thread.

Definition: A lambda expression is a concise way to represent an anonymous function in Java.

Syntax:

(parameters) -> expression

Key Features:

  • âœ… Reduces boilerplate code for functional interfaces.
  • âœ… Improves readability and maintainability.
  • âœ… Introduced in Java 8 to support functional programming.

Example 1: Without Lambda (Before Java 8)

interface MyInterface {
void show();
}
public class Main {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    MyInterface obj = new MyInterface() {
        public void show() {
            System.out.println("Hello from Anonymous Class!");
        }
    };
    obj.show();
}
}

Example 2: With Lambda Expression (Java 8+)

interface MyInterface {
void show();
}
public class Main {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    MyInterface obj = () -> System.out.println("Hello from Lambda!");
    obj.show();
}
}

Example 3: Lambda with Parameters

interface MathOperation {
int operate(int a, int b);
}
public class Main {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    MathOperation sum = (a, b) -> a + b;
    System.out.println("Sum: " + sum.operate(5, 10));
}
}

Use Cases:

  • âœ… Used in functional interfaces (e.g., Runnable, Comparator, etc.).
  • âœ… Improves efficiency in collection processing with **Streams API**.
  • âœ… Helps in writing clean and concise event handlers.

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • Lambda expressions can only be used with **functional interfaces** (interfaces with a single abstract method).
  • They allow passing behavior as a parameter.
  • Useful for event handling, multithreading, and stream operations.

Definition: The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is the engine that runs Java applications by converting bytecode into machine code at runtime.

JVM Architecture:

  • ClassLoader: Loads .class files into memory.
  • Runtime Memory Areas: Stores data and program execution details.
  • Execution Engine: Converts bytecode into machine code.
  • Garbage Collector (GC): Reclaims memory from unused objects.

JVM Memory Structure:

  • Method Area: Stores class metadata, static variables, and runtime constants.
  • Heap: Stores objects and instance variables.
  • Stack: Stores method call frames, local variables, and return addresses.
  • PC Register: Holds the address of the current executing instruction.
  • Native Method Stack: Manages native method calls (non-Java code execution).

JVM Execution Process:

1. Source Code (.java) â†’ Compilation â†’ Bytecode (.class)
2. ClassLoader loads bytecode into JVM memory.
3. Just-In-Time (JIT) Compiler converts bytecode to native code.
4. Execution Engine runs the machine code.
5. Garbage Collector (GC) removes unused objects.

Example of JVM Memory Allocation:

public class JVMExample {
static int staticVar = 10; // Stored in Method Area
int instanceVar = 20; // Stored in Heap

public static void main(String[] args) {
    JVMExample obj = new JVMExample(); // Object stored in Heap
    int localVar = 30; // Stored in Stack
    System.out.println("JVM Internals Example");
}
}

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • JVM is platform-independent, but JVM implementations (HotSpot, OpenJ9) are platform-specific.
  • JIT compiler improves performance by converting frequently used bytecode into native code.
  • Garbage collection helps in memory management but can cause **Stop-the-World (STW) pauses**.

Definition: Functional Programming is a programming paradigm that treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions and avoids changing state and mutable data.

Key Concepts of Functional Programming:

  • Pure Functions: Functions that always return the same output for the same input and have no side effects.
  • Immutability: Data is never modified after creation; new objects are created instead.
  • Higher-Order Functions: Functions that take other functions as arguments or return functions.
  • Lambda Expressions: Short, concise functions that can be used as arguments to methods.
  • Stream API: A powerful feature for processing collections in a functional way.

Example of Functional Programming with Lambda Expressions:

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;

public class FunctionalExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4, 5);
    
    // Using Stream API and Lambda to filter and print even numbers
    numbers.stream()
           .filter(n -> n % 2 == 0)
           .forEach(System.out::println);
}
}

Example of Higher-Order Function:

import java.util.function.Function;

public class HigherOrderFunction {
static int applyFunction(int x, Function<Integer, Integer> func) {
    return func.apply(x);
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    Function<Integer, Integer> square = n -> n * n;
    System.out.println(applyFunction(5, square)); // Output: 25
}
}

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • Functional programming leads to **cleaner, more concise, and bug-resistant code**.
  • Javaâ€™s `Function`, `Predicate`, and `Consumer` interfaces in `java.util.function` package support functional programming.
  • Streams allow **lazy evaluation**, improving performance in large data processing.

Definition: Serialization in Java is the process of converting an object into a byte stream to save it to a file, send over a network, or store in a database.

Key Concepts of Serialization:

  • Serializable Interface: Java provides `java.io.Serializable` to mark a class as serializable.
  • transient Keyword: Fields marked as `transient` are not serialized.
  • serialVersionUID: Used to ensure object compatibility during deserialization.
  • ObjectInputStream and ObjectOutputStream: Used for reading/writing serialized objects.

Example of Serialization:

import java.io.*;

class Person implements Serializable {
private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
String name;
transient int age; // This field will not be serialized

public Person(String name, int age) {
    this.name = name;
    this.age = age;
}
}

public class SerializationExample {
public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    Person p = new Person("John", 30);

    // Serialize the object
    ObjectOutputStream out = new ObjectOutputStream(new FileOutputStream("person.ser"));
    out.writeObject(p);
    out.close();

    // Deserialize the object
    ObjectInputStream in = new ObjectInputStream(new FileInputStream("person.ser"));
    Person deserializedPerson = (Person) in.readObject();
    in.close();

    System.out.println("Name: " + deserializedPerson.name + ", Age: " + deserializedPerson.age);
}
}

Alternatives to Java Serialization:

  • JSON (Jackson, Gson): Serialize objects to JSON format for better readability and cross-platform support.
  • XML (JAXB): Convert objects to XML format for structured data exchange.
  • Kryo: A high-performance serialization framework faster than Java's default serialization.
  • Protocol Buffers (Protobuf): Googleâ€™s efficient serialization format for structured data.

Example of JSON Serialization using Jackson:

import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper;

class Employee {
public String name;
public int age;
}

public class JsonExample {
public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    Employee emp = new Employee();
    emp.name = "Alice";
    emp.age = 28;

    ObjectMapper mapper = new ObjectMapper();
    String json = mapper.writeValueAsString(emp);
    System.out.println(json);
}
}

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • Java serialization is **slow and not secure**. Prefer alternatives like **JSON, XML, or Protobuf**.
  • When using serialization, always declare `serialVersionUID` to avoid compatibility issues.
  • Consider using **transient** keyword for sensitive data like passwords.

Definition: Java Design Patterns are well-defined solutions to common programming problems. They follow best practices and improve code reusability, maintainability, and scalability.

Types of Design Patterns:

  • Creational Patterns: Deal with object creation (e.g., Singleton, Factory, Builder).
  • Structural Patterns: Focus on class and object composition (e.g., Adapter, Composite, Decorator).
  • Behavioral Patterns: Define communication between objects (e.g., Observer, Strategy, Command).

Example 1: Singleton Pattern (Ensures only one instance of a class exists)

class Singleton {
private static Singleton instance;

private Singleton() {} // Private constructor

public static Singleton getInstance() {
    if (instance == null) {
        instance = new Singleton();
    }
    return instance;
}

public void showMessage() {
    System.out.println("Singleton Instance Created");
}
}

public class SingletonExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    Singleton obj = Singleton.getInstance();
    obj.showMessage();
}
}

Example 2: Factory Pattern (Used to create objects without specifying their exact class)

interface Shape {
void draw();
}

class Circle implements Shape {
public void draw() { System.out.println("Drawing Circle"); }
}

class Square implements Shape {
public void draw() { System.out.println("Drawing Square"); }
}

class ShapeFactory {
public static Shape getShape(String type) {
    if (type.equalsIgnoreCase("CIRCLE")) return new Circle();
    if (type.equalsIgnoreCase("SQUARE")) return new Square();
    return null;
}
}

public class FactoryExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    Shape shape1 = ShapeFactory.getShape("CIRCLE");
    shape1.draw();
}
}

Example 3: Observer Pattern (Used to notify multiple objects when the state changes)

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

interface Observer {
void update(String message);
}

class Subscriber implements Observer {
private String name;

public Subscriber(String name) { this.name = name; }

public void update(String message) {
    System.out.println(name + " received: " + message);
}
}

class Publisher {
private List observers = new ArrayList<>();

public void subscribe(Observer observer) {
    observers.add(observer);
}

public void notifySubscribers(String message) {
    for (Observer observer : observers) {
        observer.update(message);
    }
}
}

public class ObserverExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    Publisher publisher = new Publisher();
    Observer sub1 = new Subscriber("User1");
    Observer sub2 = new Subscriber("User2");

    publisher.subscribe(sub1);
    publisher.subscribe(sub2);

    publisher.notifySubscribers("New Video Uploaded!");
}
}

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • Design patterns help in writing cleaner, more structured code.
  • Singleton ensures a class has only one instance.
  • Factory Pattern helps in object creation without exposing logic.
  • Observer Pattern is useful in event-driven programming.

Definition: A ClassLoader in Java is responsible for loading classes into memory at runtime.

Types of Class Loaders in Java 8 and Later:

  • Bootstrap ClassLoader: Loads core Java classes from $JAVA_HOME/lib (e.g., java.lang.String).
  • Platform ClassLoader (Extension ClassLoader in Java 7): Loads classes from $JAVA_HOME/lib/ext or java.ext.dirs.
  • Application (System) ClassLoader: Loads classes from the application's classpath (CLASSPATH environment variable).
  • Custom ClassLoader: A user-defined class loader for dynamically loading classes.

Example: Getting Class Loader Details

public class ClassLoaderExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    // Get ClassLoader of this class
    ClassLoader classLoader = ClassLoaderExample.class.getClassLoader();
    System.out.println("Application ClassLoader: " + classLoader);

    // Get the parent of Application ClassLoader (Platform ClassLoader)
    System.out.println("Platform ClassLoader: " + classLoader.getParent());

    // Get the parent of Platform ClassLoader (Bootstrap ClassLoader)
    System.out.println("Bootstrap ClassLoader: " + classLoader.getParent().getParent());
}
}

Example: Custom ClassLoader

import java.io.*;

class CustomClassLoader extends ClassLoader {
public Class<?> findClass(String name) throws ClassNotFoundException {
    byte[] data = loadClassData(name);
    return defineClass(name, data, 0, data.length);
}

private byte[] loadClassData(String name) {
    // Load the class data from a file or other source
    return new byte[0]; // Dummy implementation
}
}

public class CustomClassLoaderTest {
public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    CustomClassLoader loader = new CustomClassLoader();
    Class<?> myClass = loader.findClass("MyClass");
    System.out.println("Class Loaded: " + myClass.getName());
}
}

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • Java 9+ introduced Module Class Loaders for better encapsulation.
  • Bootstrap ClassLoader is written in native code and doesn't have a parent.
  • Custom ClassLoaders allow dynamic class loading from non-standard sources.

Definition: Swapping two strings without using a third variable can be done using string concatenation and substring operations.

Example:

public class SwapStrings {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    String a = "Hello";
    String b = "World";

    System.out.println("Before Swap: a = " + a + ", b = " + b);

    // Swapping logic
    a = a + b;  // Step 1: Concatenate both strings
    b = a.substring(0, a.length() - b.length()); // Step 2: Extract original 'a'
    a = a.substring(b.length()); // Step 3: Extract original 'b'

    System.out.println("After Swap: a = " + a + ", b = " + b);
}
}

Explanation:

  • First, concatenate a and b.
  • Then, extract the original value of a from the concatenated string.
  • Finally, extract the original value of b.

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • This method works because strings are immutable in Java, and substring operations create new string objects.
  • It avoids the use of a third variable but temporarily increases memory usage due to string concatenation.

Definition: serialVersionUID is a unique identifier used for Java object serialization and deserialization.

Why is it needed?

  • Ensures version compatibility between serialized and deserialized objects.
  • Prevents InvalidClassException when class structure changes.
  • Acts as a version control mechanism for Serializable classes.

Example:

import java.io.Serializable;

public class Employee implements Serializable {
private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L; // Unique identifier for serialization

private String name;
private int age;

public Employee(String name, int age) {
    this.name = name;
    this.age = age;
}
}

Explanation:

  • If a class implements Serializable but doesn't define serialVersionUID, JVM generates one automatically.
  • Generated UID changes when the class structure is modified, causing deserialization issues.
  • Defining serialVersionUID manually ensures consistent object deserialization.

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • Changing serialVersionUID invalidates previously serialized objects.
  • Always update serialVersionUID if modifying the class structure significantly.
  • Use serialver tool to generate consistent UID values.

Definition: serialVersionUID should be used in Java classes implementing Serializable to ensure smooth deserialization across different versions.

When to Use It?

  • When a class is designed to be Serializable and will be saved/loaded frequently.
  • When you need backward compatibility between different versions of your class.
  • If your class structure is expected to evolve over time.
  • When working with distributed systems that exchange serialized objects.
  • When using caching frameworks like Hibernate, Redis, or Java Caching System.

Example:

import java.io.Serializable;

public class User implements Serializable {
private static final long serialVersionUID = 123456789L; // Defined manually for version control

private String username;
private String email;

public User(String username, String email) {
    this.username = username;
    this.email = email;
}
}

Why is This Important?

  • Without serialVersionUID, Java generates one dynamically, which may change when the class is modified.
  • Using an explicit serialVersionUID ensures old serialized objects remain valid after code updates.
  • Prevents InvalidClassException during deserialization.

âš ï¸ Important Notes:

  • If you change class structure (add/remove fields), update serialVersionUID to reflect the changes.
  • Use the serialver tool to generate a consistent UID.
  • For temporary objects, serialVersionUID is not necessary.

Definition: Drools is a Business Rules Management System (BRMS) that allows developers to separate business logic from application code using rule-based decision-making.

Key Features:

  • Uses a forward-chaining inference engine to evaluate rules.
  • Follows the Rete algorithm for efficient rule execution.
  • Supports Decision Tables, Rule Flows, and Templates.
  • Integrates with Java applications and enterprise systems.
  • Can be used for fraud detection, risk assessment, and automated workflows.

Example:

// Sample Drools Rule File (DRL)
rule "Discount for Gold Members"
when
    Customer(membership == "GOLD", totalPurchase > 5000)
then
    System.out.println("Applying 10% discount for GOLD member.");
end

How It Works?

  • Rules are written in Drools Rule Language (DRL) and executed by the Drools engine.
  • The engine evaluates conditions and triggers actions when conditions are met.
  • Useful in scenarios where business rules frequently change.

âš ï¸ When to Use Drools?

  • For complex decision-making based on multiple conditions.
  • When business logic needs to be updated frequently without modifying Java code.
  • To maintain separation of business rules and application logic.

Definition: Drools can be integrated into a Spring Boot application to apply business rules dynamically.

Steps to Integrate:

  • Add Drools Dependencies in pom.xml.
  • Configure KieSession for rule execution.
  • Write DRL Files to define business rules.
  • Execute Rules in a Spring Boot service.

1ï¸âƒ£ Add Dependencies:

<dependency>
<groupId>org.kie</groupId>
<artifactId>drools-core</artifactId>
<version>8.x.x</version>
</dependency>
<dependency>
<groupId>org.kie</groupId>
<artifactId>kie-spring</artifactId>
<version>8.x.x</version>
</dependency>

2ï¸âƒ£ Configure Drools in Spring Boot:

@Configuration
public class DroolsConfig {
@Bean
public KieContainer kieContainer() {
    return KieServices.Factory.get().getKieClasspathContainer();
}

@Bean
public KieSession kieSession(KieContainer kieContainer) {
    return kieContainer.newKieSession();
}
}

3ï¸âƒ£ Create a DRL File (rules.drl):

package com.example.rules

rule "Discount for Premium Users"
when
    Customer(membership == "PREMIUM", totalPurchase > 10000)
then
    System.out.println("Applying 20% discount for PREMIUM users.");
end

4ï¸âƒ£ Execute Rules in a Spring Service:

@Service
public class DiscountService {
@Autowired
private KieSession kieSession;

public void applyDiscount(Customer customer) {
    kieSession.insert(customer);
    kieSession.fireAllRules();
}
}

5ï¸âƒ£ Test the Integration:

public static void main(String[] args) {
ApplicationContext context = SpringApplication.run(App.class, args);
DiscountService service = context.getBean(DiscountService.class);
Customer customer = new Customer("John", "PREMIUM", 15000);
service.applyDiscount(customer);
}

âš ï¸ Notes:

  • Ensure rules.drl is inside resources folder.
  • Drools uses KieSession to execute rules.
  • Spring Boot simplifies rule execution using dependency injection.

Definition: JVM (Java Virtual Machine) is responsible for running Java programs by converting bytecode into machine code at runtime.

1ï¸âƒ£ JVM Architecture:

  • Class Loader: Loads classes into memory.
  • Runtime Memory Areas: Includes heap, stack, method area, and others.
  • Execution Engine: Converts bytecode into machine code.
  • Garbage Collector: Frees unused memory automatically.

2ï¸âƒ£ JVM Memory Model:

  • Heap: Stores objects and class instances.
  • Stack: Stores method-specific data such as local variables.
  • Method Area: Stores class metadata and static variables.
  • Native Method Stack: Stores native (non-Java) method references.
  • PC Register: Holds the address of the current executing instruction.

3ï¸âƒ£ JVM Garbage Collection (GC):

  • Serial GC: Best for single-threaded applications.
  • Parallel GC: Uses multiple threads for garbage collection.
  • G1 GC (Garbage First): Balances latency and throughput.
  • ZGC & Shenandoah GC: Designed for low-latency applications.

4ï¸âƒ£ JVM Performance Tuning:

  • Adjust Heap Size: Use -Xms and -Xmx to configure memory limits.
  • Enable GC Logging: Use -XX:+PrintGCDetails for insights.
  • Use JIT Compiler: Just-In-Time (JIT) optimizes execution.
  • Monitor with Tools: Use JVisualVM, JConsole, and JFR.

5ï¸âƒ£ JVM Performance Monitoring Tools:

1ï¸âƒ£ jstat - Monitor JVM statistics.
2ï¸âƒ£ jmap - Analyze memory usage.
3ï¸âƒ£ jconsole - GUI-based JVM monitoring.
4ï¸âƒ£ jvisualvm - Advanced profiling tool.
5ï¸âƒ£ jcmd - Send diagnostic commands to JVM.

6ï¸âƒ£ Example: Setting JVM Parameters

java -Xms512m -Xmx2g -XX:+UseG1GC -XX:+PrintGCDetails -jar myapp.jar

âš ï¸ Notes:

  • Use -Xms and -Xmx wisely to prevent frequent GC.
  • Monitor memory leaks using jmap and heap dumps.
  • Choose an appropriate GC strategy based on application needs.

Definition: JVM (Java Virtual Machine) is an abstract machine that provides a runtime environment to execute Java applications. It converts bytecode into machine code for execution.

Key Components of JVM:

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ Class Loader: Loads bytecode (.class files) into JVM memory.
  • 2ï¸âƒ£ Runtime Memory Areas: Stores program data during execution.
  • 3ï¸âƒ£ Execution Engine: Converts bytecode into machine-specific code.
  • 4ï¸âƒ£ Garbage Collector: Reclaims memory occupied by unreferenced objects.
  • 5ï¸âƒ£ Native Interface: Enables interaction with native libraries.

1ï¸âƒ£ Class Loader Subsystem:

  • Loads and verifies classes dynamically at runtime.
  • Types:
    • Bootstrap ClassLoader: Loads core Java classes from rt.jar.
    • Extension ClassLoader: Loads classes from lib/ext folder.
    • Application ClassLoader: Loads user-defined classes.

2ï¸âƒ£ JVM Memory Areas:

  • Heap: Stores objects and class instances.
  • Stack: Stores method-specific data and local variables.
  • Method Area: Stores class metadata and static variables.
  • Native Method Stack: Stores native (non-Java) method references.
  • PC Register: Holds the address of the current executing instruction.

3ï¸âƒ£ Execution Engine:

  • Converts bytecode into machine code for execution.
  • Components:
    • Interpreter: Executes bytecode line-by-line (slower).
    • JIT (Just-In-Time) Compiler: Optimizes frequently used code for faster execution.
    • Garbage Collector: Frees unused memory.

4ï¸âƒ£ Garbage Collection (GC):

  • Automatically manages memory by deallocating unused objects.
  • Types of GC:
    • Serial GC: Best for small applications.
    • Parallel GC: Uses multiple threads for efficiency.
    • G1 GC: Balances throughput and latency.
    • ZGC & Shenandoah: Low-latency garbage collectors.

5ï¸âƒ£ Native Interface:

  • Allows Java to call native (C/C++) code using JNI (Java Native Interface).

JVM Workflow:

1ï¸âƒ£ Java source code (.java) â†’ Compilation â†’ Bytecode (.class)
2ï¸âƒ£ Bytecode â†’ Class Loader â†’ JVM Memory
3ï¸âƒ£ Execution Engine â†’ Interpreter / JIT Compiler â†’ Machine Code
4ï¸âƒ£ Program Execution with Garbage Collection Handling

âš ï¸ Notes:

  • JVM enables platform independence through bytecode execution.
  • Performance tuning can be done using JVM arguments and profiling tools.
  • Garbage Collection strategies impact application performance.

Definition: The JVM divides memory into different areas to manage execution efficiently. These memory areas are responsible for storing classes, objects, methods, and execution data.

JVM Memory Areas:

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ Method Area: Stores class metadata, static variables, and method code.
  • 2ï¸âƒ£ Heap: Stores objects and instance variables.
  • 3ï¸âƒ£ Stack: Stores method execution frames (local variables, partial results).
  • 4ï¸âƒ£ Program Counter (PC) Register: Holds the address of the current executing instruction.
  • 5ï¸âƒ£ Native Method Stack: Stores native (non-Java) method references.

1ï¸âƒ£ Method Area:

  • Stores class structure (fields, methods, constant pool).
  • Contains static variables and method bytecode.
  • Shared among all threads.

2ï¸âƒ£ Heap:

  • Stores objects and instance variables.
  • Divided into **Young Generation (Eden, Survivor)** and **Old Generation**.
  • Garbage Collector manages memory deallocation.

3ï¸âƒ£ Stack:

  • Stores method execution data (local variables, return values).
  • Each thread has its own stack.
  • Contains multiple **stack frames**, one for each method call.

4ï¸âƒ£ Program Counter (PC) Register:

  • Holds the address of the currently executing bytecode instruction.
  • Each thread has its own PC Register.

5ï¸âƒ£ Native Method Stack:

  • Stores information about native (C/C++) method calls.
  • Used when interacting with system libraries via JNI (Java Native Interface).

JVM Memory Structure Diagram:

âš ï¸ Notes:

  • Garbage Collection mainly operates in the Heap.
  • Stack memory is limited and can cause **StackOverflowError** if too many recursive calls occur.
  • Proper memory management is crucial for application performance.

Definition: A memory leak occurs when objects are no longer needed but are still referenced, preventing garbage collection.

Common Causes of Memory Leaks:

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ Unclosed Resources: Failure to close streams, database connections, or sockets.
  • 2ï¸âƒ£ Static References: Objects stored in static fields remain in memory.
  • 3ï¸âƒ£ Improper Collection Usage: Holding unnecessary objects in **Lists, Maps, or Sets**.
  • 4ï¸âƒ£ Inner Classes: Non-static inner classes holding a reference to the outer class.
  • 5ï¸âƒ£ Listeners & Callbacks: Unregistered event listeners preventing object deallocation.

How to Detect Memory Leaks?

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ Java Profilers: Use tools like VisualVM, JProfiler, and Java Mission Control.
  • 2ï¸âƒ£ Heap Dumps: Generate heap dumps using jmap and analyze them with **Eclipse MAT (Memory Analyzer Tool)**.
  • 3ï¸âƒ£ GC Logs: Enable **Garbage Collection (GC) Logs** to identify objects not being collected.
  • 4ï¸âƒ£ Weak References: Use **WeakReference** for objects that should be garbage-collected.
  • 5ï¸âƒ£ Code Analysis: Static analysis tools like FindBugs and SonarQube detect potential memory leaks.

Example: Detecting Memory Leaks Using VisualVM

// Enable GC logs for analysis
java -XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps -Xloggc:gc.log -jar MyApp.jar

// Capture heap dump when memory is nearly full
jmap -dump:live,format=b,file=heapdump.hprof <PID>

// Analyze heap dump using Eclipse MAT

âš ï¸ Prevention Tips:

  • Always **close resources** (files, DB connections) in try-with-resources.
  • Avoid **static references** that hold large objects.
  • Use **WeakReference** for cache-like scenarios.
  • Monitor memory usage with **profiling tools** regularly.

Definition: Metaspace is the new memory space introduced in Java 8 to store class metadata, replacing the older PermGen (Permanent Generation).

Why Was PermGen Removed?

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ Fixed Size Limitation: PermGen had a fixed maximum size, leading to OutOfMemoryError: PermGen space.
  • 2ï¸âƒ£ Complex Garbage Collection: GC tuning was required to manage PermGen, making it inefficient.
  • 3ï¸âƒ£ ClassLoader Issues: In dynamic applications (like Tomcat), frequent class loading/unloading led to memory leaks.

Key Differences Between Metaspace and PermGen:

Feature Metaspace (Java 8+) PermGen (Before Java 8)
Memory Allocation Uses **native (off-heap) memory** Allocated on **JVM heap**
Size Limit Dynamic (grows automatically) Fixed (configured via -XX:MaxPermSize)
Garbage Collection More efficient and automatic Required manual tuning
OutOfMemoryError Occurs when native memory is exhausted OutOfMemoryError: PermGen space if exceeded

Configuring Metaspace:

// Set initial Metaspace size (default: unlimited)
-XX:MetaspaceSize=128M

// Set max Metaspace size (limits native memory usage)
-XX:MaxMetaspaceSize=256M

// Enable GC logging for Metaspace monitoring
-XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCDateStamps -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps

âš ï¸ Key Takeaways:

  • **Metaspace is more flexible** and does not require a fixed size like PermGen.
  • **GC tuning is easier** as Metaspace dynamically adjusts memory allocation.
  • Still requires **proper monitoring** to avoid excessive native memory usage.

Definition: JVM performance tuning involves optimizing memory management, garbage collection, and threading to ensure efficient application performance under high load.

1ï¸âƒ£ Key Areas for JVM Performance Tuning:

  • Heap Size Tuning: Adjust heap size to prevent excessive GC pauses.
  • Garbage Collection (GC) Optimization: Choose the right GC algorithm based on workload.
  • Thread and Concurrency Tuning: Optimize thread pools for efficient task execution.
  • JIT Compiler Optimizations: Use Just-In-Time (JIT) compiler tuning for better performance.
  • Monitoring and Profiling: Use tools like JVisualVM, JFR, and GC logs for analysis.

2ï¸âƒ£ JVM Heap Size Tuning:

// Set minimum and maximum heap size
-Xms2G -Xmx4G

// Enable G1 GC and configure its heap regions
-XX:+UseG1GC -XX:InitiatingHeapOccupancyPercent=45

// Enable GC logs for monitoring
-XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCDateStamps -Xloggc:gc.log

3ï¸âƒ£ Choosing the Right Garbage Collector (GC):

GC Algorithm Best For JVM Option
Serial GC Single-threaded, low-memory apps -XX:+UseSerialGC
Parallel GC High CPU, batch processing -XX:+UseParallelGC
G1 GC Low-latency, balanced workloads -XX:+UseG1GC
ZGC Ultra-low latency (millisecond pauses) -XX:+UseZGC

4ï¸âƒ£ Threading and Concurrency Tuning:

  • Use Thread Pools: Avoid creating too many threads dynamically.
  • Tune ForkJoinPool: For parallel tasks, set the right parallelism level.
  • Monitor Thread Contention: Use jstack to analyze thread dumps.

5ï¸âƒ£ Monitoring & Profiling Tools:

  • JVisualVM: Monitors CPU, memory, and threads in real time.
  • Java Flight Recorder (JFR): Low-overhead profiling tool.
  • GC Logs: Analyzes garbage collection behavior.

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Test JVM tuning changes in a staging environment before production.
  • Use profiling tools to identify bottlenecks before tuning blindly.
  • Choose the right GC algorithm based on latency and throughput needs.

Definition: The default heap size in Java depends on the JVM and the available system memory. It is dynamically determined at runtime.

1ï¸âƒ£ Default Heap Size:

  • For **32-bit JVM:** Around 256MB initial and 1GB max.
  • For **64-bit JVM:** Initial 1/64th of physical memory, max 1/4th of RAM.
  • Exact values can be checked using:
java -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal | grep HeapSize

2ï¸âƒ£ How to Modify Heap Size:

  • Set Initial Heap Size: -Xms (e.g., -Xms512m)
  • Set Maximum Heap Size: -Xmx (e.g., -Xmx2G)
  • Example: Setting heap size to 2GB:
java -Xms512m -Xmx2G MyApp

3ï¸âƒ£ Tuning Heap for Performance:

Parameter Purpose Example
-Xms Initial heap size -Xms1G
-Xmx Maximum heap size -Xmx4G
-XX:NewRatio Sets ratio of young to old generation -XX:NewRatio=2
-XX:SurvivorRatio Sets survivor space ratio -XX:SurvivorRatio=8

4ï¸âƒ£ Checking Heap Usage at Runtime:

  • Using JConsole: GUI-based heap monitoring tool.
  • Using jstat: CLI-based real-time heap monitoring.
  • Example Command:
jstat -gc  1000

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Adjust heap size based on application workload and available memory.
  • Monitor GC logs to avoid excessive pauses.
  • Use -XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError to debug memory issues.

Definition: Profiling and debugging tools help monitor JVM performance, detect memory leaks, optimize CPU usage, and analyze garbage collection (GC) behavior.

1ï¸âƒ£ Popular JVM Profiling & Debugging Tools:

  • JConsole: GUI-based monitoring tool for real-time JVM performance.
  • VisualVM: Analyzes heap dumps, threads, and CPU usage.
  • JProfiler: Commercial tool for deep JVM performance analysis.
  • YourKit: Advanced CPU & memory profiling with a user-friendly UI.
  • Eclipse MAT (Memory Analyzer Tool): Finds memory leaks and optimizes heap usage.

2ï¸âƒ£ Command-Line JVM Monitoring Tools:

Tool Purpose Example Command
jstat Monitor GC and memory stats jstat -gc 1000
jmap Dump heap memory jmap -dump:live,format=b,file=heap.bin
jstack Analyze thread dumps jstack
jcmd Send diagnostic commands jcmd VM.flags

3ï¸âƒ£ How to Profile a Java Application?

  • Using VisualVM:
    • jvisualvm
  • Using JProfiler:
    • java -agentpath:/path/to/jprofiler -jar MyApp.jar
  • Using Flight Recorder (JFR):
    • java -XX:+FlightRecorder -XX:StartFlightRecording=duration=60s MyApp

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Use **JConsole** for quick real-time monitoring.
  • Analyze **heap dumps** with Eclipse MAT to find memory leaks.
  • Use **jstat** and **jcmd** to monitor GC and optimize heap.
  • Use **Flight Recorder** for lightweight profiling in production.

Definition: Hibernate provides caching mechanisms to improve application performance by reducing database hits. There are two main cache levels: **First Level Cache** and **Second Level Cache**.

1ï¸âƒ£ First Level Cache:

  • Enabled by default. Works at the **Session** level.
  • Stores entities in the session memory.
  • Cleared when the session is closed.
  • Helps reduce duplicate database queries within the same session.

Example of First Level Cache:

// First Level Cache Example
Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Employee emp1 = session.get(Employee.class, 101); // Hits DB
Employee emp2 = session.get(Employee.class, 101); // Returns from cache (No DB hit)
session.close();

2ï¸âƒ£ Second Level Cache:

  • Not enabled by default. Works at the **SessionFactory** level.
  • Stores entities across multiple sessions.
  • Needs external providers like **EhCache, Hazelcast, or Infinispan**.
  • Reduces database hits for frequently accessed data.

How to Enable Second Level Cache?

// Step 1: Add dependency for EhCache
<dependency>
<groupId>org.hibernate</groupId>
<artifactId>hibernate-ehcache</artifactId>
<version>5.4.0.Final</version>
</dependency>

// Step 2: Configure Hibernate
hibernate.cache.use_second_level_cache=true
hibernate.cache.region.factory_class=org.hibernate.cache.ehcache.EhCacheRegionFactory

// Step 3: Enable caching in Entity
@Cacheable
@Cache(usage = CacheConcurrencyStrategy.READ_WRITE)
@Entity
public class Employee {
@Id
private int id;
private String name;
}

3ï¸âƒ£ Key Differences:

Feature First Level Cache Second Level Cache
Scope Session level SessionFactory level
Enabled by Default? Yes No
Storage Only for one session Across multiple sessions
External Configuration Not required Required (EhCache, Infinispan, etc.)
Use Case Reduces duplicate DB hits within a session Improves performance across multiple sessions

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Use **First Level Cache** for session-based optimizations.
  • Enable **Second Level Cache** for frequently accessed entities.
  • Choose the right caching strategy (**READ_ONLY, NONSTRICT_READ_WRITE, etc.**).
  • Monitor cache performance using profiling tools.

Definition: Lazy Loading and Eager Loading are two fetching strategies in Hibernate that determine when related entities are loaded from the database.

1ï¸âƒ£ Lazy Loading:

  • Default behavior in Hibernate.
  • Associated entities are not loaded immediately; they are loaded **only when accessed**.
  • Improves performance by loading data **on demand**.
  • Can cause **LazyInitializationException** if accessed outside session scope.

Example of Lazy Loading:

@Entity
public class Employee {
@Id
private int id;
private String name;

@OneToMany(mappedBy = "employee", fetch = FetchType.LAZY) // Lazy Loading
private List<Task> tasks;
}

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Employee emp = session.get(Employee.class, 1); // Tasks are NOT loaded yet
session.close();
System.out.println(emp.getTasks()); // âŒ Throws LazyInitializationException

2ï¸âƒ£ Eager Loading:

  • Loads associated entities immediately.
  • Uses **JOIN queries** to fetch all data in a single SQL statement.
  • Can cause **performance issues** if fetching large datasets unnecessarily.

Example of Eager Loading:

@Entity
public class Employee {
@Id
private int id;
private String name;

@OneToMany(mappedBy = "employee", fetch = FetchType.EAGER) // Eager Loading
private List<Task> tasks;
}

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Employee emp = session.get(Employee.class, 1); // Tasks are also loaded immediately
session.close();
System.out.println(emp.getTasks()); // âœ… No exception

3ï¸âƒ£ Key Differences:

Feature Lazy Loading Eager Loading
Fetching Strategy Loads data only when needed Loads all data immediately
Performance Better for large datasets May cause performance issues
SQL Query Executes separate queries when accessing associations Executes a single query with JOINs
Risk of Exception May throw LazyInitializationException No exception
Best Use Case When associated data is rarely needed When associated data is frequently needed

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Use **Lazy Loading** by default and fetch associations only when required.
  • Use **JOIN FETCH queries** to avoid LazyInitializationException.
  • Avoid **Eager Loading** for large data sets to prevent performance issues.

Definition: The Criteria API in Hibernate is used to create **dynamic, type-safe queries** programmatically without writing raw SQL or HQL.

1ï¸âƒ£ Why Use Criteria API?

  • Provides a **type-safe and flexible** way to create queries.
  • Avoids SQL injection as it generates queries dynamically.
  • Useful for **complex queries with multiple conditions**.
  • Works well when query conditions are **built dynamically at runtime**.

2ï¸âƒ£ Example: Basic Criteria Query

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
CriteriaBuilder cb = session.getCriteriaBuilder();
CriteriaQuery<Employee> cq = cb.createQuery(Employee.class);
Root<Employee> root = cq.from(Employee.class);
cq.select(root);
Query<Employee> query = session.createQuery(cq);
List<Employee> employees = query.getResultList();
session.close();

3ï¸âƒ£ Applying Filters (WHERE Clause)

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
CriteriaBuilder cb = session.getCriteriaBuilder();
CriteriaQuery<Employee> cq = cb.createQuery(Employee.class);
Root<Employee> root = cq.from(Employee.class);
cq.select(root).where(cb.equal(root.get("department"), "IT"));
Query<Employee> query = session.createQuery(cq);
List<Employee> employees = query.getResultList();
session.close();

4ï¸âƒ£ Criteria API vs HQL

Feature Criteria API HQL
Query Type Dynamic & Programmatic Static & String-based
Readability Better for complex queries Harder to maintain for large queries
Performance Depends on query complexity Generally faster for simple queries
Type Safety Yes (Prevents runtime errors) No (Prone to runtime errors)

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Use **Criteria API** when building queries dynamically at runtime.
  • Use **HQL** when queries are static and performance is critical.
  • Combine **pagination** with Criteria API for better efficiency.

Definition: The @NamedQuery annotation in Hibernate is used to define **predefined, reusable HQL queries** at the entity level.

1ï¸âƒ£ Why Use @NamedQuery?

  • Improves **code reusability** by defining queries once at the entity level.
  • Enhances **performance** since queries are compiled at startup.
  • Makes the code **cleaner and easier to manage**.

2ï¸âƒ£ Example: Defining @NamedQuery

@Entity
@NamedQuery(name = "Employee.findByDepartment", 
        query = "SELECT e FROM Employee e WHERE e.department = :dept")
public class Employee {
@Id
@GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
private Long id;
private String name;
private String department;
}

3ï¸âƒ£ Executing @NamedQuery in Hibernate

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Query<Employee> query = session.createNamedQuery("Employee.findByDepartment", Employee.class);
query.setParameter("dept", "IT");
List<Employee> employees = query.getResultList();
session.close();

4ï¸âƒ£ Multiple Named Queries in @NamedQueries

@Entity
@NamedQueries({
@NamedQuery(name = "Employee.findByName", query = "SELECT e FROM Employee e WHERE e.name = :name"),
@NamedQuery(name = "Employee.findAll", query = "SELECT e FROM Employee e")
})
public class Employee {
@Id
@GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
private Long id;
private String name;
private String department;
}

5ï¸âƒ£ Benefits of @NamedQuery

Feature @NamedQuery Dynamic HQL
Performance Faster (Precompiled at startup) Slower (Compiled at runtime)
Code Reusability Yes, defined at the entity level No, needs to be written repeatedly
Readability Improved (Defined once in the entity) Harder to manage in large projects
Maintainability Easy (Centralized query management) Complex (Scattered across codebase)

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Use @NamedQuery for **frequently used, static queries**.
  • Avoid it when queries **need dynamic conditions** (Use Criteria API instead).
  • Keep query names **consistent and meaningful** for better readability.

Definition: These methods are used for **inserting and updating entities** in Hibernate, but they have different behaviors.

1ï¸âƒ£ Difference Between save(), persist(), and merge()

Method Session or EntityManager Behavior Return Type Transaction Required?
save() Session Inserts a new record, assigns an identifier immediately. Serializable (ID) No (Executes immediately)
persist() EntityManager Makes entity managed but delays insert until commit. void Yes (Requires transaction)
merge() EntityManager Updates or inserts the entity (if detached). Managed entity Yes

2ï¸âƒ£ Example: Using save() (Works in Hibernate 6)

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Transaction tx = session.beginTransaction();
Employee emp = new Employee();
emp.setName("John");
Serializable id = session.save(emp); // Immediately assigns ID
tx.commit();
session.close();

3ï¸âƒ£ Example: Using persist() (Recommended in Hibernate 6 with JPA)

EntityManager entityManager = entityManagerFactory.createEntityManager();
entityManager.getTransaction().begin();
Employee emp = new Employee();
emp.setName("Alice");
entityManager.persist(emp); // Insert happens at commit
entityManager.getTransaction().commit();
entityManager.close();

4ï¸âƒ£ Example: Using merge() (For updating detached entities)

EntityManager entityManager = entityManagerFactory.createEntityManager();
entityManager.getTransaction().begin();
Employee emp = entityManager.find(Employee.class, 1L); // Fetch existing entity
entityManager.detach(emp); // Make it detached
emp.setName("Updated Name");
Employee mergedEmp = entityManager.merge(emp); // Updates entity
entityManager.getTransaction().commit();
entityManager.close();

âš ï¸ Changes in Hibernate 6:

  • save() is still supported but generally replaced by **persist()** in JPA-based applications.
  • persist() is **preferred** in Hibernate 6 when using JPA EntityManager.
  • merge() is still necessary for updating **detached entities**.
  • **session.update()** has been **deprecated** in favor of merge().

ğŸ›  Best Practices:

  • Use persist() when working with **new entities** in a managed transaction.
  • Use merge() when you need to **update a detached entity**.
  • Use save() only when working with **Hibernate Session** directly (not recommended in JPA).

Definition: Hibernate manages transactions internally using **JDBC transactions, JTA (Java Transaction API), or a custom transaction manager**.

1ï¸âƒ£ Hibernate Transaction Management Workflow:

  • Hibernate uses the Transaction interface to **begin, commit, or rollback** transactions.
  • By default, Hibernate transactions are **auto-commit disabled**, requiring explicit commit.
  • It supports **JDBC transactions**, **JTA transactions**, and **Spring-managed transactions**.
  • Each transaction is bound to a **Session**, and multiple operations within the session participate in the same transaction.

2ï¸âƒ£ Example: Hibernate Transaction with JDBC

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Transaction tx = null;
try {
tx = session.beginTransaction();
Employee emp = new Employee();
emp.setName("John Doe");
session.save(emp);
tx.commit(); // âœ… Commit transaction
} catch (Exception e) {
if (tx != null) tx.rollback(); // âŒ Rollback on failure
e.printStackTrace();
} finally {
session.close();
}

3ï¸âƒ£ Example: Hibernate with Spring Transaction Management

@Service
public class EmployeeService {
@Autowired
private EntityManager entityManager;

@Transactional // Spring manages transaction automatically
public void saveEmployee(Employee emp) {
    entityManager.persist(emp); // Insert happens within the transaction
}
}

âš ï¸ Key Points:

  • By default, **each Session manages its own transaction**.
  • If an exception occurs, Hibernate **automatically rolls back** the transaction if `commit()` is not called.
  • When using **Spring**, transactions are handled via `@Transactional`, and Spring manages commits and rollbacks.
  • In JTA (Java EE applications), Hibernate works with **distributed transactions** across multiple databases.

ğŸ›  Best Practices:

  • Always use **transactions** when performing database operations.
  • Prefer @Transactional when using **Spring Boot** for simplified transaction management.
  • Use **try-catch-finally** to handle transaction rollback manually in plain Hibernate.
  • Avoid **long-running transactions**, as they can cause performance issues and lock database resources.

Definition: Hibernate performance tuning involves optimizing queries, caching, and session management to improve efficiency in high-load applications.

1ï¸âƒ£ Enable Hibernate Caching:

  • Use **First-Level Cache (Session Cache)** â€“ Enabled by default.
  • Use **Second-Level Cache (EhCache, Caffeine, Infinispan, etc.)** for frequently accessed data.
  • Enable **Query Cache** to avoid repeated execution of the same queries.

2ï¸âƒ£ Optimize Hibernate Queries:

  • Use **JOIN FETCH** instead of multiple separate queries.
  • Avoid **N+1 Query Problem** using **@BatchSize** or **JOIN FETCH**.
  • Use **pagination (setMaxResults, setFirstResult)** for large datasets.

3ï¸âƒ£ Use Connection Pooling:

  • Use **HikariCP** or **Apache DBCP** for efficient connection pooling.
  • Ensure the database connection pool is properly sized to handle concurrent requests.

4ï¸âƒ£ Enable Batch Processing:

  • Batch inserts/updates using **JDBC batching** (`hibernate.jdbc.batch_size`).
  • Flush and clear the session periodically to avoid memory overload.

5ï¸âƒ£ Lazy Loading vs Eager Loading:

  • Use **Lazy Loading (`fetch = FetchType.LAZY`)** to load data only when required.
  • Use **Eager Loading (`fetch = FetchType.EAGER`)** cautiously for frequently accessed relationships.

6ï¸âƒ£ Example: Batch Processing in Hibernate

Session session = sessionFactory.openSession();
Transaction tx = session.beginTransaction();
for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
Employee emp = new Employee("Employee " + i);
session.save(emp);
if (i % 50 == 0) { // âœ… Flush & clear every 50 inserts
    session.flush();
    session.clear();
}
}
tx.commit();
session.close();

7ï¸âƒ£ Example: Connection Pooling with HikariCP

spring.datasource.hikari.minimumIdle=10
spring.datasource.hikari.maximumPoolSize=50
spring.datasource.hikari.idleTimeout=30000
spring.datasource.hikari.maxLifetime=1800000

âš ï¸ Key Points:

  • Use **caching** wisely to reduce database calls.
  • Avoid **loading large datasets into memory**, use pagination.
  • Optimize **batch processing** for bulk operations.
  • Monitor Hibernate queries with **SQL logs & performance profiling tools**.

ğŸ›  Best Practices:

  • Use **@Transactional** effectively to manage transactions.
  • Avoid unnecessary **Session open/close operations** inside loops.
  • Use **Indexes in the database** to optimize query execution.
  • Regularly monitor **Hibernate statistics & slow queries**.

Definition: Docker is a containerization platform that allows applications, including Java applications, to run in isolated environments called **containers**.

1ï¸âƒ£ Why Use Docker for Java Applications?

  • **Portability:** Run Java apps consistently across different environments (dev, test, production).
  • **Lightweight:** Uses fewer resources compared to virtual machines (VMs).
  • **Scalability:** Easily deploy and manage multiple instances using **Docker Compose** or **Kubernetes**.
  • **Dependency Management:** Ensures the same **JDK, libraries, and dependencies** in all environments.
  • **Faster Deployment:** Eliminates "works on my machine" issues.

2ï¸âƒ£ How Docker Works with Java Applications?

  • Package your **Java application and dependencies** into a **Docker image**.
  • Run the **image as a container** on any system with Docker installed.
  • Use **Docker Compose** for managing multi-container Java applications.

3ï¸âƒ£ Example: Dockerfile for a Spring Boot Java Application

# Use an official OpenJDK base image
FROM openjdk:17-jdk-slim

# Set working directory
WORKDIR /app

# Copy JAR file to container
COPY target/myapp.jar myapp.jar

# Expose port for the application
EXPOSE 8080

# Run the Java application
CMD ["java", "-jar", "myapp.jar"]

4ï¸âƒ£ Build and Run Java Application in Docker

# Build the Docker image
docker build -t my-java-app .

# Run the container
docker run -p 8080:8080 my-java-app

âš ï¸ Best Practices for Java & Docker:

  • Use **smaller base images** like `adoptopenjdk:17-jre-slim` to reduce size.
  • Optimize JVM options for Docker (`-XX:+UseContainerSupport`).
  • Use **multi-stage builds** to reduce final image size.
  • Store **configuration & secrets** outside the container (e.g., environment variables).

ğŸ›  Advanced Features:

  • Use **Docker Compose** for managing multiple Java microservices.
  • Deploy containers to **Kubernetes (K8s)** for scaling.
  • Monitor Java applications using **Prometheus + Grafana** in Docker.

Definition: Kubernetes (K8s) is an **open-source container orchestration platform** that automates the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

1ï¸âƒ£ Key Features of Kubernetes:

  • **Automatic Scaling:** Adjusts the number of containers based on demand.
  • **Self-Healing:** Restarts failed containers and replaces unhealthy ones.
  • **Load Balancing:** Distributes traffic across containers for efficiency.
  • **Service Discovery:** Assigns stable DNS names to services.
  • **Rolling Updates:** Deploys new versions of applications without downtime.
  • **Multi-Cloud Support:** Runs applications across different cloud providers.

2ï¸âƒ£ Kubernetes Architecture:

  • Master Node: Controls and manages the cluster.
  • Worker Nodes: Run the application containers.
  • Pods: The smallest deployable units in Kubernetes.
  • Deployments: Ensure the desired number of Pods run.
  • Services: Expose applications to the network.

3ï¸âƒ£ Example: Kubernetes Deployment for a Java Spring Boot App

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
name: spring-boot-app
spec:
replicas: 3
selector:
matchLabels:
  app: spring-boot-app
template:
metadata:
  labels:
    app: spring-boot-app
spec:
  containers:
  - name: spring-boot-container
    image: my-spring-boot-app:latest
    ports:
    - containerPort: 8080

4ï¸âƒ£ Kubernetes Commands:

# Apply deployment
kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml

# Get running pods
kubectl get pods

# Scale application
kubectl scale deployment spring-boot-app --replicas=5

âš ï¸ Best Practices for Kubernetes:

  • Use **ConfigMaps & Secrets** to manage configurations.
  • Implement **Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA)** for dynamic scaling.
  • Enable **monitoring with Prometheus & Grafana**.
  • Use **RBAC (Role-Based Access Control)** for security.

ğŸ›  Advanced Features:

  • Manage microservices with **Kubernetes Service Mesh** (Istio).
  • Use **Helm Charts** for simplified application deployment.
  • Deploy across multiple clouds using **Kubernetes Federation**.

Definition: CI/CD (Continuous Integration & Continuous Deployment) automates building, testing, and deploying microservices, ensuring **fast & reliable releases**.

1ï¸âƒ£ Key Steps in CI/CD for Microservices:

  • **Source Code Management:** Store microservices in Git repositories (GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket).
  • **Continuous Integration (CI):** Automate build & testing using Jenkins, GitHub Actions, or GitLab CI.
  • **Containerization:** Package services into Docker containers for consistent deployment.
  • **Continuous Deployment (CD):** Deploy microservices to Kubernetes or cloud platforms.
  • **Monitoring & Logging:** Use Prometheus, Grafana, ELK Stack for observability.

2ï¸âƒ£ CI/CD Pipeline Example (Jenkins + Docker + Kubernetes)

pipeline {
agent any
stages {
    stage('Clone Repo') {
        steps {
            git 'https://github.com/user/microservice-repo.git'
        }
    }
    stage('Build & Test') {
        steps {
            sh 'mvn clean package'
            sh 'mvn test'
        }
    }
    stage('Build Docker Image') {
        steps {
            sh 'docker build -t my-microservice:latest .'
            sh 'docker tag my-microservice:latest myrepo/microservice:latest'
        }
    }
    stage('Push to Docker Hub') {
        steps {
            withDockerRegistry([credentialsId: 'docker-hub', url: '']) {
                sh 'docker push myrepo/microservice:latest'
            }
        }
    }
    stage('Deploy to Kubernetes') {
        steps {
            sh 'kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml'
        }
    }
}
}

3ï¸âƒ£ Deployment Configuration (Kubernetes YAML)

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
name: microservice
spec:
replicas: 3
selector:
matchLabels:
  app: microservice
template:
metadata:
  labels:
    app: microservice
spec:
  containers:
  - name: microservice-container
    image: myrepo/microservice:latest
    ports:
    - containerPort: 8080

4ï¸âƒ£ CI/CD Tools for Microservices:

  • **Version Control:** GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket
  • **CI/CD Pipelines:** Jenkins, GitHub Actions, GitLab CI/CD
  • **Containerization:** Docker
  • **Orchestration:** Kubernetes, OpenShift
  • **Monitoring:** Prometheus, Grafana, ELK Stack

âš ï¸ Best Practices:

  • Use **feature flags** for safe deployment.
  • Enable **blue-green or canary deployments** to reduce downtime.
  • Implement **role-based access control (RBAC)** for security.
  • Ensure **automated rollback** in case of failure.

ğŸš€ Advanced CI/CD Enhancements:

  • Use **Helm Charts** to manage Kubernetes deployments.
  • Integrate **Chaos Engineering** for failure testing.
  • Implement **service mesh (Istio/Linkerd)** for traffic control.

Before Kubernetes: Different methods and tools were used to manage containerized applications.

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ Manual Container Management (Docker CLI & Docker Compose)
    • How it worked: Used docker run commands & docker-compose.yml files.
    • Limitations: No auto-scaling, no self-healing, complex networking.
  • 2ï¸âƒ£ Configuration Management Tools (Ansible, Chef, Puppet)
    • How it worked: Automated server & app deployment but lacked orchestration.
    • Limitations: No built-in scaling or dynamic load balancing.
  • 3ï¸âƒ£ Container Orchestration Systems (Before Kubernetes)
Tool Description Limitations
Docker Swarm Lightweight orchestration from Docker. Limited auto-scaling & features compared to Kubernetes.
Apache Mesos Cluster manager with Marathon for containers. Complex setup, less adoption over time.
Amazon ECS AWS-specific container orchestration. Vendor lock-in (tied to AWS).

Why Kubernetes Replaced These?

  • âœ… Automated Scaling (Auto-scales based on CPU/memory usage).
  • âœ… Self-healing (Restarts failed containers automatically).
  • âœ… Service Discovery & Load Balancing (No manual networking needed).
  • âœ… Multi-cloud & Hybrid Support (Works on AWS, GCP, Azure, On-Prem).

Definition: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) is a DevOps practice where infrastructure is provisioned and managed using code instead of manual processes.

Why Use IaC?

  • âœ… **Automation** â€“ Reduces manual effort by automating infrastructure provisioning.
  • âœ… **Consistency** â€“ Avoids configuration drift by maintaining a single source of truth.
  • âœ… **Scalability** â€“ Enables easy scaling of infrastructure for large applications.
  • âœ… **Version Control** â€“ Infrastructure configurations can be tracked using Git.
  • âœ… **Faster Deployments** â€“ Reduces deployment time by quickly spinning up environments.

Popular IaC Tools:

Tool Description Use Case
Terraform Declarative IaC tool for managing cloud infrastructure. Works with AWS, Azure, GCP, Kubernetes.
CloudFormation AWS-specific IaC tool using YAML/JSON. Best for AWS-only infrastructure automation.
Ansible Configuration management and provisioning tool. Great for automating server configurations.
Pulumi IaC tool that allows writing configurations in programming languages. Best for developers preferring TypeScript, Python, or Go.

Example: Terraform Code for AWS EC2 Instance

# Define AWS Provider
provider "aws" {
region = "us-east-1"
}

# Create an EC2 instance
resource "aws_instance" "example" {
ami           = "ami-12345678"
instance_type = "t2.micro"

tags = {
Name = "TerraformInstance"
}
}

Conclusion: IaC simplifies infrastructure management, reduces human error, and ensures **faster, more efficient** deployments in a DevOps environment.

Overview: Spring Boot and Kubernetes together provide a **scalable, resilient, and automated** deployment environment for microservices.

Key Benefits:

  • âœ… **Scalability** â€“ Kubernetes auto-scales Spring Boot applications based on demand.
  • âœ… **Self-Healing** â€“ Automatically restarts failed pods, ensuring high availability.
  • âœ… **Service Discovery** â€“ Kubernetes provides built-in service discovery for microservices.
  • âœ… **Configuration Management** â€“ Externalized configuration using ConfigMaps and Secrets.
  • âœ… **Load Balancing** â€“ Kubernetes balances traffic between application instances.
  • âœ… **CI/CD Integration** â€“ Works well with Jenkins, GitHub Actions, and ArgoCD for automated deployments.

Example: Deploying a Spring Boot App in Kubernetes

# Deployment YAML for Spring Boot App
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
name: spring-boot-app
spec:
replicas: 3
selector:
matchLabels:
  app: spring-boot
template:
metadata:
  labels:
    app: spring-boot
spec:
  containers:
  - name: spring-boot-container
    image: myrepo/spring-boot-app:latest
    ports:
    - containerPort: 8080

Example: Kubernetes Service for Spring Boot

# Exposing Spring Boot app as a service
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
name: spring-boot-service
spec:
type: LoadBalancer
selector:
app: spring-boot
ports:
- protocol: TCP
  port: 80
  targetPort: 8080

Conclusion: Spring Boot with Kubernetes enables **cloud-native development**, ensuring reliability, scalability, and **faster deployments** with minimal manual intervention.

Overview: The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is an **engine** that runs Java bytecode and provides an abstraction over the underlying hardware.

Key Components of JVM:

  • ğŸ”¹ **ClassLoader** â€“ Loads Java classes into memory.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Runtime Memory Areas**:
    • ğŸ“Œ **Method Area** â€“ Stores class metadata, static variables, and runtime constants.
    • ğŸ“Œ **Heap** â€“ Stores objects and their instance variables.
    • ğŸ“Œ **Stack** â€“ Stores method execution frames and local variables.
    • ğŸ“Œ **PC Register** â€“ Holds the current instruction being executed.
    • ğŸ“Œ **Native Method Stack** â€“ Manages native method calls.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Execution Engine**:
    • âš™ï¸ **Interpreter** â€“ Converts bytecode to machine code line by line.
    • âš™ï¸ **JIT (Just-In-Time) Compiler** â€“ Converts frequently used bytecode into native code for better performance.
    • âš™ï¸ **Garbage Collector** â€“ Automatically deallocates unused objects in the heap.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Java Native Interface (JNI)** â€“ Allows Java code to interact with native libraries.

JVM Architecture Diagram:

Example Code: JVM loads and executes Java bytecode.

public class JVMExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    System.out.println("JVM Architecture Demo!");
}
}

Conclusion: JVM provides **platform independence** by converting Java bytecode into machine-specific instructions, making Java a **"write once, run anywhere"** language.

Overview: Hibernate uses **JDBC or JTA (Java Transaction API)** to manage transactions. It ensures **ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability)** properties in database operations.

Transaction Handling in Hibernate:

  • ğŸ”¹ **Session & Transaction API** â€“ Hibernate transactions are handled via the `Session` and `Transaction` interfaces.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Commit & Rollback** â€“ Operations are committed if successful, or rolled back if an exception occurs.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Automatic & Manual Transactions**:
    • âœ… **Automatic** â€“ Managed by frameworks like Spring (via `@Transactional`).
    • âœ… **Manual** â€“ Explicitly controlled via Hibernate API.

Example: Manual Transaction Management

Session session = HibernateUtil.getSessionFactory().openSession();
Transaction transaction = null;
try {
transaction = session.beginTransaction();

// Perform database operations
User user = new User("John Doe");
session.save(user);

transaction.commit(); // Commit transaction
} catch (Exception e) {
if (transaction != null) {
    transaction.rollback(); // Rollback on error
}
e.printStackTrace();
} finally {
session.close();
}

Example: Transaction Management using Spring

@Service
public class UserService {
@Autowired
private UserRepository userRepository;

@Transactional
public void createUser(String name) {
    User user = new User(name);
    userRepository.save(user); // Transaction is handled automatically
}
}

Key Takeaways:

  • ğŸ”¹ Use **manual transactions** when fine-grained control is needed.
  • ğŸ”¹ Use **Spring @Transactional** for automatic transaction management.
  • ğŸ”¹ Always **commit or rollback** transactions to ensure data integrity.

Conclusion: Hibernate provides **flexible transaction handling**, allowing both manual and automatic management via Spring or native Hibernate API.

Overview: **CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)** and **Event Sourcing** are two architectural patterns often used together but serve different purposes.

1ï¸âƒ£ CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation):

  • ğŸ”¹ Separates the **read** (Query) and **write** (Command) operations into different models.
  • ğŸ”¹ Improves **scalability** and **performance** by optimizing reads and writes separately.
  • ğŸ”¹ Helps in **distributed systems** where read and write workloads differ significantly.
  • ğŸ”¹ Example: A microservices architecture where **commands update the database**, and **queries fetch from a read-optimized cache**.

2ï¸âƒ£ Event Sourcing:

  • ğŸ”¹ Instead of storing only the latest state, **stores a sequence of events** that led to the current state.
  • ğŸ”¹ Enables **rebuilding past states** by replaying events.
  • ğŸ”¹ Useful for **audit logs, temporal queries, and debugging**.
  • ğŸ”¹ Example: A banking system that stores **"Money Deposited"** and **"Money Withdrawn"** events instead of just an account balance.

ğŸ†š Key Differences:

Aspect CQRS Event Sourcing
Purpose Separates read and write models Stores all changes as events
Storage Stores only the latest state Keeps a full history of changes
Use Case Optimizing performance & scalability Ensuring auditability & historical analysis
State Recovery Depends on database snapshots Reconstructs state by replaying events

Example: Implementing CQRS with Event Sourcing

// Event definition
class OrderPlacedEvent {
private String orderId;
private String product;
private int quantity;
}

// Command for placing an order
class PlaceOrderCommand {
private String product;
private int quantity;
}

// Handling the command
class OrderService {
public void handle(PlaceOrderCommand command) {
    // Save event to Event Store
    eventStore.save(new OrderPlacedEvent(UUID.randomUUID().toString(), command.getProduct(), command.getQuantity()));
}
}

// Querying the read model
class OrderQueryService {
public Order getOrder(String orderId) {
    return orderRepository.findById(orderId);
}
}

Key Takeaways:

  • ğŸ”¹ **CQRS optimizes performance** by separating read and write models.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Event Sourcing ensures a full history** of state changes for traceability.
  • ğŸ”¹ Both can be used **together** to achieve **high scalability and event-driven systems**.

Conclusion: While **CQRS improves scalability**, **Event Sourcing provides historical state tracking**. They complement each other in distributed and event-driven architectures.

Overview: Docker helps package, distribute, and run Java applications in isolated containers, ensuring consistency across different environments.

1ï¸âƒ£ Why Use Docker for Java Applications?

  • ğŸ”¹ Ensures **environment consistency** across development, testing, and production.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Easier deployment** without worrying about dependencies.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Efficient resource usage** with containerized microservices.
  • ğŸ”¹ Supports **scalability** and **CI/CD automation**.

2ï¸âƒ£ Steps to Containerize a Java Application:

  • ğŸ”¹ Create a **Dockerfile** to define how your Java app should be built and run.
  • ğŸ”¹ Build the Docker image using **docker build**.
  • ğŸ”¹ Run the container using **docker run**.

3ï¸âƒ£ Example: Dockerizing a Spring Boot App

# Dockerfile
FROM openjdk:17-jdk-slim
WORKDIR /app
COPY target/myapp.jar app.jar
EXPOSE 8080
ENTRYPOINT ["java", "-jar", "app.jar"]

Commands to Build & Run:

# Build the Docker image
docker build -t my-java-app .

# Run the container
docker run -p 8080:8080 my-java-app

4ï¸âƒ£ Running Java Containers in Kubernetes:

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
name: java-app
spec:
replicas: 2
selector:
matchLabels:
  app: java-app
template:
metadata:
  labels:
    app: java-app
spec:
  containers:
    - name: java-app
      image: my-java-app
      ports:
        - containerPort: 8080

5ï¸âƒ£ Benefits of Running Java in Docker:

  • ğŸ”¹ **Faster deployment** with pre-built images.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Simplified dependency management**.
  • ğŸ”¹ **Better resource utilization** with container orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes).

Conclusion: Docker simplifies Java application deployment, making it portable, scalable, and easy to manage across different environments.

Overview: In Java, exceptions are organized into a hierarchical structure under the Throwable class. This hierarchy helps in structured exception handling.

1ï¸âƒ£ Exception Hierarchy Diagram:

          Throwable
         â”œâ”€â”€ Error (Unchecked)
         â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ StackOverflowError
         â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ OutOfMemoryError
         â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ VirtualMachineError
         â”‚   â””â”€â”€ AssertionError
         â”‚
         â””â”€â”€ Exception (Checked)
             â”œâ”€â”€ IOException
             â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ FileNotFoundException
             â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ EOFException
             â”‚
             â”œâ”€â”€ SQLException
             â”œâ”€â”€ InterruptedException
             â”œâ”€â”€ ReflectiveOperationException
             â”œâ”€â”€ RuntimeException (Unchecked)
                 â”œâ”€â”€ NullPointerException
                 â”œâ”€â”€ ArithmeticException
                 â”œâ”€â”€ IndexOutOfBoundsException
                 â”œâ”€â”€ IllegalArgumentException
                 â””â”€â”€ ClassCastException

2ï¸âƒ£ Key Categories:

  • ğŸ”¹ Checked Exceptions: Must be handled using try-catch or declared with throws.
  • ğŸ”¹ Unchecked Exceptions: Occur due to programming errors and donâ€™t require explicit handling.
  • ğŸ”¹ Errors: Indicate serious issues like JVM crashes (should not be caught).

3ï¸âƒ£ Example: Handling Checked & Unchecked Exceptions

import java.io.*;

public class ExceptionExample {
public static void main(String[] args) {
    try {
        FileReader file = new FileReader("test.txt"); // Checked Exception
    } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
        System.out.println("File not found: " + e.getMessage());
    }

    // Unchecked Exception Example
    int[] arr = {1, 2, 3};
    System.out.println(arr[5]); // Throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
}
}
